questions.text:
Which of the following enzymes are involved in gluconeogenesis? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

A. Pyruvate carboxylase

B. Phosphoenol pyruvate carboxy kinase

C. Hexokinase

D. Pyruvate kinase

E. Glucose 6 phosphatase
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A and E only

 

Gluconeogenesis bypasses the three irreversible steps of glycolysis using four specific enzymes. From the given options, only two are actual gluconeogenic enzymes. Pyruvate carboxylase converts pyruvate to oxaloacetate in the mitochondria, requiring ATP and biotin as cofactor. This is the first step in bypassing the pyruvate kinase reaction. Glucose-6-phosphatase catalyzes the final step, converting glucose-6-phosphate to free glucose, which allows glucose release from liver and kidney cells. This enzyme is absent in muscle, explaining why muscle cannot contribute glucose to the bloodstream despite having glycogen stores.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A (A, B and E only): "Phosphoenol pyruvate kinase" is not a real enzyme - this appears to be a nomenclature error. The actual gluconeogenic enzyme is phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK), which converts oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate.

 

Option B (B and C only): Neither enzyme participates in gluconeogenesis. "Phosphoenol pyruvate kinase" doesn't exist, and hexokinase catalyzes the forward glycolytic reaction (glucose → glucose-6-phosphate), consuming ATP rather than producing glucose.

 

Option D (A, B and C only): This includes both the non-existent "phosphoenol pyruvate kinase" and hexokinase, which is a glycolytic enzyme that would oppose gluconeogenesis by converting free glucose back to glucose-6-phosphate.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Among the listed enzymes, only pyruvate carboxylase and glucose-6-phosphatase are genuine gluconeogenic enzymes that help bypass the irreversible steps of glycolysis to synthesize glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. On examination, his GCS was E2M2V3. He had no fractures and no hydrocephalus or raised intracranial pressure. Non-contrast CT was performed and was found to be normal. The likely diagnosis is? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A Diffuse axonal injury

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario of the patient who had an RTA presents with an abnormal clinical manifestation and no imaging abnormality suggests diffuse axonal injury.

 

C/F: High energy trauma (road traffic accident) + Low GCS score / comatose

Initial investigation for DAI→ NCCT: Normal or tiny microbleeds

IOC for DAI → MRI

Sequence of MRI best: SWI/ Gradient MR: Shows blooming suggestive of axonal shearing

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Post-concussion syndrome: Patients with post-concussion syndrome have mild traumatic brain injury. It does not present with a severe clinical status as seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Extra Dural hemorrhage: Extradural hemorrhage results secondary to trauma to head. The bleeding is usually arterial and blood collects between outer dura and inner table of the skull. It can very well be visualized on CT.

 

Option D. Post-concussion syndrome: A cerebral herniation is a shift of cerebral tissue in an adjacent space. Intracranial brain herniation can be classified into 3 types - subfalcine, trans tentorial and tonsillar. A distinct clinical picture can be produced as a result of compression of neurovascular structures by the herniating part. CT is the imaging modality of choice because it can be done rapidly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of road traffic accidents where a patient presents with a significant neurological deficit and a normal initial CT scan, diffuse axonal injury should be considered. An MRI with specific sequences is required to confirm the diagnosis and understand the extent of injury.

questions.text: The components of qSOFA score include all except: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased heart rate

 

Quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) scoring system:

 

Other Options:

 

It uses three criteria, assigning one point each for:

 

Option A. Altered mental status

 

Option B. Low blood pressure (SBP < 100 mmHg)

 

Option C. High respiratory rate (>22 breaths per min)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequential organ failure assessment score (SOFA score), previously known as the sepsis-related organ failure assessment score, is used to track a person's status during the stay in an intensive care unit (ICU) to determine the extent of a person's organ function or rate of failure.

 

The score is based on six different scores, one each for the respiratory, cardiovascular, hepatic, coagulation, renal and neurological systems.

 

The Quick SOFA Score (quickSOFA or qSOFA) was introduced by the Sepsis-3 group in February 2016 as a simplified version of the SOFA Score as an initial way to identify patients at high risk for poor outcome with an infection.

 

The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points near the onset of infection was associated with a greater risk of death or prolonged intensive care unit stay.

choices.text: Factor VII
Factor V
Factor XII

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factor deficiency will not affect clotting in vivo? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Factor XII

 

Factor XII, also known as Hageman factor, is part of the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade. Although Factor XII is essential in the laboratory-based tests for clotting, such as the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), its deficiency does not result in a bleeding tendency in vivo.

 

  • In vivo, tissue factor (TF) plays the central role in initiating the coagulation process, which primarily involves the extrinsic pathway. The extrinsic pathway is triggered by exposure of TF to the blood, which leads to the activation of Factor VII, and subsequently, the common pathway, ultimately forming a clot.
  • Factor XII deficiency does not cause bleeding in vivo because it is not required for the tissue factor pathway, which is the primary pathway for initiating coagulation in the body. In fact, people with Factor XII deficiency do not typically experience abnormal bleeding, despite having prolonged aPTT in laboratory tests.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor VII: Essential for the extrinsic pathway; deficiency leads to bleeding disorders.

 

Option B. Factor V: Part of the common pathway; deficiency leads to bleeding disorders.

 

Option D. Factor IX: Essential for the intrinsic pathway; deficiency causes Hemophilia B, a bleeding disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor XII deficiency will not affect the clotting in vivo. In vivo, tissue factor is the major initiator of coagulation. It is amplified by feedback loops involving thrombin.

questions.text: A boy presents with pallor and lymphadenopathy; the X-ray of his skull is given below. Which of the following drug is not used for the management of the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vincristine

 

  • The X-ray of the skull is showing circumscribed punched out lesions in the skull of a boy whose history reveals the presence of pallor and lymphadenopathy. This is suggestive of Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis.
  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is a rare disease in which an excess of immature Langerhans cells (a type of white blood cell) accumulates in various parts of the body, leading to tissue damage and dysfunction.
  • The treatment of LCH depends on the severity and extent of the disease, as well as the age and overall health of the patient. Some cases of LCH can go away on their own, while others require treatment.

 

The main treatment options for LCH include:

 

1. Observation: In some cases, particularly in mild cases that only involve one or a few areas of the body, doctors may recommend monitoring the disease closely without any treatment. The goal is to watch for any changes or progression of the disease and intervene if necessary.

 

2. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy drugs are used to kill the abnormal Langerhans cells and control the disease. Some commonly used chemotherapy drugs for LCH include:

 

  • Vinblastine: Vinblastine is a chemotherapy drug that is often used as the first-line treatment for LCH, particularly in children. It works by disrupting the growth of abnormal Langerhans cells. Vincristine is not recommended for LCH.
  • Methotrexate: Methotrexate is another chemotherapy drug that is commonly used to treat LCH. It works by interfering with the growth of abnormal cells.
  • Cladribine: Cladribine is a chemotherapy drug that is sometimes used in more severe cases of LCH that do not respond to other treatments. It works by killing abnormal white blood cells.
  • Etoposide: Etoposide is a chemotherapy drug that is sometimes used in combination with other drugs to treat LCH. It works by interfering with the ability of abnormal cells to divide and grow.
  • Cyclophosphamide: Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapy drug that is sometimes used in combination with other drugs to treat LCH. It works by interfering with the growth and division of abnormal cells.

 

1. Steroids: Steroids are often used in conjunction with chemotherapy to help reduce inflammation and improve symptoms.

 

2. Immunotherapy: Immunotherapy is a newer treatment option that involves using drugs that stimulate the immune system to attack and kill the abnormal cells.

 

3. Surgery: In some cases, surgery may be needed to remove damaged or diseased tissue, particularly if it is causing significant problems or pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Cyclophosphamide: Explanation: Cyclophosphamide is used in combination with other drugs to treat LCH by interfering with the growth and division of abnormal cells.

 

Options B. Methotrexate: Explanation: Methotrexate is used to treat LCH by interfering with the growth of abnormal cells.

 

Options C. Vinblastine: Explanation: Vinblastine is commonly used as the first-line treatment for LCH, particularly in children, by disrupting the growth of abnormal Langerhans cells.

 

Options D. Vincristine: Explanation: Vincristine is not recommended for LCH. Other chemotherapy drugs like vinblastine are preferred for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH) is treated with various chemotherapy drugs, but vincristine is not typically used for this condition. Vinblastine, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and other drugs are preferred for the management of LCH.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient visits his family practitioner for a yearly examination. On examination, his BP was 190/100 mm Hg. His pulse pressure was 90 mm Hg. What would have decreased resulting in this increase in pulse pressure?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arterial wall compliance

 

Pulse pressure is the difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressure, and it reflects the compliance (elasticity) of the arterial walls. In this scenario, the patient has a high systolic blood pressure and a normal diastolic blood pressure, resulting in an increased pulse pressure of 90 mm Hg (190 mm Hg - 100 mm Hg = 90 mm Hg).

 

Arterial wall compliance refers to the ability of the arteries to expand and contract with each heartbeat, which helps maintain a steady blood pressure. Decreased arterial wall compliance leads to increased stiffness of the arteries, which can cause an increase in systolic blood pressure and pulse pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myocardial contractility: Incorrect. While myocardial contractility can influence blood pressure, it is not directly related to the increase in pulse pressure in this scenario.

 

Option B. Stroke volume: Incorrect. Stroke volume affects cardiac output and overall blood pressure but is not the primary factor in the increase in pulse pressure observed here.

 

Option D. Cardiac output: Incorrect. Cardiac output can affect overall blood pressure, but the specific increase in pulse pressure in this case is more closely linked to decreased arterial wall compliance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased arterial wall compliance leads to increased stiffness of the arteries, resulting in higher systolic blood pressure and an increased pulse pressure, as observed in the patient.

choices.text: Pernicious anemia
Carcinoid syndrome
Vit B12 Deficiency
Zollinger Ellison syndrome

questions.text: The absence of the structure marked as A will present with all except: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Zollinger Ellison syndrome

 

The eosinophilic appearing cells marked as A are the parietal cells, the absence of which is not associated with Zollinger Ellison Syndrome.

 

 

Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is caused by gastrin-secreting tumors, gastrinomas, that are most commonly found in the small intestine or pancreas. Patients often present with duodenal ulcers or chronic diarrhea. Within the stomach, the most remarkable feature is a doubling of oxyntic mucosal thickness due to a fivefold increase in the number of parietal cells It is caused by gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pernicious anemia: This condition is directly related to the absence or dysfunction of parietal cells, leading to a lack of intrinsic factor and B12 deficiency.

 

Option B. Carcinoid syndrome: While not directly related to parietal cells, the presence or absence of parietal cells might influence gastric pH and indirectly affect gastrointestinal symptoms.

 

Option C. Vit B12 Deficiency: B12 deficiency results from a lack of intrinsic factor, which is produced by parietal cells. The absence of parietal cells would lead to B12 deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The absence of parietal cells is not associated with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome but can lead to Pernicious anemia and Vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1493

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures. His CT head reveals multiple parenchymal cysts. Which of the following is correct regarding management in this case? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Steroids followed by antiparasitic drugs

 

Clinical history is suggestive of neurocysticercosis.

 

Causative organism - Larval stage (cysticercus cellulosae) of T. solium.

 

Neurocysticercosis (cysticercosis of brain) is the most common and most serious form of cysticercosis. About 70% of adult-onset epilepsy is due to neurocysticercosis. Other clinical features of neurocysticercosis are increased intracranial tension, hydrocephalus, psychiatric disturbances, meningoencephalitis, transient paresis, behavioral disorders, aphasia and visual disturbances. It is considered as the second most common cause of intracranial space occupying lesion (lCSOL) after tuberculosis in India.

 

Treatment –

 

  1. For cysticercosis, excision is the best method, wherever possible.
  2. Asymptomatic neurocysticercosis requires no treatment.
  3. For symptomatic cerebral cysticercosis, praziquantel in a dose of 50 mg/ kg in three divided doses for 20-30 days and albendazole in a dose of 400 mg twice daily for 30 days may be administered.
  4. Corticosteroids may be given along with praziquantel or albendazole to reduce the inflammatory reactions caused by the dead cysticerci.
  5. In addition, antiepileptic drugs should be given until the reaction of the brain has subsided.
  6. Operative intervention is indicated for hydrocephalus

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Antiparasitic drugs followed by steroids: The correct sequence is to give steroids first to control inflammation, followed by antiparasitic drugs.

 

Option C. Steroids before antiepileptics: While steroids are important, antiepileptics are also necessary to control seizures.

 

Option D. Continue antiepileptics: While antiepileptics are part of the treatment, steroids and antiparasitic drugs are also necessary for managing neurocysticercosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of neurocysticercosis involves administering steroids first to control inflammation, followed by antiparasitic drugs to target the larval infection, along with antiepileptic drugs to control seizures.

choices.text: Iron deficiency anemia
B12 deficiency
Hereditary spherocytosis
Acute myeloid leukemia

questions.text: What is your diagnosis with respect to the findings shown in the peripheral smear given below? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B12 deficiency

 

The peripheral smear provided shows the presence of macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils. These findings are characteristic of megaloblastic anemia, which is most commonly caused by deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate.

 

  • Macro-ovalocytes are large, oval-shaped red blood cells that result from impaired DNA synthesis, which occurs in megaloblastic anemia.
  • Hypersegmented neutrophils are neutrophils with more than the normal number of nuclear lobes (usually more than five). This is a classic finding in vitamin B12 or folate deficiency.

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to impaired DNA synthesis, causing ineffective erythropoiesis and resulting in the release of abnormally large red blood cells (macro-ovalocytes) and hypersegmented neutrophils into the circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia: This typically presents with microcytic hypochromic red blood cells, not macro-ovalocytes or hypersegmented neutrophils.

 

Option C. Hereditary spherocytosis: This condition is characterized by the presence of spherocytes (small, round, dense red blood cells) and not macro-ovalocytes or hypersegmented neutrophils.

 

Option D. Acute myeloid leukemia: AML is characterized by the presence of blasts in the peripheral blood smear, which are immature white blood cells, not macro-ovalocytes or hypersegmented neutrophils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils in a peripheral smear is indicative of B12 deficiency and megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: A male baby, born to a non-consanguineous couple, presents with blisters on areas of friction. Their previous baby also experienced similar issues and unfortunately passed away at the age of 2 weeks. What is the probable diagnosis?(INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epidermolysis bullosa

 

  • The male baby's current condition, characterized by blisters appearing in areas of friction, along with a similar history in a sibling, strongly suggests a diagnosis of a genetic condition called as epidermolysis bullosa congenita.
  • Epidermolysis bullosa is a mechano-bullous disease where blisters develop in response to mechanical trauma, often occurring in regions prone to friction such as the hands, feet, elbows, and knees.

 

 

Various types of Epidermolysis bullosa (EB) & Defects associated with them:

 

 

Other options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The likely diagnosis in a neonate presenting with blistering at areas of friction, especially with a similar family history and early demise in a sibling, is Epidermolysis bullosa, a genetic condition causing extremely fragile skin leading to blister formation with minimal trauma.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 71 Page no 71.4-71.16

questions.text: Which of the following substances can be used for new bone formation in cases of non-union fracture?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone morphogenetic protein

 

PROPERTIES OF GRAFT MATERIALS

 

 

 

  • Atrophic non union (absent callus, poor bone biology, lack of blood supply) are fixed by internal fixation with biologic stimulation.
  • Biologic stimulation is done with bone graft and bone morphogenetic protein (BMP).
  • Although the gold standard in nonunion therapy is the transplantation of autologous bone graft, missing bone regeneration subsequent to transplantation of autologous bone graft poses a serious disadvantage for the patients. Therefore, in the last few years, this therapy was combined with the application of bone morphogenetic protein-7 (BMP-7).
  • Use of BMP-7 is approved for tibial non-unions.
  • BMP-2 is approved for 1 level degenerative disk disease in spinal fusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium phosphate. Calcium Phosphate Cement is a useful bone substitute for benign bone tumor surgery. It provides excellent osteoconductivity and long-lasting stability without internal fixation.

 

Option B. Caclium sulphate. Calcium sulfate is a synthetic ceramic bone graft substitutes which has an osteoconductive property. It is a bio-inert material which gets resorbed over a period of weeks and fibrovascular tissue takes its place which eventually allows neovascularisation and bone formation within the area. Use of calcium sulfate as a bone graft substitutes avoids the complications and morbidity associated with autograft like infection.

 

Option C. PMMA. Polymethylmethacrylate is one of the most enduring materials in orthopaedic surgery. It has a central role in the success of total joint replacement and is also used in newer techniques such as percutaneous vertebroplasty and kyphoplasty.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BMP helps in bone formation and repair. Thus, for the union of non-united fractures by surgery, it is used as an autograft material.

questions.text: A man in his 50s comes to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain. During the examination, his heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is measured at 90/50mmg. Guarding is observed during a per abdomen examination. An erect abdominal X-ray is provided. What is the best management in this case based on these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exploratory laparotomy

 

Given clinical scenario of tachycardia, hypotension with abdominal guarding and X ray showing pneumoperitoneum is suggestive of hollow viscous perforation. The best management would be laparotomy and repair. The next step would be IV fluids.

 

Given the patient's severe abdominal pain, guarding during the physical examination, tachycardia, and hypotension, along with X ray findings suggest a perforation. An exploratory laparotomy would allow for direct visualization and treatment of the underlying cause. In emergent situations like this, a surgical exploration might be the most appropriate next step. Hence, OPTION C is the most appropriate choice among the given options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. USG abdomen: Ultrasonography (USG) of the abdomen is a non-invasive imaging technique used to visualize abdominal organs. It may be used for a preliminary assessment of abdominal pain, but in the case of a patient with severe pain, hemodynamic instability (as indicated by tachycardia and hypotension), and guarding, accompanied by X ray showing free air, a USG would not add to the management.

 

Option B. IV fluids: Administering IV fluids can help stabilize the patient's blood pressure and is an essential immediate measure. However, fluids alone might not address the underlying cause of perforation.

 

Option D. Elective surgery: Elective surgery is a planned procedure that is done when a condition is not immediately life-threatening. Given the severity of the patient's symptoms and the potential for an acute abdominal catastrophe, waiting for an elective procedure is not appropriate in this situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of air or gas within the peritoneal cavity, the space within the abdomen that contains the intestines, liver, and other abdominal organs.

 

Clinical Presentation and Diagnosis:

 

Patients with a significant amount of free air in the peritoneal cavity due to organ perforation often present with severe abdominal pain, signs of peritonitis (like guarding and rebound tenderness), and systemic symptoms like fever or shock. An erect abdominal X-ray is a commonly used diagnostic modality to detect pneumoperitoneum. On the X-ray, free air under the diaphragm, or "free subdiaphragmatic air", is a classic finding.

questions.text: The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fibrous joint

 

Explanation:

 

The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a fibrous joint (syndesmosis).

 

Fibrous joints are joints where bones are connected by fibrous tissue, such as ligaments or sutures.

 

Examples of fibrous joints include the sutures of the skull and the syndesmosis between the radius and ulna at the distal radioulnar joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plane synovial: Plane synovial joints are also known as gliding joints. They allow for limited gliding or sliding movements between flat articular surfaces. Examples of plane synovial joints include the intercarpal joints of the wrist.

 

Option B. Primary cartilaginous: Primary cartilaginous joints, also called synchondroses, are joints where bones are connected by hyaline cartilage. An example of a primary cartilaginous joint is the epiphyseal plate in growing long bones.

 

Option C. Secondary cartilaginous: Secondary cartilaginous joints, or symphyses, are joints where bones are connected by fibrocartilage. Examples include the intervertebral discs and the pubic symphysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Three joints connect the radius and ulna to one another:

 

  • Proximal (superior) radioulnar joint
  • Middle radioulnar joint
  • Distal (inferior) radioulnar joint

 

Proximal and distal radioulnar joints are uniaxial pivot joints (synovial) and are involved in pronation and supination movements of the forearm.

 

The middle radioulnar joint is a fibrous joint (syndesmosis). The radius and ulna, in the middle, are connected by two syndesmoses namely:

 

  1. The oblique cord - extends distally from the radial tuberosity to the radius from the lateral side of the ulnar tuberosity.
  2. Interosseous membrane - a broad, thin collagenous structure, which runs perpendicular to the oblique cord. It extends distomedially between the interosseous borders of the radius and ulna.

choices.text: Transverse perineal muscles
Transverse perineal branches of pudendal nerves

questions.text: All of the following structures are cut in mediolateral episiotomy except? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Obturator muscle

 

Explanation:

 

The obturator muscle is not cut in a mediolateral episiotomy. It is located deeper in the pelvis and is not involved in the incision made during this procedure.

 

Structures cut in a mediolateral episiotomy:

 

  • Posterior vaginal wall mucosa
  • Perineal muscles:
    • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles
    • Bulbospongiosus
    • Part of levator ani
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

 

Other options:

 

In a mediolateral episiotomy, the following structures are typically cut to facilitate childbirth:

 

Option A. Transverse perineal muscles: These include the superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles.

 

Option C. Bulbospongiosus: A muscle of the perineum that is also incised during the procedure.

 

Option D. Transverse perineal branches of pudendal nerves: These branches can be affected during the episiotomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a mediolateral episiotomy, various perineal structures, including the posterior vaginal wall mucosa, superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus, part of the levator ani, subcutaneous tissue, and skin, are incised. The obturator muscle is not involved in this procedure.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Pg 649

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Does not provide multiple doses
﻿﻿﻿Drug deposition in the oropharynx

questions.text: What is the most common drawback of the given device? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Drug deposition in the oropharynx

 

The given image shows a metered-dose inhaler (MDI). It is a common device used for delivering drugs (like inhaled corticosteroids, bronchodilators etc.) used in the management of bronchial asthma and COPD.

 

Drug Deposition in the Oropharynx is a well-recognized limitation of MDIs. A significant proportion of the medication can deposit in the oropharynx and upper airways instead of reaching the lower respiratory tract where it is needed. This not only reduces the efficiency of the drug delivery to the lungs but can also increase the risk of local side effects, such as oral thrush when using corticosteroid inhalers.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Bacterial Contamination: While good hygiene is important in the maintenance of any inhaler device, bacterial contamination is not a commonly cited primary drawback of MDIs. Regular cleaning can typically manage this risk.

 

Options B. Does Not Provide Multiple Doses: This is not accurate. MDIs are designed to provide multiple doses. They contain a pressurized canister that delivers a specific dose of medication in aerosol form with each actuation.

 

Options D. Not Portable: MDIs are actually very portable and convenient, which is one of their advantages. They are compact and easy to carry, making them suitable for use on the go.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common drawback of metered-dose inhalers (MDIs) is drug deposition in the oropharynx, which reduces the efficiency of drug delivery to the lungs and can increase the risk of local side effects.

questions.text: A young girl presents with the complaints of continuous dribbling of urine. However, she also voids normally. Her parents tell you that she had never been totally dry since her birth. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ectopic ureter

 

The clinical presentation described is most consistent with an ectopic ureter. An ectopic ureter is a congenital anomaly where the ureter does not insert into the bladder at the normal location (the trigone). Instead, it may insert outside the bladder, such as into the urethra, vagina, or other structures in females. This abnormal insertion leads to continuous dribbling of urine because the urine bypasses the bladder's normal storage function.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Continuous Urine Dribbling: The hallmark symptom of an ectopic ureter, particularly in females, is constant urinary dribbling or incontinence despite normal voiding. This is because the ureter drains urine directly into a location outside the bladder, where it cannot be stored.
  • Normal Voiding: The girl still voids normally because she likely has a second, normally positioned ureter that drains into the bladder, allowing for regular voiding alongside the continuous leakage from the ectopic ureter.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ureterocele: A ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the distal ureter as it enters the bladder, which can cause obstruction and lead to urinary symptoms. However, it does not typically cause continuous dribbling.

 

Option C. Congenital megaureter: This refers to an abnormal dilation of the ureter, usually associated with some degree of obstruction or reflux, but it does not typically present with continuous dribbling of urine.

 

Option D. Vesicoureteric reflux (VUR): VUR is the backward flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters and possibly the kidneys. It can lead to recurrent urinary tract infections and renal damage but does not typically cause continuous dribbling of urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An ectopic ureter should be suspected in a young female with continuous dribbling of urine since birth, despite normal voiding, due to the abnormal insertion of the ureter outside the bladder.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female was brought dead to the casualty. On examination there was frothing from her nose and mouth. What is the likely cause of death? (INICET NOVEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Drowning

 

The image shows frothing from nostrils which is likely to be due to drowning.

 

Postmortem changes of drowning:

 

  • Bloody froth in the airway

  • Water in the stomach and small intestine

  • Water in middle ear

  • Cerebral edema

  • Bloated and cyanosed face

  • Petrous or mastoid hemorrhage.

  • Voluminous / ballooned out lungs

  • Suffused conjunctive, dilated pupils

  • "Washerwoman" changes of the hands (shriveling of the skin) develop when submerged in water for several hours

  • Cutis anserina / goose skin- The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and a grainy appearance of the skin.

  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning.

  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.

  • Diatom test

 

Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hanging: Typically presents with a ligature mark around the neck, not frothing.

 

Option C. Strangulation: Often shows signs of external trauma to the neck, such as bruising or fractures, but not frothing.

 

Option D. Traumatic asphyxia: This results from severe chest compression, leading to petechiae and cyanosis but not usually frothing from the nose and mouth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frothing from the nose and mouth, along with other specific postmortem findings, strongly suggests drowning as the cause of death.

questions.text:
John is a 45-year-old male who has been experiencing a bulge in his groin area that becomes more prominent when he coughs or strains. He has been diagnosed with an inguinal hernia and is scheduled for surgery. Before the procedure, the surgeon explains the condition and its potential complications. Which of the following statements about inguinal hernias are true? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. Medial border of the triangle of doom is bound by gonadal vessels
  2. Medial border of the triangle of doom is bound by Vas deferens
  3. Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bound by rectus abdominis.
  4. Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bound by iliopsoas
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 and 3

 

Medial border of the triangle of doom is bounded by Vas deferens and the Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bounded by lateral border of rectus abdominis.

 

Triangle of doom boundaries:

 

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

 

 

Myopectineal orifice of Frouchard boundaries:

 

  • Medially by the lateral border of the rectus sheath.
  • Above by the arched fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscle.
  • Laterally by the iliopsoas muscle.
  • Below by the pectin pubis and fascia covering it.
  • All groin hernia- direct inguinal, indirect inguinal and femoral occur through this orifice.

choices.text: B and C
A and B
A, B, C

questions.text:
Which of the following drug reduces mortality in COVID-19 patients? (INICET Nov 2020)

A. Dexamethasone

B. Remdesivir

C. Favipiravir
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Only A

 

  • In severe COVID-19 infection, there is a systemic inflammatory response, which can lead to lung injury and multiple organ dysfunction. Corticosteroids, due to their anti-inflammatory effect, can help mitigate these negative effects and reduce the mortality in patients.
  • Only dexamethasone has been shown to reduce mortality in severe covid19 cases.
  • Dexamethasone 6 mg IV/PO once daily for 10 days or until hospital discharge is given in severe cases. In the absence of dexamethasone, equivalent doses of other corticosteroids such as prednisone, methylprednisone, or hydrocortisone may be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Remdesivir

 

  • Mechanism: Remdesivir is an antiviral drug that inhibits viral RNA polymerase.
  • Usage: It is used to reduce the duration of illness in COVID-19 patients, but it has not been conclusively shown to reduce mortality.

 

Option C. Favipiravir

 

  • Mechanism: Favipiravir is an antiviral drug that inhibits viral RNA polymerase.
  • Usage: It is used in some countries for the treatment of COVID-19, but there is no strong evidence to support a reduction in mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexamethasone is the only drug among the listed options that has been shown to reduce mortality in severe COVID-19 cases, due to its potent anti-inflammatory effects. Remdesivir and favipiravir have not demonstrated a mortality benefit.

questions.text:
Galactomannan in serum is seen in: (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. Invasive aspergillosis
  2. Systemic candidiasis
  3. Mucormycosis
  4. Cryptococcosis
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 Only

 

The galactomannan assay is used for the diagnosis of invasive Aspergillosis

 

Galactomannan (GM) belongs to a group of polysaccharides which consist of a mannose backbone and a variable number of galactofuran side chains. GM makes up a major part of the cell wall of Aspergillus spp. These galactofuranose-containing polysaccharides vary are secreted in vivo by the fungus during invasive growth. In recent years, the detection of galactofuranose-containing antigens, including GM, has been used for diagnosing invasive aspergillosis (IA).

 

The most commonly used method to determine GM in serum and broncho-alveolar lavage (BAL) fluid is a double sandwich enzyme-linked immune assay

 

Other Fungal Infections:

 

2. Systemic Candidiasis: Does not typically involve the release of galactomannan.

 

3. Mucormycosis: Caused by fungi of the order Mucorales, which do not produce  galactomannan. It has beta-D-Glucans and mannans that can be used for diagnosis of invasive candidiasis.

 

4. Cryptococcosis: Caused by Cryptococcus species, and the detection of its polysaccharide capsule antigen (cryptococcal antigen) is used for diagnosis, not galactomannan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The galactomannan assay is specifically used to diagnose invasive aspergillosis, and the presence of galactomannan in serum is indicative of this fungal infection.

questions.text:
Which of the following helps to differentiate a fixed dilated pupil? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Phenylephrine
  2. 1% Pilocarpine
  3. 0.1% Pilocarpine
  4. Cocaine 0.5%
  5. Epinephrine
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3 only

 

Pilocarpine is used to differentiate fixed dilated pupils.

 

2. 1% Pilocarpine

 

 

3. 0.1% Pilocarpine

 

 

Other Options:

 

1. Phenylephrine: This is a sympathomimetic agent that typically dilates the pupil and is not used for differentiating causes of fixed dilation.

 

4. Cocaine 0.5%: Cocaine tests for anisocoria primarily in the context of Horner’s syndrome. It blocks the reuptake of norepinephrine, failing to dilate a Horner’s pupil due to sympathetic chain lesion.

 

 

Note - Cocaine and 1% hydroxy amphetamine are used to evaluate anisocoria in smaller pupil.

 

 

5. Epinephrine: Similar to phenylephrine, epinephrine is not used to differentiate fixed dilated pupils but rather to induce dilation for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pilocarpine at concentrations of 1% and 0.1% is crucial for differentiating causes of fixed dilated pupils, with 1% identifying pharmacological blockade or nerve palsy, and 0.1% detecting hypersensitivity in cases like Adie's pupil.

choices.text: Breech identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for vaginal delivery
Breech delivery is done in a hospital where a facility for emergency cesarean delivery is available
Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labour
Should be done by a skilled obstetrician

questions.text: A woman in labour presented to the ER. A vaginal breech delivery was planned for her. What statement regarding the management is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Breech identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for vaginal delivery 

 

Breech identified for the first time during delivery is not a contraindication for normal delivery.

 

Vaginal Breech Delivery is Considered When:

 

  • Fetal weight is between 1.5 kg and 3.5 kg
  • There is an adequate pelvis
  • The presentation is frank breech
  • The fetal head is flexed
  • There are no medical or obstetric complications
  • Facilities for emergency cesarean section are available (anesthetists, neonatologists) — relates to option B
  • Facilities for continuous labor monitoring are available — relates to option C
  • A skilled obstetrician is present — relates to option D
  • Detailed informed consent has been obtained, explaining the risks of vaginal breech delivery

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breech delivery is done in a hospital where a facility for emergency cesarean delivery is available: True. Availability of cesarean facilities is critical for safety.

 

Option C. Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labour: True. Continuous fetal heart rate (FHR) monitoring is essential to ensure fetal well-being.

 

Option D. Should be done by a skilled obstetrician: True. Vaginal breech delivery requires expertise to minimize risks.

 

Educational Objective:


Breech presentation during labour is not an automatic contraindication for vaginal delivery. However, specific criteria must be met, including the availability of emergency cesarean facilities, continuous fetal monitoring, and the presence of a skilled obstetrician.

questions.text: Which fixation technique is used for fat in the histopathological examination? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Frozen section

 

Identification of neutral lipids and fatty acids in smears and tissues may require fresh smears or sometimes cryostat sections of tissue. 

 

Rapid freezing makes the tissue sample firmer and ice acts as an embedding media allowing the tissue to be sectioned.

 

Cryostat machine temperature ranges from 0°C to -35°C. Most of the tissue can be sectioned between -15°C to -25°C. Tissue samples with high water content can be sectioned at a higher temperature. The tissues with high fat content are cut at a lower temperature.

 

The stain used for fat is the oil red O stain.

 

It is used in the following conditions:

 

  • Fat emboli in lung tissue
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Sebaceous gland tumors of the skin
  • Lipid-rich carcinomas

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IHC (Immunohistochemistry): This technique is used for detecting specific proteins within tissue sections but is not specifically used for fat preservation or visualization.

 

Option C. Liquid paraffin: Liquid paraffin is most commonly used for the fixation technique in the histopathological examination. It involves the fixation of tissues using formalin and subsequent embedding in paraffin wax. This technique allows for long-term preservation of tissue morphology and cellular details, making it the standard preservation procedure.

 

Option D. Formalin fixed: Formalin fixation is the standard method for preserving general tissue morphology but is not ideal for fat preservation, as it can dissolve lipid content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcoholic formalin is the most commonly used fixation technique for preserving and examining fat in histopathological sections.

 

Liquid paraffin is the most commonly used embedding agent.

questions.text: Match the following E. coli with their respective pathogenesis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

 

The correctly matched pairs are as follows:

 

1. ETEC (Enterotoxigenic E. coli)

 

  • Mechanism: Produces a heat-stable toxin and causes activation of guanylyl cyclase.
  • Match: A. Produces a heat-stable toxin and causes activation of guanylyl cyclase.

 

2. EIEC (Enteroinvasive E. coli)

 

  • Mechanism: Invades intestinal mucosal cells.
  • Match: B. Invades intestinal mucosal cells.

 

3. EHEC (Enterohemorrhagic E. coli)

 

  • Mechanism: Produces a toxin against endothelial cells.
  • Match: C. Produces a toxin against endothelial cells.

 

4. EPEC (Enteropathogenic E. coli)

 

  • Mechanism: Adheres to the mucosal surface and causes effacement of microvilli.
  • Match: D. Adheres to the mucosal surface and causes effacement of microvilli.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Check carotid pulse, start CPR, and call for help, Defibrillate if no pulse.
Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse

questions.text: On your evening walk in the park, you notice an unconscious man lying on the ground. What would you do next? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse

 

Explanation:

 

Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse: This is the recommended sequence in most bystander situations. Firstly, ensure scene safety (make sure you're not putting yourself or the individual in further danger). Then, call for help or ask someone nearby to do so. This ensures that professional medical help is on the way. After calling for help, you’d check the pulse and breathing. If the person is not breathing and/or doesn’t have a pulse, you would start CPR. If an Automated External Defibrillator (AED) is available and the person doesn’t have a pulse, you would use it as soon as possible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Check carotid pulse, start CPR, and call for help, Defibrillate if no pulse: While checking the pulse and starting CPR is correct, calling for help first ensures that professional medical assistance is on the way, which is crucial for the best chance of survival.

 

Option C. Observe: This is not the recommended approach. Immediate intervention is critical when someone is unconscious, especially if they are not breathing or lack a pulse. Delays in initiating CPR or calling for help can drastically reduce the chance of survival and increase the potential for permanent injury.

 

Option D. Ignore and continue to walk: This is not an ethical or appropriate response when encountering someone in potential distress. Immediate action can make the difference between life and death.

 

Educational Objective :

 

In an emergency situation where someone is unconscious, the immediate steps should be to call for help, check for a pulse and breathing, start CPR if needed, and use a defibrillator if available and the person has no pulse.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 2715-2716

questions.text:
You are posted as an intern in casualty. An elderly 60-year-old man is brought to you with complaints of chest pain. He has tested positive for COVID. Which of the following features will prompt you to get this patient admitted to dedicated COVID health centre? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

A. Respiratory rate of 25/min

B. SpO2 93%

C. Multiple comorbidities

D. Age
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A, B, C & D only

 

A & B Respiratory rate of 25/min and SpO2 93% : Both of these values are indicative of potential respiratory compromise, which is concerning in a COVID-19 patient. These values suggest the need for closer monitoring and possible oxygen supplementation.

 

C. Multiple comorbidities: Patients with multiple comorbidities are at a higher risk of severe disease and complications from COVID-19, warranting admission for close monitoring and treatment.

 

D. Age: Age is a known risk factor for severity and complications in COVID-19. Older patients, like the 60-year-old man in the scenario, generally have poorer outcomes and may benefit from hospital care.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When evaluating a COVID-19 patient for hospital admission, consider clinical signs of respiratory distress, overall oxygen saturation, presence of comorbidities, and age due to their significant impacts on disease severity and outcome.

questions.text:
Which of these is the definition of effective CPR?

 

  1. Respiratory rate: 20 - 24 breaths per minute.
  2. Chest compressions: 100-120/min.
  3. Allow complete chest recoil.
  4. 5-6 cm depression.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 2, 3 and 4

 

Components of High-Quality CPR:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Effective CPR includes the following components:

 

  • Chest compressions: 100-120/min. This ensures that the heart is pumping enough blood to maintain circulation during cardiac arrest.
  • Allow complete chest recoil. Allowing the chest to fully recoil between compressions ensures that the heart fills adequately with blood between each compression, which is crucial for effective circulation.
  • 5-6 cm depression. The depth of chest compressions should be between 5-6 cm (2-2.4 inches) for adults. This depth is essential to create enough pressure to maintain circulation.

 

Other Option:

 

  1. Respiratory rate: 20-24 breaths per minute. This is not correct for effective CPR. The recommended respiratory rate during CPR is about 10-12 breaths per minute when an advanced airway is in place. Higher respiratory rates can lead to hyperventilation, which can be detrimental.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Effective CPR is characterized by chest compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute, allowing complete chest recoil, and compressing the chest to a depth of 5-6 cm.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2529-2534

questions.text:
What are the objective tests used to assess hearing?

 

  1. BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry)
  2. OAE (Otoacoustic emission)
  3. PTA (Pure tone audiometry)
  4. Tympanometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

 

Objective hearing tests are those that do not require a response from the patient and are used to assess hearing ability or the integrity of parts of the hearing pathway.

 

1. BERA - Also called BAER or BAEP (brainstem auditory evoked response or potential) is an objective test to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts. It is a noninvasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the VIIIth nerve, pons and midbrain

 

 

2. OAE is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by outer hair cells of a normal cochlea and can be elicited by a very sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal and analyzed by a computer.

 

4. Tympanometry is an objective test for compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system.

 

 

 

Other Option:

 

3. Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA): PTA requires the patient's active participation to indicate when a sound is heard. It tests the hearing threshold levels of an individual, enabling determination of the degree, type, and configuration of a hearing loss, thus classifying it as a subjective test.

 

Other examples of subjective tests include tuning fork tests and speech audiometry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Objective tests such as BERA, OAE, and Tympanometry provide essential diagnostic data without requiring any active response from the patient, thus suitable for use in patients who may not be able to respond reliably, such as young children or those with certain disabilities.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 25, 26, 29

questions.text:
You are working as a casualty medical officer. A 16-year-old girl is brought to the casualty by her parents after alleged sexual assault, the girl refuses physical examination. Which of the following would you do?

  1. Start treatment for STD and pregnancy

  2. Inform the police

  3. Record refusal of consent

  4. Take vaginal samples

  5. Start medical examination
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 2 and 3

 

As the girl is under 18 years of age, the medical practitioner must follow the guidelines of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act 2012, which include:

 

1. Start treatment for STD and pregnancy: The medical officer should begin prophylactic treatment for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and pregnancy to ensure the girl's health and safety.

 

2. Inform the police: It is mandatory to report the alleged sexual assault to the police, as it involves a minor.

 

3. Record refusal of consent: The refusal of the girl to undergo a physical examination must be documented properly to respect her autonomy and legal rights.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Take vaginal samples: This should not be done without the girl's consent, as it violates her autonomy and legal rights.

 

5. Start medical examination: Any physical examination must be consented to by the patient. In this case, the girl has refused consent, so the examination should not proceed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As the girl is under 18 years of age, as per POCSO (The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences) act 2012, the medical practitioner should start treatment for STI & pregnancy, inform the police and record the refusal of consent for examination

choices.text: Presence of a mass in the periumbilical region
Brilliant transillumination when a light is shone through the mass
Mobility of the mass perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line
Positive fluctuation observed when the mass is pressed

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the Tillaux sign? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mobility of the mass perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line

 

Tillaux sign is seen in presence of mesenteric cyst, which shows mobility perpendicular to line of mesenteric attachment.

 

The Tillaux sign refers to the observation that a tumor arising from mesentry, typically a mesenteric cyst will move in a direction perpendicular to the line of mesenteric attachment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of a mass in the periumbilical region: While the presence of a mass can be indicative of many conditions, the Tillaux sign specifically refers to the mobility of a mass in relation to the mesentery attachment, not merely the presence of a mass.

 

Option B. Brilliance of transillumination when a light is shone through the mass: This describes the positive transillumination test that might be observed in cystic masses like hydroceles or  superficial cysts with clear fluid like ranula.

 

Option D. Positive fluctuation observed when the mass is pressed: This refers to a fluctuation test, where pressing on one side of a fluid-filled mass results in a palpable bulge or movement on the opposite side. This indicates the presence of fluid within the mass but isn't related to the Tillaux sign.

 

In summary, the Tillaux sign helps in the clinical assessment of abdominal masses, with the mass's mobility providing clues about its origin and location in relation to the mesentery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tillaux's sign is positive when a mesenteric cyst is present, and the mass or swelling is mobile perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line. Mesenteric cysts are typically found in the small intestine (60%) or colon (40%) and can be classified as chylolymphatic (the most common type), enterogenous, urogenital remnant, or dermoid. These cysts are commonly found in adults and are characterized by a painless abdominal swelling with physical signs (Tillaux triad) such as a fluctuant swelling near the umbilicus, a mass that moves freely in a plane perpendicular to the attachment of the mesentery (known as Tillaux's sign), and the presence of a zone of resonance around the cyst.

 

Tillaux triad of mesenteric cyst:

 

  1. Soft fluctuant periumbilical lump
  2. Movement perpendicular to mesenteric attachment
  3. Zone of resonance around the lump

questions.text: The following sets of X-rays are suggestive of:(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
  • It is a seronegative chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis & synovitis.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years.
    • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, associated with morning stiffness for few hours that improves with activity.
    • Question mark (?) posture due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Hip and shoulder joint arthritis may occur.
    • Peripheral joints may also be involved in some.
    • Anterior uveitis is the most common extra-articular manifestation.
       
  • Spine radiograph:
    • Loss of lumbar lordosis (Straightening).
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.
    • Later on, SI joints show irregular subchondral erosions in, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
    • Calcification of supraspinous & interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacrotuberous ligaments.
    • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons & ligaments.
    • Trolley/Tram-track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
    • Erosions of anterior corners of vertebral body causing squaring of vertebral body.
    • Bridging osteophytes (syndesmophytes) with vertical orientation bridging vertebral bodies are seen. Bamboo spine appearance due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

 

 

A. Trolley/Tram track sign; B. Bamboo Spine

 

 

Dagger Sign

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paget’s disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. It is the osteoclast that appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. The new bone formed is abnormal, very vascular and larger (deforms and fractures) than preexisting bone which leads to cortical widening and contributes to the deformity. Long bone X-ray shows deformity, enlargement or expansion of bone with cortical thickening coarsening of trabecular markings and lytic and sclerotic changes. Blade of grass lesion is seen. Skull X-ray reveal “cotton wool” or osteoporosis circumscripta, thickening of diploic area. Vertebral cortical thickening at superior and inferior end plates creates a picture frame vertebrae and diffuse sclerosis causing ivory vertebrae. Pelvic radiograph shows sclerotic iliopectineal line (Brim sign), fusion or disruption of sacroiliac joints, etc.

 

 

Blade of grass appearance

 

 

 

 

Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis. In rheumatoid arthritis, upper cervical spine & hip joint are less commonly involved. There is atlantoaxial joint subluxation when cervical spine is involved. Lumbar spine is usually spared. The chronic inflammatory synovitis in the cervical spine results in severity that progresses to bone erosion and ligamentous laxity, leading to late spinal instability. The most common radiological presentations of spinal involvement in RA are: atlantoaxial subluxation, cranial settling (also known as basilar impression, atlantoaxial impaction or superior migration of the odontoid, the most severe form of spinal instability in RA), subaxial subluxation or a combination of them.

 

 

Option D. Hyperparathyroidism. Hyperparathyroidism maybe primary (due to adenoma or hyperplasia), secondary (due to persistent hypocalcemia) or tertiary (when secondary hyperplasia leads to autonomous overactivity). Parathyroid adenoma is most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism. It presents with subperiosteal resorption, and replacement of endosteal cavitation marrow by vascular granulation and fibrous tissue (osteitis fibrosa cystica). Classical and pathognomic feature of hyperparathyroidism is subperiosteal cortical resorption of middle phalanges on radial aspect. Clinical features are Abdominal groans (dyspepsia), psychic moans, renal stones and weak bones (Groans, moans, stones and Bones). Hyperparathyroidism causes diffuse rarefaction of bone (osteopenia) and osteitis fibrosa cystica. Radiological Features includes subperiosteal resorption of terminal tufts of phalanges, lateral end of clavicle and symphysis pubis, loss of lamina dura (i.e. thin cortical bone of tooth socket surrounding teeth is seen as thin white line, is resorbed), irregular, diffuse rarefaction of bones, i.e. generalized osteopenia, thinning of cortices, and indistinct bony trabeculae, brown tumor, salt pepper appearance of skull.

 

 

 

Resorption of lamina dura

 

 

Salt-pepper skull

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

The radiographic images given the question shows:

 

A. Bamboo spine

 

B. Sacroiliitis

 

C. Loss of lumbar lordosis

 

D. Dagger’s sign

 

These features are characteristic of Ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: A 14-month-old child with Hb 6.3 was undergoing repeated blood transfusions. The last transfusion was given in the 9th month. Which of the following investigation is used for a definitive diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Globin gene sequencing

 

Based on the clinical presentation of low hemoglobin levels, the presence of target cells in the blood smear, and the need for repeated blood transfusions, the most likely diagnosis is thalassemia. Thalassemia is an inherited disorder affecting the production of alpha- or beta-globin chains, leading to an imbalance in globin chain synthesis. This imbalance results in ineffective erythropoiesis and hemolysis, requiring frequent blood transfusions.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Thalassemia: A genetic disorder that can be categorized into alpha-thalassemia and beta-thalassemia based on the affected globin chain. The severity of the condition depends on the number of functioning globin genes.
  • Definitive Diagnosis: The definitive diagnosis of thalassemia is made through globin gene sequencing, which identifies mutations in the genes encoding the globin chains.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC): HPLC is used as a screening tool for thalassemia and other hemoglobinopathies by analyzing hemoglobin fractions. However, it is not definitive for diagnosing thalassemia.

 

Option B. Ferritin levels estimation: Ferritin levels are used to assess iron stores in the body, particularly in cases of iron deficiency anemia or iron overload. It is not diagnostic for thalassemia.

 

Option C. Bone marrow aspiration: While bone marrow aspiration can reveal ineffective erythropoiesis and hypercellularity, it is not used for a definitive diagnosis of thalassemia.

 

Hemoglobin Patterns:

 

  • Normal Hemoglobin Pattern: HbA = 95%, HbA2 = 3.5%, HbF = 1.5%
  • Beta-thalassemia Trait: HbA = 90%, HbA2 = 5%, HbF = 5%
  • Beta-thalassemia Intermedia: HbA = 45%, HbA2 = 5%, HbF = 50%

 

Hemoglobin Electrophoresis is another tool used for screening, often complemented by HPLC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Globin gene sequencing is the definitive test for diagnosing thalassemia, a genetic disorder affecting hemoglobin production.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman who presented with complaints of fever and joint pain develops the following lesion on her nose after a few days of taking NSAIDs. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chikungunya

 

  • The patient's medical history is indicative of a potential diagnosis of Chikungunya (CKG) infection.
  • Chikungunya is a mosquito-borne viral illness presenting with fever, joint pain, and potential rash.

 

 

Fig: Nose pigmentation

 

IMAGE DEPICTING CHIK SIGN

 

  • It can cause skin hyperpigmentation, especially on the nose and cheeks, known as the "Chik sign."
  • The "Chik sign" is distinctive to Chikungunya and is not usually seen with other viral infections.
  • The nose pigmentation may last three to six months post-infection, aiding in clinical and retrospective diagnosis.
  • This pigmentation pattern serves as a clinical marker for Chikungunya infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melasma:

 

Typically presents as symmetric brown patches on the face, especially the cheeks, bridge of the nose, forehead, chin, and above the upper lip as shown in the image below.

 

 

It is often triggered by sun exposure or hormonal changes, such as pregnancy or use of oral contraceptives.

 

Option B. Fixed drug eruption (FDE):

 

  • It is a type of allergic reaction to medications. It presents as well-demarcated, round, or oval patches of redness and swelling that can later become brown.
  • However, FDEs are typically recurrent in the same location when the offending drug is taken again, and the presentation isn't specifically associated with the symptoms described.

 

Option C. Dengue:

 

  • While dengue fever is also a mosquito-borne viral infection leading to symptoms like fever, headache, and joint pains, it does not typically result in brownish pigmentation on the nose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of fever, body ache, and joint pain, followed by the development of brownish pigmentation on the nose, Chikungunya is the probable diagnosis, as it can present with persistent joint pain and hyperpigmentation, particularly in regions where the virus is endemic.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a good prognostic factor in schizophrenia? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insidious onset of symptoms

 

Insidious onset of symptoms, where the symptoms develop slowly and subtly over time, tends to indicate a poorer prognosis when compared to an abrupt or sudden onset of symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Schizophrenia's prognosis varies based on several factors:

 

Option A. Positive symptoms: Positive symptoms such as hallucinations and delusions are usually more responsive to antipsychotic medications, marking them as a better prognostic factor.

 

Option B. Late age of onset: Late age of onset indeed is a better prognostic factor. Early-onset schizophrenia tends to be more severe and has a poorer prognosis than schizophrenia that begins in adulthood.

 

Option D. Associated with depression: If a patient with schizophrenia also has depressive symptoms, the prognosis might be somewhat better since affective symptoms might respond to treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 62.

questions.text: Which of the following systems exhibits a feedback gain of infinity in negative feedback mechanism? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blood volume control by kidney

 

The regulation of blood volume by the kidney, it operates through a negative feedback mechanism. When blood volume decreases, the kidney responds by conserving water and producing concentrated urine to help increase blood volume. Conversely, when blood volume increases, the kidney excretes excess water to reduce blood volume. This process is regulated by hormones like aldosterone and antidiuretic hormone (ADH) and helps maintain the body's fluid balance within a relatively narrow range until the error becomes zero leading to infinite gain. 

 

The feedback gain is designed to be adaptive and responsive, preventing extreme deviations but not amplifying them to infinity. The other options (B. Temperature control in hypothalamus and C. BP control by baroreceptors) also involve negative feedback mechanisms that aim to maintain stability, not infinite gain.

 

Negative feedback is a regulatory mechanism in which a system responds to a stimulus by producing an output that opposes the stimulus, thereby reducing the deviation from the desired set point. In such a system, the feedback gain refers to the strength of the feedback loop, or the degree to which the output is affected by changes in the input.   

However, it is not possible to have an infinite feedback gain in any system, as this would result in an uncontrollable, unstable response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Temperature control in hypothalamus: This system also uses negative feedback but does not achieve infinite gain. The hypothalamus regulates body temperature by initiating responses that either dissipate heat (e.g., sweating) or conserve heat (e.g., shivering).

 

Option C. BP control by baroreceptors: Baroreceptors provide negative feedback for blood pressure control by adjusting heart rate and vessel diameter. While effective, this system does not have infinite gain.

 

Option D. Infinite gain is not possible: In practical terms, infinite gain is not achievable in biological systems due to the inherent delays and limitations in feedback mechanisms. However, the concept can be used to describe highly effective regulatory systems, such as the kidneys' role in blood volume control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood volume control by the kidney exemplifies a highly effective negative feedback mechanism, theoretically approaching infinite gain by maintaining blood volume within a narrow range. While true infinite gain is not possible in biological systems, the kidneys' regulatory function is exceptionally efficient.

questions.text:
A woman presented with morning stiffness that gradually resolves over one hour. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. NSAIDs can improve the symptoms and have disease modifying activity.
  2. Absence of erosion rules out the diagnosis.
  3. It is associated with raised ESR and CRP.
  4. HLA DR4 is related to the prognosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) III, IV are correct

 

RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic non-suppurative inflammation of the synovial joints.
  • Clinical Features:
    • It occurs between the age of 20 and 50 years.
    • Women are affected about 3 times more commonly than men.
    • Older women (> 60 year) are 6 times more commonly involved than younger one.
    • It may present as:
      • An acute, symmetrical polyarthritis
      • Pain and stiffness in multiple joints (at least four), particularly in the morning, mark the beginning of the disease.
      • This may be followed by frank symptoms of articular inflammation.
      • The joints affected most commonly are the metacarpophalangeal joints, particularly that of the index finger.
         
  • Joints affected in Rheumatoid arthritis:
    • Common: MCP joints of hand, PIP joints of fingers, wrists, knees, elbows, ankles, MTP joint
    • Less common: Hip joint, temporo mandibular joint
    • Uncommon: Atlanto-axial joint, facet joints of cervical spine
    • Usually DIP is not involved in and is not used for diagnosis but is involved when swan neck and boutonniere deformity develops.
    • Lumbar Spine is usually spared.
       
  • The onset may be with fever, the cause of which cannot be established (PUO), especially in children.
  • Sometimes, visceral manifestations of the disease such as pneumonitis, rheumatoid nodules etc. may antedate the joint complaints.
  • Inflammatory markers like ESR and CRP are elevated.
  • Some studies have shown that HLA DR4 positivity affects the prognosis.
  • Deformities in Rheumatoid Arthritis:

 

 

  • Radiological Features:
    • Reduced joint space
    • Erosion of articular margins
    • Subchondral cysts
    • Juxta-articular rarefaction
    • Soft tissue shadow at the level of the joint because of joint effusion or synovial hypertrophy
    • Deformities of the hand and fingers
       
  • Treatment:
    • Exercises to maintain muscle strength and joint mobility.
    • NSAIDs
    • Glucocorticoid therapy esp. in vasculitis.
    • Immunosuppressive therapy by leflunomide, DMARDs, methotrexate (drug of choice), anticytokine, etanercept, cyclosporine, infliximab, adalimumab, abatacept.

 

Other Options:

 

  • NSAIDs are anti-inflammatory drugs and not disease-modifying drugs. NSAIDs are used for symptomatic treatment in RA. They have few side effects but also have potential adverse effects like GI bleeding.
  • Bone erosion is a central feature of rheumatoid arthritis and is associated with disease severity and poor functional outcome. Erosion of periarticular cortical bone, the typical feature observed on plain radiographs in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, results from excessive local bone resorption and inadequate bone formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis presents with raised serum ESR and quantitative CRP levels, and HLA DR4 positivity.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a type of subcortical dementia?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pick's disease

 

To approach this question, we need to differentiate between cortical and subcortical dementias.

 

This is a type of frontotemporal dementia and is cortical. It primarily affects the frontal and temporal lobes. Memory may be preserved in the early stages, but personality and language changes are prominent. Therefore, it doesn't fall under the subcortical category, making it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Parkinson's disease: Parkinson's primarily affects the basal ganglia in the brain, which is a subcortical structure. The primary symptoms are motoric (tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia), but dementia can develop in the later stages of the disease.

 

Option C. Huntington's disease: This is a genetic disorder that affects the basal ganglia, especially the caudate nucleus, which is also a subcortical structure. Cognitive decline and psychiatric symptoms are common.

 

Option D. Wilson's disease: This is a genetic disorder that leads to copper accumulation in the body, including the brain. The basal ganglia is one of the primary areas affected, making the dementia subcortical in nature.

 

Given the options, Pick's disease is the only cortical dementia, making it the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 24.

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressants causes the least sexual dysfunction? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mirtazapine

 

The typical antidepressants (SSRI, SNRI, MAO inhibitors and TCA) are notorious for causing sexual disturbances like erectile dysfunction due to increased levels of serotonin. On the other hand, atypical anti-depressants (like mirtazapine and bupropion etc) have lesser propensity to cause these adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Fluoxetine: As a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), fluoxetine is commonly associated with sexual dysfunction, including decreased libido, difficulty achieving orgasm, and erectile dysfunction.

 

Options B. Venlafaxine: This is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). While perhaps slightly less likely to cause sexual side effects than SSRIs, venlafaxine can still lead to sexual

dysfunction in a significant number of patients.

 

Options D. Imipramine: A tricyclic antidepressant (TCA), imipramine can cause sexual dysfunction, often due to its anticholinergic effects. TCAs, in general, are more likely to cause a variety of side effects, including those affecting sexual function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant. Apart from increasing the levels of serotonin and nor-adrenaline (due to blockade of presynaptic alpha 2 receptors), It also acts as an antagonist of serotonin (5-HT2 and 5-HT3) receptors. It has some degree of H1 blocking property also. It is therefore known as NSSA (Nor adrenergic and Specific Serotonergic Antidepressant). Mirtazapine is generally associated with a lower incidence of sexual side effects compared to SSRIs and SNRIs, making it a better option for patients concerned about these issues.

questions.text: M3 incisional hernia refers to: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Umbilical

 

According to the European Hernia Society classification, M3 incisional hernia refers to umbilical hernia.

 

M=Midline, L=Lateral

 

M1: defect up to 3 cm below xiphoid

 

M3: Defect within 3 cm of umbilicus (above or below)

 

M5: Defect up to 3 cm above pubis

 

M2: Defects between M1 and M3

 

M4: Defects between M3 and M5.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman visits an infertility clinic. She has a regular 28-day cycle. How should she be evaluated? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serum progesterone on day 21

 

Explanation:

 

For a woman with a regular 28-day cycle, serum progesterone is typically measured on day 21 to assess for ovulation. Progesterone levels on day 21 of the menstrual cycle provide information about whether ovulation has occurred.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Day 21 Progesterone Measurement: In a regular 28-day cycle, day 21 corresponds to the mid-luteal phase, about 7 days after ovulation. Progesterone levels peak during this time, and values above 10 ng/mL are indicative of ovulation.
  • Purpose: This test helps to determine if the cycles are ovulatory or anovulatory.

 

Other tests for ovulation:

 

  • Basal body temperature: A biphasic temperature pattern suggests ovulation.
  • Urinary LH kits (ovulation prediction kits): Ovulation occurs the day following the peak LH surge.
  • Endometrial biopsy: This can provide histological confirmation of ovulation.
  • Ultrasonography: Follicular tracking can visualize the growth and rupture of the follicle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum progesterone on day 14: Measuring progesterone on day 14 is not useful as it corresponds to the follicular phase when progesterone levels are low and not indicative of ovulation.

 

Option C. Serum LH on day 14: While an LH surge around day 14 can indicate impending ovulation, it does not confirm that ovulation has actually occurred.

 

Option D. Serum LH on day 21: Measuring LH on day 21 is not useful for assessing ovulation, as LH levels peak around mid-cycle and are not elevated during the luteal phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a woman with a regular 28-day menstrual cycle, measuring serum progesterone on day 21 is the appropriate method to evaluate for ovulation, with levels above 10 ng/mL indicating that ovulation has occurred.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg435

questions.text: Which of these hormones have intracellular receptors? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thyroxine

 

  • Thyroxine hormone act by binding to intracellular nuclear receptors.
  • All other hormones mentioned in the options bind to receptors on the cell membrane.
  • Thyroxine crosses the plasma membrane for its action.
  • The thyroid hormone receptors are either attached to the DNA genetic strands or located in proximity to them. The thyroid hormone receptor usually forms a heterodimer with retinoid X receptor (RXR) at specific thyroid hormone response elements on the DNA. On binding with thyroid hormone, the receptors become activated and initiate the transcription process.
  • Then large numbers of different types of messenger RNA are formed, followed within another few minutes or hours by RNA translation on the cytoplasmic ribosomes to form hundreds of new intracellular proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epinephrine: Epinephrine binds to adrenergic receptors on the cell membrane, which are G protein-coupled receptors, and does not use intracellular receptors.

 

Option C. Glucagon: Glucagon binds to glucagon receptors on the cell membrane, which are also G protein-coupled receptors, and does not use intracellular receptors.

 

Option D. Parathormone: Parathormone (PTH) binds to PTH receptors on the cell membrane, which are G protein-coupled receptors, and does not use intracellular receptors.

 

Educational Objective:
