Thyroxine acts by binding to intracellular nuclear receptors, initiating transcription and subsequent protein synthesis. This distinguishes it from hormones like epinephrine, glucagon, and parathormone, which bind to receptors on the cell membrane.

questions.text: A rose gardener with a history of thorn prick presents with the following lesions. What is the possible causative agent? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sporothrix schenckii

 

Diagnosis from the given findings is Sporotrichosis.

 

Few important points about Sporotrichosis:

 

  • Caused by Sporothrix schenckii
  • An acute or chronic fungal infection where, a linear distribution of nodules is seen Commonly in gardeners, florists due to high thorn prick possibility.

 

Clinically presents with Linear nodulo-ulcerative lesions (Sporotrichoid) aligned along lymphatics, with Satellite lesions.

 

Sporotrichoid lesions also seen in:

 

  • Fish tank/Swimming pool granuloma
  • Lupus vulgaris.

 

The given image shows the distribution of lesions along lymphatics.

 

 

Histopathology: Asteroid bodies are seen as shown in the image below.

 

 

Treatment: Itraconazole / Terbinafine / Saturated solution of Potassium Iodide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pyogenes:

 

  • While Streptococcus pyogenes can cause skin infections, it is not typically associated with thorn pricks or rose gardening.
  • This bacterium is more commonly linked with pharyngitis, scarlet fever, and rheumatic fever.

 

Option C. Strongyloides stercoralis:

 

  • This is an intestinal nematode and is not associated with skin lesions from thorn pricks.
  • It primarily causes gastrointestinal symptoms and can cause systemic disease in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus:

 

  • This bacterium can indeed cause skin infections, but the scenario described is not its classic presentation.
  • Staphylococcus aureus can take advantage of wounds to cause infection, but it is not specifically associated with thorn pricks or rose gardening

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a history of thorn prick, especially a gardener, presenting with nodular lesions along lymphatic channels, the most likely causative agent is Sporothrix schenckii, responsible for sporotrichosis, a fungal infection commonly associated with gardening activities.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition, Chapter 32 Page no 32.71

Illustrated synopsis of dermatology & sexually transmitted diseases page no 297

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine, 21st edition Page no 1542

choices.text: CO2 retention due to opioid use

questions.text:
A patient presented with pelvic fracture and head trauma after a road traffic accident.

He was given IV morphine for pain relief following which he developed respiratory difficulty. What could be the most likely cause? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CO2 retention due to opioid use


The development of respiratory difficulty in a patient who received IV morphine for pain relief after sustaining a pelvic fracture and head trauma can be due to several reasons.

 

Opioids like morphine can depress the respiratory center in the brain, leading to decreased respiratory rate and tidal volume. This can result in CO2 retention and respiratory difficulty, particularly in higher doses or in patients with pre-existing respiratory issues. This is a well-known side effect of opioids and is a common cause of respiratory depression following opioid administration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pelvic Fracture: While a pelvic fracture can be severe and cause significant pain, it is not typically directly associated with the development of respiratory difficulty unless there are associated injuries, such as a pneumothorax or hemorrhage leading to shock.

 

Option C. Cerebral Edema: Head trauma can lead to cerebral edema, which in turn can affect the brain's respiratory center. However, the onset of respiratory difficulty immediately following opioid administration suggests that the opioid's effects are more likely to be the cause, rather than a progression of cerebral edema, which usually develops over a longer period.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Embolism: A pulmonary embolism (PE) is a possible complication following trauma and immobilization. However, the immediate onset of respiratory difficulty after opioid administration makes PE less likely as the primary cause in this scenario.

 

Considering the timing and circumstances, the most likely cause of the respiratory difficulty in this patient is CO2 Retention due to Opioid Use. Morphine and other opioids can cause respiratory depression, leading to reduced ventilation and CO2 retention.

 

  • The CO2 retention can also increase the ICP. Apart from that, miosis is produced by morphine, which makes it difficult for assessment of neurological status in head trauma patients. Therefore, morphine is contraindicated in head injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Opioids like morphine can cause respiratory depression by decreasing the respiratory rate and tidal volume, leading to CO2 retention. This effect is particularly concerning in patients with head trauma due to the potential for increased intracranial pressure.

questions.text: A public health officer is reviewing populations targeted by the HIV sentinel surveillance program. Which group is NOT traditionally included in HIV sentinel surveillance? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) STD clinic attendees

 

  • Routine monitoring for HIV is generally not conducted among individuals visiting STD clinics.
  • Sentinel surveillance serves to enhance the existing notification systems employed for disease surveillance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Single male migrants: Included in sentinel surveillance as they are considered at high risk.

 

Option B. Truck drivers: Included due to their high-risk behavior.

 

Option D. Antenatal women: Included to monitor HIV prevalence among pregnant women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sites for HIV sentinel surveillance includes:

 

  • A pregnant woman of reproductive age and attending the antenatal clinic for the first time.
  • Female sex workers.
  • Hijra/Transgenders.
  • IV drug users
  • Truckers.
  • Homosexual Men
  • Migrants.

choices.text: Pulmonary infarction
Diffuse alveolar damage
Endothelial injury

questions.text: The most common lung finding in COVID 19 infection is? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diffuse alveolar damage

 

Diffuse alveolar damage may be seen in patients suffering from COVID-19.

 

COVID-19 related histopathological changes in the lungs include:

 

  1. Incipient pulmonary damage in early-stage disease with intraalveolar edema, endothelial necrosis, microthrombosis, and endothelialitis.
  2. Pneumocyte type 2 hyperplasia in exudative phase
  3. Multiple intraalveolar giant cells in exudative phase
  4. Hyaline membranes and solid fibrin deposits in exudative phase
  5. Thrombosis in small- to medium-sized vessels in early-stage lung disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary infarction: While pulmonary infarctions may occur due to thromboembolism, they are not the primary lung finding in COVID-19.

 

Option C. Endothelial injury: Endothelial injury does occur in COVID-19 and contributes to microvascular damage and thrombosis, but it is part of the broader picture of diffuse alveolar damage.

 

Option D. Fibrin clots: Fibrin clots are seen in COVID-19 as part of the coagulopathy associated with the disease, but they are secondary findings within the context of DAD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diffuse alveolar damage is the most common and significant lung finding in severe COVID-19 infection, leading to the clinical syndrome of ARDS.

questions.text: The structures marked in the image below are found in the epithelial lining of all of the following sites, except? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Epididymis

 

The picture depicts an arrow mark pointing in the direction of the cilia. All of the structures listed as choices have ciliated lining epithelia, with the exception of the epididymis, which has pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia, that’s play a role in sperm maturation and storage.

 

The given image is a histological section of the epididymis showing the pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia.

 

 

Cilia are minute hair-like projections, while stereocilia are very long, thick microvilli measuring about 5-10 um in length.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oviduct (Fallopian Tube): The oviduct, also known as the Fallopian tube, is a part of the female reproductive system. It contains ciliated epithelium, which helps in the transport of the egg from the ovary to the uterus. The cilia in the oviduct assist in moving the egg and help in the fertilization process.

 

Option C. Bronchi: The bronchi are part of the respiratory system and are responsible for conducting air to and from the lungs. They contain ciliated epithelium to help move mucus and trapped particles out of the respiratory tract.

 

Option D. Ependyma : it is a type of neuroglial cell that lines the ventricles of the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord. It contains ciliated epithelium, which assists in the circulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the central nervous system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ciliated epithelium:

 

  • The epithelium bears cilia, which moves in a coordinated fashion, and help in the movement of the mucus, or propel the movement of any other structures such as ova or spermatozoa.
  • The ciliated columnar epithelium is found in most of the respiratory tract, the uterus, and the uterine tube (oviduct), efferent ductules of the testis, parts of the middle ear and auditory tube; the ependyma lining the central canal of the spinal cord and the ventricles of the brain.
  • The pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium is seen in the trachea and in large bronchi.

questions.text: Methylisothiazolinone (MI) in cosmetics is used as? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Preservative

 

Methylisothiazolinone (MIT) is a preservative present in various facial cosmetics, deodorants, sunscreens, and industrial products. The frequency of contact dermatitis resulting from either Methyl-chloro-isothiazolinone/methylisothiazolinone (MCI/MIT or Kathon CG) or MIT has been on the rise.

 

 

Moreover, there have been reported cases of severe airborne and generalized dermatitis caused by exposure to MIT through recently painted walls and even from toilet cleaners.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

It's important to understand that Methylisothiazolinone (MI) is used as a preservative in cosmetics to prevent microbial growth, distinguishing it from surfactants, humectants, and emulsifiers, which have different functional roles in product formulation.

 

Ref:

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 128, Page no 128.36

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4689087/

questions.text: What is absent in a case of otitis media among the options provided? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Battle's sign

 

Battle's sign, characterized by ecchymosis (bruising) over the mastoid process, is typically indicative of a basilar skull fracture, specifically fractures involving the temporal bone. It is not associated with otitis media, which is an infection or inflammation of the middle ear.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bezold abscess: This abscess is a serious complication of otitis media. It occurs when the infection spreads from the mastoid process into the surrounding tissues, leading to a collection of pus.

Option B. Griesinger's sign: This sign is associated with lateral sinus thrombosis, a rare but severe complication of otitis media and mastoiditis. It involves tenderness and swelling behind the ear and along the mastoid bone.

Option D. Delta sign: Also related to lateral sinus thrombosis, the Delta sign typically appears on contrast-enhanced imaging studies as a NON enhancement at thrombosed area of sinus, a complication arising from otitis media.

Educational Objective:

 

While otitis media can lead to various complications, including Bezold abscess and lateral sinus thrombosis (indicated by Griesinger’s sign and Delta sign), Battle's sign is not associated with this condition. Instead, Battle's sign should prompt an evaluation for temporal bone fractures, emphasizing the importance of distinguishing between signs of infection and trauma.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 87, 93, 507

questions.text: You are a researcher aiming to compile and analyze data from various independent studies to enhance the precision of treatment effect estimates for a specific medical condition. Which of the following methodologies is most appropriate for achieving this objective? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Meta-analysis

 

Preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality:

 

  • 1st preference: Meta-analysis
  • 2nd preference: Randomised controlled trials (RCTs)
  • 3rd preference: Retrospective (Non-concurrent/ Historical) cohort study
  • 4th preference: Prospective cohort study (Concurrent cohort study)
  • 5th preference: Case control study
  • 6th preference: Cross-sectional study
  • 7th preference: Ecological study

 

Meta-analysis

 

  • An objective, systematic review that employs statistical methods to combine and summarize the results of several studies. 
  • A quantitative synthesis of all unbiased evidence, meant for summarizing large volume of data, establishing and determining the magnitude of an effect, and to increase power and precision of studies

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort study: Observational study design, not suitable for synthesizing data from multiple studies.

 

Option B. Systematic review: Provides a qualitative synthesis of evidence but does not statistically combine results.

 

Option D. RCT (Randomized Controlled Trial): Primary study design, not a method for combining results from multiple studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meta-analysis is the most effective quantitative approach for synthesizing data from multiple research studies to derive a more precise estimate of the treatment effect.
  • Preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality - 1st preference is - Meta-analysis

questions.text: What is the action of the muscle at the hip, which is attached to the marked area in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Extension and lateral rotation

 

Explanation:

 

The primary actions of the gluteus maximus are hip extension and lateral rotation. These actions are important for movements like standing up from a sitting position, climbing stairs, and running.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abduction and external rotation: The gluteus maximus does contribute to abduction but not external rotation. The primary muscles responsible for hip external rotation are the deep muscles of the hip joint i.e., Piriformis, gemelli superior and inferior, quadratus femoris.

 

Option C. Extension, adduction, and lateral rotation: While extension and lateral rotation are correct, adduction is not a primary action of the gluteus maximus. Adduction is more associated with the adductor muscles of the thigh (muscles of medial compartment of thigh).
 

 

Option D. Flexion and abduction: Flexion and abduction are not the primary actions of the gluteus maximus. These movements are primarily associated with other muscles like the iliopsoas for hip flexion and the tensor fasciae latae for hip abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gluteus maximus muscle, which is attached to the gluteal tuberosity of the femur, primarily performs hip extension and lateral rotation. These actions are essential for tasks such as standing up, climbing stairs, and running. Remember, despite contributing to abduction, the gluteus maximus does not support external rotation as a primary action.

questions.text: A patient is unable to abduct his arm. Which of the following root values is likely to be affected? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. C5

 

Explanation:

 

The most likely cause of the inability to abduct the arm is a C5 root lesion.

 

The C5 spinal nerve plays a crucial role in controlling shoulder abduction. It gives rise to the axillary nerve, which innervates the deltoid muscle. Damage or compression of the C5 nerve root or axillary nerve can result in weakness or paralysis of the deltoid muscle, leading to difficulty in abducting the arm.

 

Deltoid is supplied by axillary nerve which has the root value of C4-C6. The C5 component is responsible for abduction.Other components help in flexion and extensionm at shoulder joint

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C4: The C4 spinal nerve does not directly innervate the muscles responsible for shoulder abduction. It primarily supplies sensory information to areas of the neck and upper shoulders.

 

Option C. C6: The C6 spinal nerve primarily innervates the muscles responsible for elbow flexion and wrist extension, not shoulder abduction. Damage to the C6 nerve root would affect these functions rather than shoulder abduction.

 

Option D. C7: The C7 spinal nerve primarily innervates the muscles responsible for elbow and wrist flexion and finger extension. It is not directly involved in shoulder abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscles of the shoulder

choices.text: Upper GI endoscopy and 24-hour PH monitoring

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic with a complaint of difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids for the last eight months. A barium swallow test has been conducted, and the results are available for review. What further investigations are required for this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper GI endoscopy & Manometry

 

The given scenario of long standing dysphagia in a 45 year old, with barium swallow showing smooth tapering is suggestive of achalasia. Next investigations would be upper GI endoscopy (to rule of cancer) and esophageal manometry (IOC).

 

  • Upper GI endoscopy: This procedure involves a visual examination of the esophagus, allowing the physician to see any obstructions, lesions, or abnormalities that could be causing dysphagia like cancer
  • Manometry: Manometry measures the pressures and coordinated muscle contractions of the esophagus. It's particularly helpful for conditions like achalasia, where there's an absence of normal esophageal peristalsis and increased lower esophageal sphincter tone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Upper GI endoscopy & PET scan: While a PET scan can identify metabolic activity and might be useful in detecting metastasis, it isn't a first-line test for dysphagia. The primary concern with dysphagia is often mechanical or functional obstruction, which a PET scan wouldn't directly address.

 

Option C. Upper GI endoscopy & CECT: CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography) can provide images of the esophagus, but it is not the primary modality for evaluating dysphagia. While it can identify masses or structural issues, it doesn't offer functional insights like manometry.

 

Option D. Upper GI endoscopy and 24-hour PH monitoring: 24-hour pH monitoring assesses the acidity in the esophagus over 24 hours. While it can be valuable for diagnosing conditions like GERD, it's not the primary investigation for dysphagia unless reflux symptoms are predominant

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Achalasia is a disorder of the esophagus characterized by absent peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the LES.
  • Manometry is the most sensitive test to diagnose achalasia and can identify early disease before esophageal dilatation and food retention.
  • The diagnostic criteria for achalasia with manometry are impaired LES relaxation, absent peristalsis, and elevated LES pressure. Subtypes are classified according to Chicago classification as Type 1 (classical), Type 2 (pan-esophageal pressurisation) and type 3 (Spastic).
  • Endoscopy can rule out pseudo achalasia/carcinoma.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway: (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Cochlear nucleus
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Inferior colliculus
  5. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 - 1 - 3 - 4 - 5

 

The auditory pathway is the sequence of neural structures that sound information travels through from the ear to the brain for processing. The correct sequence from the initial sensory input at the ear to the higher centers of the brain is as follows:

 

2. Spiral ganglion : Contains the cell bodies of the auditory nerve fibers. These neurons receive mechanical sound vibrations converted into electrical signals by the hair cells of the cochlea.

 

1. Cochlear nucleus : The first brainstem nucleus where auditory nerve fibers synapse. This nucleus begins the central processing of auditory information.

 

3. Superior olivary nucleus : Receives inputs from both cochlear nuclei and is involved in binaural cues for sound localization.

 

4. Inferior colliculus : A midbrain nucleus that acts as a major relay and integration point for auditory information.

 

5. Medial geniculate body : Part of the thalamus that acts as the final relay station for auditory information being sent to the auditory cortex in the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA). 
    1. Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve
    2. Cochlear Nucleus
    3. Superior Olivary nucleus
    4. Lateral lemniscus
    5. Inferior colliculus
    6. Medial geniculate body
    7. Auditory cortex
  • The spiral ganglion situated in Rosenthal's canal contains bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells join to form the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve which ends in the cochlear nuclei.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs promotes bone formation? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Teriparatide
 

  • Teriparatide is recombinant PTH analogue that is used in the treatment of osteoporosis. When given in low doses, it stimulates bone formation by mimicking the physiological action of PTH on the osteoblasts.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Calcitonin: Mechanism: Calcitonin inhibits osteoclast activity, reducing bone resorption. It helps maintain bone density but does not stimulate new bone formation.

 

Options B. Raloxifene: Mechanism: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM). It inhibits bone resorption by reducing osteoclast activity and is used to prevent bone loss in postmenopausal women, but it does not promote bone formation.

 

Options C. Bisphosphonates: Mechanism: Bisphosphonates, such as alendronate and risedronate, inhibit osteoclast-mediated bone resorption. These drugs help maintain bone density and reduce the risk of fractures, but they do not promote new bone formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DRUGS USED IN OSTEOPOROSIS

questions.text: Gibbs free energy curve of an enzyme-catalysed reaction is given by? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A

 

Among the shown options, Gibbs free energy change of an enzyme-catalysed reaction is shown by A.

 

Formation of a product requires the breaking of substrate bonds and conformational change forming a highly unstable transitional state intermediate, it requires energy and this is called Gibbs free energy of activation. In an enzyme-catalysed reaction, this energy barrier is reduced by forming a relatively stable intermediate-enzyme complex. The enzyme provides attachment sites for the substrate and speeds up the rate of reaction. It doesn't change the Gibbs energy of either the substrate or the product. Gibbs free energy curve of an enzyme-catalysed reaction (with no intermediate state) is shown in the image given below.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: All the reactions have a transition state, but not all reactions have an intermediate state. There are 2 reasons as to why option B

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Transition state intermediate usually has higher energy compared to the substrate or product. Very unusually a dip might be seen like this when the enzyme-intermediate complex is more stable than the product, and the product is not formed.
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Every intermediate state is again, always followed by another transition state. Therefore, every reaction, if it has an intermediate state, needs to have two transition states as shown in the image given below. We don't have 2 such transition states in curve B in the question, which makes it an incorrect answer.

 

 

Option C: Free energy change cannot be a straight line. It has to pass through a high energy intermediate state

 

Option D: Transition energy intermediate never has lower energy compared to the product

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gibbs free energy curve of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction is best represented by Curve A, which shows the formation of a transition state and the reduction in activation energy, leading to the production of the final product.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient comes to the clinic with a history of rapidly enlarging swelling in her right breast for the last 15 days. During the physical examination, there was a local rise in temperature, and the lump was partially mobile over the chest wall. What could be the probable diagnosis for this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inflammatory carcinoma

 

Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) is a rare and aggressive form of breast cancer. It presents with rapid onset of swelling (edema), redness (erythema), and warmth due to its tendency to block the lymphatic vessels in the skin of the breast. This blockage leads to the classic "peau d'orange" appearance, resembling the skin of an orange. A local rise in temperature and rapid progression of symptoms (as in 15 days) can be consistent with inflammatory carcinoma. The tumor might be mobile initially, but as the disease progresses, it becomes fixed. Given the described symptoms and rapid onset, inflammatory carcinoma is a probable diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Giant fibroadenoma: Fibroadenomas are benign tumors composed of glandular and connective tissue. They are usually painless, mobile, and have a rubbery consistency. While they don't typically present with inflammation or a rapid onset of symptoms, giant fibroadenomas are larger than typical fibroadenomas (>5cm). They are seen in the 15 to 25 year old age group.

 

Option C. Phyllodes tumor: Phyllodes tumors are rare breast tumors that can be benign, borderline, or malignant. They can grow quickly and become quite large, and while they might be mobile, they do not typically present with inflammatory signs like warmth or redness.

 

Option D. Galactocele: A galactocele is a milk-filled cyst that can form in the breast. It typically presents in women who are lactating or have recently stopped lactating. While a galactocele can cause a lump in the breast, it doesn't cause inflammatory symptoms such as a local rise in temperature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the given scenario, the patient's rapid onset of disease and examination findings suggest inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, which is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer.
  • Inflammatory breast cancer typically presents with brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (Peau d'orange appearance), along with a breast lump.
  • Skin biopsy is used to diagnose inflammatory breast cancer.
  • The treatment for inflammatory breast cancer includes combined-modality treatment, such as neoadjuvant chemotherapy, mastectomy, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy for ER-positive tumors, and Trastuzumab for HER-2-positive tumors.

questions.text:
The following are true about chancroid: (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. School of fish appearance
  2. Bleeds on touch
  3. Painful
  4. Groove sign
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A, B, & C

 

Chancroid is caused by the bacterium Hemophilus ducreyi and results in painful, superficial ulcers, often with regional lymphadenopathy.

 

H. ducreyi is a small, fastidious gram-negative rod that requires an enriched growth medium cultivated in a high humidity, CO2-enriched environment. On Gram stain, long strands of organisms are seen in a pattern often referred to as a "school of fish" or "railroad track" in appearance.

 

Typically, an erythematous papule develops at the site of inoculation, which quickly becomes a pustule and subsequently develops into an extremely painful ulcer with soft irregular margins, often referred to as a "soft chancre." Multiple ulcers may be noted either as a result of multiple areas of microtrauma or as a result of direct contact between two adjacent areas resulting in "kissing ulcers." The ulcer typically has a friable base with yellow-gray exudate, which easily bleeds when abraded and varies in size, typically from 1 to 2 cm. Left untreated, the lesion spontaneously resolves within 1 to 3 months.

 

Other Option:


D. Groove sign: This is typically associated with lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) and not chancroid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, is characterized by painful ulcers with a friable base that easily bleeds and has a "school of fish" appearance on Gram stain. The "groove sign" is not associated with chancroid but rather with lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV).

questions.text: A 38-year-old chef presented with complaints of leg pain and swelling. Upon examination, he was diagnosed with varicose veins. Further examination revealed the presence of skin eczema and lipodermatosclerosis. According to the CEAP classification system, He would be classified as: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) C4

 

Explanation of the CEAP Classification:

 

The CEAP classification is a system used to categorize venous disease based on clinical, etiologic, anatomic, and pathophysiologic criteria. Here's a breakdown:

 

  • C: Clinical classification
  • E: Etiologic classification
  • A: Anatomic classification
  • P: Pathophysiologic classification

 

The "C" or clinical classification is divided as follows:

 

  • C0: No visible or palpable signs of venous disease.
  • C1: Telangiectasias or reticular veins.
  • C2: Varicose veins.
  • C3: Edema.
  • C4: Skin changes without ulceration. This is further divided into:
    • C4a: Pigmentation or eczema.
    • C4b: Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche.
    • C4c: Corona phlebectatica
  • C5: Skin changes with healed ulceration.
  • C6: Skin changes with active ulceration.

 

In summary, the patient's symptoms of varicose veins combined with skin changes such as eczema and lipodermatosclerosis correspond to the C4 classification in the CEAP system.

questions.text: Which protein is present in the HPV vaccine? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L1

 

9-valent HPV vaccine (Gardasil-9) is a non-infectious recombinant vaccine prepared from the purified virus-like particles (VLPs) of the major capsid (L1) protein of HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.

 

Available HPV vaccines protect against either two, four, or nine types of HPV. All HPV vaccines protect against at least HPV types 16 and 18, which cause the greatest risk of cervical cancer. It is estimated that HPV vaccines may prevent 70% of cervical cancer, 80% of anal cancer, 60% of vaginal cancer, 40% of vulvar cancer, and show more than 90% efficacy in preventing HPV-positive oropharyngeal cancers. They additionally prevent some genital warts, with the quadrivalent and nonavalent vaccines that protect against HPV types HPV-6 and HPV-11 providing greater protection.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. E6, E7: These proteins are oncogenes that contribute to the development of cancer by interfering with tumor suppressor proteins such as p53 and Rb but are not components of the vaccine.

 

Option C. E1, E2: These are early proteins involved in the replication and regulation of HPV DNA but are not used in the vaccine formulation.

 

Option D. L2: This is a minor capsid protein of HPV, but the vaccine primarily uses the major capsid protein L1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HPV vaccine contains the L1 protein, which forms virus-like particles that induce an immune response to prevent infection by various HPV types, significantly reducing the risk of HPV-associated cancers and genital warts.

questions.text: The correct order of steps in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Denaturation, Annealing, Extension

 

Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is a widely used method to amplify specific DNA segments. The process involves three main steps that are repeated in cycles, resulting in the exponential amplification of the target DNA sequence.

 

Steps of PCR:

 

 

The steps of 1, 2 and 3 are repeated results in the exponential amplification of DNA segments of defined length. In each cycle, the DNA strands are doubled. Thus 20 cycles provide for 1 million times amplifications. These cycles are generally repeated by automated instrument, called Thermal cycler.

 

After the amplification procedure, DNA hybridization technique or Southern blot analysis with a suitable probe, shows the presence of the DNA in the sample tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of steps in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is Denaturation, Annealing, and Extension. These steps are repeated in cycles to exponentially amplify the target DNA segment.

questions.text: A patient comes with palpitation to ER. His Pulse-180/min and BP-70mm of Hg systolic. ECG shows narrow QRS complex tachycardia with regular heart rate. What is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DC cardioversion

 

For a patient presenting with hemodynamically unstable symptoms such as a significantly low blood pressure and a high heart rate, as indicated by a pulse of 180/min and systolic BP of 70 mmHg, immediate DC cardioversion is indicated. This procedure is critical for restoring normal heart rhythm and preventing further cardiovascular compromise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valsalva Maneuver: it is typically used in stable patients to attempt cardioversion of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) back to a normal rhythm. It is not suitable for patients showing signs of hemodynamic instability.

 

Option C. Adenosine: it is effective in terminating certain types of SVT by temporarily blocking the AV node but is used in stable patients. Given the patient's low BP, this is not the first-line approach.

 

Option D. Verapamil: it is a calcium channel blocker used for rate control in cases of SVT, more appropriate for stable patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DC cardioversion is the emergency treatment of choice for a patient with hemodynamically unstable narrow QRS complex tachycardia, as it quickly restores normal rhythm and stabilizes the patient.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Cardiology/SVT/chap 246

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Marbling

 

  • The post mortem change shown above is marbling.

  • In marbling, blood vessels are visible on the skin as greenish-black streaks and eventually results in skin discoloration ranging from green to black, due to the formation of sulphmethemoglobin, which starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in 36-48 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Postmortem lividity: This is the settling of blood in the lower parts of the body after death, causing a purplish-red discoloration. It does not produce the distinct streaks seen in marbling.

 

Option C. Filigree burns: These are burns that produce a lace-like pattern on the skin, usually caused by electrical injuries. They do not match the appearance shown in the image.

 

Option D. Subcutaneous emphysema: This occurs when air is trapped under the skin, often due to trauma or infection, leading to a characteristic crackling sensation when pressed. It does not produce the streaked pattern seen in marbling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marbling is a postmortem change characterized by greenish-black streaks on the skin due to the formation of sulfhemoglobin, becoming prominent 24-48 hours after death.

questions.text: A patient underwent LASIK for myopia and now is undergoing cataract surgery. What is the formula used for lens power calculation in this patient?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Haigis-L  

 

  • The Haigis-L regression formula is used for lens power calculation in patients undergoing cataract surgery with a past history of LASIK for myopia.
  • Corneal refractive surgery significantly affects the IOL power required, making standard IOL calculations unsuitable.
  • Several methods of calculating corneal refractive power are used, such as the double-K method, Masket and modified Masket, and Haigis-L formulas.
  • The Haigis-L regression formula uses statistical data to facilitate calculation on post-refractive surgery eyes using only standard inputs.
  • It may be prudent to utilize more than one method of IOL calculation.

 

NEWER IOL POWER CALCULATION FORMULAE FOR POST REFRACTIVE SURGERY PATIENTS ARE –

 

  • Wang-Koch-Maloney
  • Shammas
  • Haigis-L
  • Galilei
  • Potvin-Hill Pentacam
  • Barrett True K No History      

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SRK 1 and Option B. SRK 2: These are older formulas that do not account for post-refractive surgery changes in corneal curvature and are less accurate in such cases.

 

Option C. Hoffer Q: While useful for eyes with shorter axial lengths, this formula also does not specifically adjust for the changes induced by corneal refractive surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients who have had previous corneal refractive surgery like LASIK, specialized IOL calculation formulas such as Haigis-L should be used to ensure accurate lens power calculation for cataract surgery. This formula specifically addresses the altered corneal parameters to provide a more precise refractive outcome.

questions.text: Apart from the abdomen, which body part is included in e-FAST? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thoracic cavity

 

eFAST or extended FAST covers 4 regions of abdomen (epigastrium, right and left paracolic areas and pelvis) and both the thoracic spaces.

 

Correct. The e-FAST exam extends the basic FAST exam by including views of the thoracic cavity, specifically looking for evidence of pneumothorax or hemothorax. This is done by assessing the pleural spaces on both sides of the chest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retroperitoneum: These injuries are often missed on e-FAST.

 

Option B. Peripheral vessels: Peripheral vessels are not the primary focus of the e-FAST exam. The main goal of e-FAST is to rapidly identify free fluid in specific body cavities that might indicate trauma.

 

Option D. Dural and subdural spaces: These spaces are within the cranial cavity and pertain to the brain. They are not part of the e-FAST exam.

 

In summary, the e-FAST exam primarily evaluates the abdomen for evidence of trauma, but it also extends to the thoracic cavity to look for signs of pneumothorax or hemothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

E-FAST stands for Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma, which is a bedside ultrasound examination used to evaluate trauma patients. It involves the use of a portable ultrasound machine to assess for free fluid in the abdomen, chest, and around the heart.

 

 

In addition to identifying free fluid, e-FAST can also be used to evaluate for other injuries, such as pneumothorax, hemothorax, and pericardial effusion. E-FAST has become a standard of care in trauma evaluation and is a valuable tool in the early detection and treatment of life-threatening injuries.

choices.text: Central line insertion
Arterial line insertion

questions.text: The given set of instruments are used in? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Airway management

 

Explanation:

 

The instruments shown in the image are part of an airway cart. The equipment typically found in an airway cart is designed for managing the airway during anesthesia or in emergency situations. The contents of the airway cart usually include:

 

  • Laryngoscope: A device used to obtain a view of the vocal folds and the glottis, which is essential for endotracheal intubation.
  • Tracheal tubes of various sizes: These tubes are used to secure the airway by passing through the trachea.
  • Masks: Various types of masks to deliver oxygen or anesthetic gases.
  • Laryngeal mask airways (LMA): A device placed over the laryngeal inlet to provide ventilation.
  • Flexible fiberoptic intubation equipment: Used for intubation in difficult airway situations.
  • Retrograde intubation equipment: Tools used for intubation when conventional methods fail.
  • Front of neck access equipment: Devices for surgical airway access.
  • Equipment required for emergency invasive airway access: Tools needed for emergency tracheostomy or cricothyrotomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central line insertion: This procedure requires different instruments such as central venous catheters, guidewires, dilators, and sterile drapes.

 

Option B. Arterial line insertion: This involves the use of arterial catheters, guidewires, and transducers, not typically found in an airway cart.

 

Option D. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR): CPR primarily requires defibrillators, chest compression devices, and basic airway management tools like bag-valve masks (BVM), but not the comprehensive set shown for airway management.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The instruments in an airway cart are specifically designed for various procedures involved in airway management, including intubation and emergency airway access.

choices.text: FeSO4 + Vit C + Folate + Vit B12

questions.text: You work as a medical officer in a Primary Health Center (PHC). You are tasked with developing a strategy to address widespread anemia in the community. Considering the need for efficacy, safety, and ease of administration, which of the following options would you recommend for the prevention and treatment of anemia in this setting? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) FeSO4 + Vit C + Folate + Vit B12

 

  • Among the given options, FeSO4 + vitamin C + Folate + vitamin B12 is likely to be the best mass prophylaxis against anemia.
  • Vit C enhances the absorption of iron from the stomach by acting as a reducing substance.
  • Supplementing vitamin B12 can reduce incidence and prevalence of megaloblastic anemia as cost factor is not that significant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Iron (III) hydroxide polymaltose: It is not yet evident to be more efficacious than FeSO4

 

Option C. Ferrous fumarate: It is considered to be equally efficacious but vitamin C as an adjunct improves absorption.

 

Option D. Injection iron sucrose: Injection iron sucrose or any parenteral form is a first-line option. It is only indicated if the oral form is not tolerated or patient is not compliant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The comprehensive and cost-effective approach, including FeSO4 + Vitamin C + Folate + Vitamin B12, is preferable for the widespread prevention and treatment of anemia in a community setting, especially in a resource-limited Primary Health Center (PHC).

questions.text:
A 23-year-old medical student developed epistaxis that resolved spontaneously. He has been afebrile for the last 24 hours and his platelet count is 14,000/µL. His BP is 110/70 mm of Hg and there is a 28% rise in hematocrit. What should be the management? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

1. Give 4 units of platelets

2. Give plenty of oral fluids

3. Give IV fluids

4. Keep under observation

5. Discharge the patient
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 3 and 4

 

The patient likely has Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever, indicated by a significant rise in hematocrit, which suggests plasma leakage during the critical phase of the illness. The management strategy includes:

 

  • Statement 2. Oral fluids to maintain hydration but must be balanced to avoid fluid overload.
  • Statement 3. IV fluids are essential for the management of severe dengue to correct the plasma leakage and prevent shock.
  • Statement 4. Observation is crucial to monitor for further complications such as dengue shock syndrome.

 

Option A. 1 and 2: Platelet transfusion is generally reserved for severe bleeding or very low platelet counts (typically <10,000/µL without bleeding). This patient's platelet count, while low, does not alone justify transfusion without signs of active or severe bleeding.

 

Option C. 1, 2 and 4: Includes unnecessary platelet transfusion without the clear presence of severe bleeding or extremely low platelet counts.

 

Option D. 2 and 5: Discharging the patient is inappropriate given the potential for rapid deterioration during the critical phase of dengue fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In dengue hemorrhagic fever, management focuses on careful fluid management and close observation during the critical phase to prevent or manage complications such as shock. Platelet transfusions are not routinely given based solely on low counts but are reserved for cases of significant clinical bleeding or extremely low platelet counts.

 

Note - There is no correlation between bleeding manifestation and platelet count.

 

Reference - Dengue Case management for Clinicians- CDC

questions.text: The radiograph presented below has been taken to enhance the evaluation of the frontal sinus. What is the widely used term for this particular perspective?(INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Caldwell view

 

  • The above X ray shows the Caldwell view in which the frontal sinus is best seen.
  • Caldwell view (Occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position) is taken with nose and forehead touching the film and X-ray beam is projected 15–20° caudally.
  • Structures seen are:
    1. Frontal sinuses (Best Visualization).
    2. Ethmoid sinuses.
    3. Maxillary sinuses.
    4. Frontal process of zygoma and zygomatic process of frontal bone.
    5. Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea.
    6. Superior orbital fissure.
    7. Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water's view: Primarily used for examining the maxillary sinuses and can also show the frontal sinuses but with less clarity than the Caldwell view.

 

Option C. Pierre's view: This is not a standard term in radiographic terminology.

 

Option D. Towne's view: Used to visualize the occipital bone and foramen magnum, not typically used for sinus examination.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: A-1, B-3, C-4, D-2
A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3
A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2
A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

questions.text: Match the following bacteria with the drug of choice used for each? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3

 

  1. Vancomycin is Drug of Choice for Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) – It acts by inhibiting the cell wall synthesis and is a bactericidal drug.
  2. Metronidazole drug of choice against anaerobic infections caused by Bacteroides.
  3. Meropenem is used in infections caused by Klebsiella. Klebsiella is known to produce ESBL (Extended Spectrum Beta Lactamases). Carbapenems are not hydrolyzed by ESBL. Therefore, carbapenems like imipenem, meropenem, ertapenem are indicated in the treatment of infections caused by ESBL producing bacteria.
  4. Penicillin like amoxicillin, ampicillin can be used in H. influenzae infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Metronidazole is the drug of choice for anaerobic infections caused by Bacteroides.
  • Vancomycin is the drug of choice for infections caused by MRSA.
  • Penicillins like amoxicillin and ampicillin are used for Haemophilus influenzae infections.
  • Meropenem is used for infections caused by Klebsiella, particularly ESBL-producing strains.

choices.text: 1 & 3; a, c, d
2 & 4; b, c, e
1 & 3; a, d
2 & 4; b, e

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy collapsed while playing football. ECG showed V5, V6 inversion and prominent inverted T-waves. 2D echocardiography showed the septal anterior motion of mitral valve leaflet. Which of the following features will be seen on clinical examination and which of the following are true regarding the management? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

Clinical findings

 

a. Pulsus bisferiens

b. Pulsus alternans

c. Ejection systolic murmur

d. Murmur increases on standing

e. Murmur decreases on standing

 

Management

 

1. Beta-blockers are given

2. Beta-blockers are contraindicated

3. ICD is indicated

4. ICD is contraindicated
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 & 3; a, c, d

 

The echocardiography findings and symptoms are indicative of Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM). In HCM, due to the thickening of the heart muscle, there is a dynamic obstruction to blood flow, often worsening with decreased preload, such as when standing.

 

  • Pulsus bisferiens (a) is commonly observed in conditions like HCM, where there are two distinct peaks in arterial pulse per cardiac cycle due to the dynamic obstruction.
  • Ejection systolic murmur (c) is typical in HCM and is due to the obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract.
  • Murmur increases on standing (d) in HCM due to increased obstruction with reduced venous return.

 

Regarding management:

 

  • Beta-blockers (1) are typically used in HCM to manage symptoms and reduce heart rate, thereby decreasing myocardial oxygen demand and the degree of obstruction.
  • ICD (Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator) (3) is recommended in patients with HCM who are at high risk of sudden cardiac death.

ICD indicated for all patients with ≥1 risk factor for SCD or HCM-AF score >6%

 

MAVACAMTEN is recently approved drug which modulates b-myosin heavy chain (↓Bridging & Inotropy) & reduces the need for ablation by 80% in long term

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. This is incorrect as it suggests that beta-blockers are contraindicated and includes "murmur decreases on standing," which is not characteristic of HCM. Pulsus alternans (b), indicative of severe heart failure, is not typical in HCM without heart failure.

 

Option C. It misses the key management and diagnostic features by excluding the ejection systolic murmur, which is a significant finding in HCM.

 

Option D. This incorrectly includes beta-blockers as contraindicated and excludes the key symptom of an ejection systolic murmur. It also incorrectly suggests that ICD is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Key Points:

 

  • All murmurs decrease on standing except MVP and HCM.
  • Pulsus bisferiens can be seen in HCM
  • HCM is characterized by myocyte disarray & fibrosis causing increase risk of sudden cardiac death & arrhythmias.
  • Pulsus alternans is seen in LVF

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Basics of CVS/Chap 239

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is suffering from selective mutism. He is most probably suffering from? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Childhood anxiety disorder

 

Selective mutism is an anxiety disorder where a child speaks in some settings (like home) but consistently remains silent in others (like school).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Childhood depression: Children with depression might withdraw but don't exhibit selective mutism.

 

Option B. Childhood psychosis: Psychosis presents with hallucinations or delusions, not selective mutism.

 

Option D. Hyperkinetic disorder: ADHD involves inattention or hyperactivity, not selective silence in specific scenarios.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Selective mutism is an anxiety disorder characterized by a child's consistent failure to speak in specific situations, despite being able to speak in others.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 3719.

A-2 B-1 C-3
A-3 B-2 C-1
A-1 B-3 C-2

questions.text: Match the following dilution of adrenaline and its use? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A-2 B-1 C-3

 

Dilutions of adrenaline (epinephrine) with their typical uses:

 

  1. 1:1000 dilution of adrenaline is more concentrated and is commonly used in the treatment of Anaphylaxis. It is administered intramuscularly in emergency situations for its rapid vasoconstrictive and bronchodilating effects.
  2. 1:10000 dilution is less concentrated and is typically used in the management of Cardiac Arrest. It's administered intravenously.
  3. 1:100000 dilution is used as an additive in Local Anesthesia. The vasoconstrictive properties of adrenaline help to prolong the action of the local anesthetic and reduce bleeding in the surgical field.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the approximate age of a person in whom the medial end of the clavicle is fused and also the sternum is completely fused? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. >25 years

 

Approximate age for the given person with fused medial end of clavicle and completely fused sternum is most likely >25 years.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient comes to the hospital within 3 hours of the onset of chest pain. ECG revealed ST depression in anterior chest leads and T wave inversion. She could be best managed by? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aspirin with heparin

 

The description of diffuse symmetric TWI without ST elevations is consistent with NSTEMI which is characterized by subtotal platelet-rich thrombosis + distal phasic embolization. NSTEMI treated with DAPT+LMWH followed by CAG for risk stratification

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCI is treatment of choice for STEMI.

 

Option B. Arrhythmia prophylaxis is not the definitive best management strategy

 

Option C. Thrombolysis/Fibrinolytics have no role in the management of NSTEMI

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/ACS/Chap 277

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is attached to the area marked green in the image below? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Opponens pollicis

 

Explanation:

 

The palmar aspect of the first metacarpal is the area marked in the image. At this location, the opponens pollicis muscle inserts.

 

  • Opponens pollicis:
  • Origin: Crest of the trapezium and flexor retinaculum
  • Insertion: Whole length of the lateral border and adjoining lateral half of the palmar aspect of the first metacarpal.
  • Action: Flexes the metacarpal bone of the thumb.

 

The image below shows various intrinsic muscles of the hand.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abductor Pollicis Longus: Abductor pollicis longus is not directly attached to the first metacarpal. It originates from the posterior surface of the ulna and radius and inserts into the base of the first metacarpal bone. Its primary action is to abduct the thumb away from the palm.

 

Option B. Palmar Interossei: The palmar interossei muscles are located between the metacarpal bones in the palm of the hand. They are responsible for adducting the fingers toward the midline of the hand. They are not directly attached to the first metacarpal.

 

Option D. Flexor Pollicis Brevis: The flexor pollicis brevis muscle has two heads: the superficial head and the deep head. The superficial head originates from the flexor retinaculum, while the deep head originates from the trapezoid and capitate bones.

  • Both heads of the flexor pollicis brevis insert into the base of the first metacarpal bone.
  • The main action of the flexor pollicis brevis is to flex the thumb at the metacarpophalangeal joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The opponens pollicis muscle originates from the flexor retinaculum and the Crest of the trapezium bone. It inserts into the first metacarpal bone.
  • The primary action of the opponens pollicis is to oppose the thumb, allowing for the grasping and pinching movements of the thumb.

questions.text: Identify the brace given in the following image:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Milwaukee brace

 

  • The brace given in the image is Milwaukee brace that is used for scoliosis.

 

SCOLIOSIS

 

  • Scoliosis is characterized by lateral curvature of the spine associated with rotation of the involved vertebrae and classified by its anatomic location, in either the thoracic or lumbar spine, with rare involvement of the cervical spine.
  • There are four main categories of scoliosis: 
    1. Idiopathic: Idiopathic scoliosis accounts for around 80% of cases. It is more common in girls and typically develops around 10-12 years of age, but can occur earlier. There is a genetic component, but the etiology is multifactorial.
    2. Congenital: Congenital scoliosis accounts for 5-7% of cases and is a result of vertebral abnormalities due to a failure of formation or segmentation of the affected vertebrae.
    3. Neuromuscular (associated with a neurological or muscular disease)
    4. Syndromic (associated with a known syndrome)
       
  • Types of scoliosis:

 

 

  • Clinical Findings:
    • Scoliosis in adolescents does not typically cause significant pain. If a patient has significant pain, she/he should be evaluated to rule out the possibility of some other disorder such as infection or tumor.
    • Deformity of the rib cage and asymmetry of the waistline are clinically evident for curvatures of 30 degrees or more.
    • Lesser curves may be detected through a forward bending test (Adam’s test), which is designed to detect early abnormalities of rotation that may not be apparent when the patient is standing erect.
    • Rotation of the spine may be measured with a scoliometer. Rotation is associated with a marked rib hump as the lateral curvature increases in severity.
       
  • Imaging:
    • Radiographs taken of the entire spine in the standing position in both the posterior anterior (PA) and lateral planes are the most valuable for diagnosis.
    • Usually, a primary curve is evident with compensatory curvature to balance the body.
    • Skeletal maturity can be assessed by the Risser sign. A radiograph is employed to see how far the patient's iliac apophysis has progressed from the anterior superior iliac spine. During development, the iliac apophysis first appears laterally and grows medially. The stages are Risser I-V, where Risser V denotes that the apophysis has completely fused with the iliac crest and therefore, skeletal maturity can be assumed hence, further progression of curve of scoliosis will not take place.

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment of scoliosis depends on the curve magnitude, skeletal maturity, and risk of progression.
    • Specific management is dependent on the Cobb angle, measured on a standing PA X-ray of the spine.
    • Brace treatment is restricted to immature children in an attempt to prevent curve progression during further skeletal growth. So, it is indicated in Growing adolescents (Risser 0, 1 or 2) who, on presentation, have curves in range of 30-45 degrees or who have had documented progression exceeding 5 degrees in curve that initially measured 20-30 degrees.
    • TLSOs are the most commonly used orthoses today, but their use is restricted to patients whose curve apex is at or below T7.
    • Suspensory plaster cast of sayre, Rissers cast hinge or turnbuckle cast of Hibbs and Kisser, Milwaukee brace, Boston brace, Charleston night-time bending brace, Wilmington brace and thoraco-lumbo- sacral orthoses (TLSOs) are used to treat idiopathic scoliosis (Lower Dorsal scoliosis > Lumbar Scoliosis).
    • Surgical treatment consists of corrective osteotomies and fusion.
    • Spinal instrumentation (rods,  screws, hooks, etc.) are applied to the region of the spine to be corrected through transpedicular route and bone graft is added.
    • Spinal fusions are delayed as long as possible in young children through the use of casting, bracing, and growth modulating surgeries such as growing rods or vertical expandable prosthetic titanium ribs (VEPTR).

 

 

  • Milwaukee Brace: 
    • The Milwaukee brace is an active corrective spinal orthosis.
    • It consists of a neck ring with a throat mould and two occipital pads to avoid a high pressure in the neck.
    • Other elements are a plastic pelvic girdle, aluminium uprights, leather L-shaped thoracic pads and metal bars in the front and in the back.
    • It is used in the treatment of postural disorders like idiopathic scoliosis or Scheuerman disease.
    • The brace is normally prescribed for children, with a postural disorder, who have not reached their growth spurt or who are in their fast growing period.
    • It is not used for adults or adolescents already beyond their growth spurt, as it will have no effect.
    • If the spinal curve has a Cobb angle between 20° and 40°, it is an indication to use a brace.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The brace shown in the image in the question is of a Milwaukee brace, which is used to treat scoliosis in adolescent children.

questions.text: A researcher is comparing the means of three different groups with non-normally distributed data and small sample sizes. Which of the following tests is best suited for analyzing this non-parametric data? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Friedman test

 

  • Friedman test is a non-parametric statistical test used for detecting differences in treatments across multiple test attempts.
  • It is the equivalent of a one-way ANOVA with repeated measures but for non-parametric data.
  • Since the data in this scenario is not normally distributed, and the groups are related, the Friedman test is the appropriate choice.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Student t-test: Student t-test is used for comparing the means of two groups. However, it assumes that the data is normally distributed. 

 

Option C. ANOVA: ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) is used for comparing the means of three or more independent groups. 

 

Option D. Pearson: Pearson correlation is used for measuring the strength of a linear association between two quantitative variables. It is not a test for comparing means and also assumes a normal distribution of the data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Choose the Friedman test when you need to compare the means of three or more related groups, and the data is not normally distributed, ensuring accurate and reliable statistical analysis in non-parametric settings.

choices.text: Visible peristalsis from left to right

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which among the following will not be seen in this child? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bilious vomiting

 

In congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, the hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pylorus muscle lead to gastric outlet obstruction. This causes projectile, non-bilious vomiting because the obstruction is proximal to the bile duct entry into the duodenum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Visible peristalsis from left to right: Due to the obstruction caused by CHPS, there's an increase in gastric peristalsis as the stomach tries to push its contents past the hypertrophied pylorus. This can result in visible waves of peristalsis moving from the left side of the abdomen (where the stomach is located) to the right side (towards the pylorus) on giving a feed.

 

Option C. Hypochloremia and hypokalemia: Persistent vomiting in CHPS can lead to the loss of gastric acid (hydrochloric acid). This results in hypochloremia due to the loss of chloride ions. The body also tries to compensate for the alkalosis by excreting more potassium in the kidneys, leading to hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis: As mentioned earlier, the loss of gastric acid from repeated vomiting results in a state of metabolic alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CHPS (congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis) is most commonly seen in infants between 2 to 8 weeks of age.
  • It is caused by the hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the Pylorus, which results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet.
  • First-born male infants are at the highest risk for developing CHPS.
  • Projectile, non-bilious vomiting is a common symptom in infants with CHPS.
  • A palpable olive-shaped mass is usually felt in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium, and visible peristalsis can be observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting.
  • Infants with CHPS develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality including hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.
  • Loss of hydrochloric acid leads to metabolic alkalosis and hypochloremia due to persistent vomiting.
  • The kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3, but the loss of sodium stimulates aldosterone secretion leading to the loss of potassium ions (hypokalemia).
  • Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in paradoxical aciduria.
  • Treatment involves rehydration and correction of metabolic abnormalities before surgery, and the Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for CHPS.

questions.text:
What investigations would you recommend for a female patient who presents with a 4cm x 3cm irregular mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast and a palpated lymph node of 2cm in the right axilla, but no mass palpated in the opposite breast? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. Bilateral Mammography
  2. PET Scan
  3. Biopsy of the breast mass
  4. USG guided biopsy of the lymph node
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4

 

  • The clinical presentation indicates that the patient may have breast cancer with local spread but no distant metastasis. To further investigate this, it is recommended to conduct bilateral mammography, biopsy of the breast mass (Triple assessment), and USG-guided biopsy of the suspicious lymph node.
  • Diagnostic mammography is a useful tool for examining women with abnormal findings, including breast masses and nipple discharge, and it is more accurate than clinical examination in detecting early breast cancers.
  • Breast cancer can be identified through mammographic features such as a solid mass with or without stellate features, asymmetric thickening of breast tissue, or clustered microcalcifications.
  • To diagnose carcinoma, a core needle biopsy or fine-needle aspiration is usually performed before any treatment begins. In cases where suspicious lymph nodes are present, US-guided fine-needle aspiration or core biopsy is performed to determine the presence of metastatic disease.
  • PET scans are typically done after completion of triple assessment and confirmation of malignancy of breast.

questions.text: The image below shows simple muscle twitch along with the time trace, recorded in a frog gastrocnemius muscle. Calculate the minimum tetanizing frequency. (The time tracer was made with a 100hz tuning fork)?(INICET 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 20 per second

 

The tetanizing frequency of the muscle, based on the given diagram, is 20 per second.

 

Tetanizing frequency - 1/contraction period

 

Where the contraction period is the time taken from latent period to maximum force of contraction.

 

In the given diagram, the time tracer was taken using a 100Hz tuning fork. Which means, the tracer recorded 100 waves per second, below the twitch graph.

 

Therefore, the duration of each wave in time tracer = 0.01 seconds.

 

The formula used to calculate the tetanizing frequency is:

 

Tetanizing frequency = 1 / contraction period

 

Substituting the values obtained:

 

Tetanizing frequency = 1 / 0.05 sec = 20/sec

 

Therefore, the tetanizing frequency of the muscle is 20 per second.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The minimum tetanizing frequency of a muscle is determined by the reciprocal of the contraction period.

questions.text:
In which of the following situations will you use a sanitizer? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. Before examining the patient
  2. After examining the patient
  3. After touching the patient's surroundings
  4. Hands are visibly soiled
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A, B and C only

 

Healthcare personnel should perform hand hygiene with soap and water when hands are visibly soiled.

 

Healthcare personnel should use an alcohol-based hand rub for the following clinical indications:

 

  • Immediately before touching a patient
  • Before performing an aseptic task (e.g., placing an indwelling device) or handling invasive medical devices
  • Before moving from work on a soiled body site to a clean body site on the same patient
  • After touching a patient or the patient’s immediate environment
  • After contact with blood, body fluids, or contaminated surfaces
  • Immediately after glove removal

 

Other Option:

 

D. Hands are visibly soiled: In this case, hand washing with soap and water is recommended rather than using a sanitizer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Healthcare personnel should use hand sanitizer before and after examining a patient and after touching the patient's surroundings. However, when hands are visibly soiled, hand hygiene should be performed using soap and water instead of a sanitizer.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4

 

A-3. Balamuthia mandrillaris is a free-living amoeba uses pseudopodia for locomotion.

 

B-2. Balantidium coli, is a ciliated protozoan (and the largest protozoan that infects humans)

 

C-1. Trichomonas vaginalis is an anaerobic, flagellated protozoan parasite.

 

D-4.Toxoplasma gondii is a member of the phylum Apicomplexa, a diverse group of intracellular parasites that share a unique form of gliding motility. Gliding is substrate dependent and occurs without apparent changes in cell shape and in the absence of traditional locomotory organelles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Balamuthia mandrillaris: Uses pseudopodia for movement.
  • Balantidium coli: Uses cilia for locomotion.
  • Trichomonas vaginalis: Uses flagella for movement.
  • Toxoplasma gondii: Exhibits gliding motility, a substrate-dependent movement without the use of traditional locomotory organelles.

questions.text: The following groups of people must be screened for Ca cervix: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 25 to 65-year-old females

 

Explanation:

 

According to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) and the American Cancer Society (ACS) guidelines (2020), cervical cancer screening is recommended for women aged 25 to 65 years. The guidelines specify the following:

 

ACOG/ACS Guidelines (2020):

 

  • Begin screening at age 25.
  • Ages 25 to 65:
    • HPV testing every 5 years (preferred).
    • HPV/Pap co-testing every 5 years (acceptable).
    • Pap test alone every 3 years (acceptable).
  • Age >65: No testing required if a series of previous tests were normal.

 

WHO Guidelines (2020):

 

  • Begin screening at age 30.
  • Primary mode of screening: HPV testing.
  • Frequency: Every 5 to 10 years.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. More than 65 years old: Screening is generally not required for women over 65 if they have had a series of normal screening results.

 

Option B. Less than 25 years old: Screening is not recommended for women under 25 according to ACOG/ACS guidelines.

 

Option D. Teenagers: Screening is not recommended for teenagers as cervical cancer is extremely rare in this age group and the benefits of screening do not outweigh the potential harms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervical cancer screening is recommended for women aged 25 to 65 years, with various acceptable methods and intervals as specified by the ACOG and ACS guidelines.

 

Ref: ACOG guidelines for screening of cervical cancer, WHO guidelines for screening of cervical cancer, Williams Textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 634, 635.

choices.text: POP for 3 months

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with abnormal uterine bleeding for two months. What is the next line of management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endometrial sampling

 

Explanation:

 

The next line of management in a 50-year-old woman with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) is an endometrial biopsy. This is crucial to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy, especially in a peri-menopausal woman.

 

Indications for Endometrial Sampling:

 

  • Peri-menopausal women with AUB.
  • Hyperestrogenic states like obesity or tamoxifen treatment with thickened endometrium on transvaginal sonography (TVS).
  • Women with failed medical management and persistent bleeding.
  • Transvaginal ultrasound findings of endometrial thickness >12 mm in premenopausal women and >4 mm in postmenopausal women.

 

Methods of Endometrial Sampling:

 

  • Curettage
  • Aspiration biopsy using Pipelle or Vibra aspirator

 

Other options:

 

Option A. LNG-IUCD: The Levonorgestrel intrauterine device (LNG-IUCD) is a treatment option but should be considered after ruling out malignancy.

 

Option B. POP for 3 months: Progestin-only pills (POP) can be used to manage AUB, but endometrial sampling should be done first to rule out malignancy.

 

Option C. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is a definitive treatment but is considered after other management options and ruling out malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In peri-menopausal women presenting with abnormal uterine bleeding, the first step is to perform endometrial sampling to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy before considering other treatment modalities.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg184

questions.text:
Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is seen in: (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. HIV  
  2. SLE  
  3. CLL  
  4. Hepatitis B
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPG) is seen in HIV, SLE, CLL, and Hepatitis B.

 

MPGN is caused due to immune-mediated injury. It often presents with a nephritic-nephrotic picture.

 

The causes of MPGN are as follows:

 

  • Primary MPGN (Idiopathic)
  • Secondary MPGN
  • System lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Alpha 1-antitrypsin deficiency
  • Infections - hepatitis B, hepatitis C, HIV, schistosomiasis, endocarditis, infected ventriculoarterial shunts, chronic visceral abscesses
  • Malignancies - chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)

 

MPGN is characterized by the proliferation of cells predominantly in the mesangium and the capillary loops. Hence it is also called mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis.

 

There are 2 types of MPGN:

 

 

  • Duplication of the basement membrane gives a double contour or tram-track appearance. It is especially evident in silver or PAS stains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MPGN can be seen in various conditions, including HIV, SLE, CLL, and Hepatitis B, making it important to consider these diseases in the differential diagnosis of MPGN

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathological basis of disease 8th edition pg 1777

choices.text: TDM is done with penicillin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with both because of dangerous side effects
Both drugs do not need monitoring

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct for a patient on high dose of penicillin and gentamicin? iNICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index


Therapeutic Drug Monitoring has to be done for drugs that have a narrow safety margin. Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that acts by inhibiting the protein synthesis at the 30S ribosomal subunit of the bacteria. It is nephrotoxic as well as ototoxic. It has a narrow therapeutic margin; therefore, it requires TDM.

 

Option B. TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index: Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic, and these drugs are known for their narrow therapeutic index. TDM is important for gentamicin to ensure effective therapeutic levels are achieved without causing toxicity. Aminoglycosides can cause nephrotoxicity (kidney damage) and ototoxicity (hearing loss), so monitoring blood levels is crucial to avoid these adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. TDM is done with penicillin because of narrow therapeutic index: This is not typically the case. Penicillin, for the most part, does not have a narrow therapeutic index, and Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) is generally not required for penicillin.

 

Options C. TDM is done with both because of dangerous side effects: While it's true that both drugs can have side effects, TDM is generally only recommended for gentamicin because of its narrow therapeutic window and potential for serious side effects. Penicillin does not typically require TDM.

 

Options D. Both drugs do not need monitoring: This statement is incorrect because gentamicin does require monitoring due to its narrow therapeutic index and potential for toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) is crucial for gentamicin due to its narrow therapeutic index and potential for nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity. Penicillin, on the other hand, generally does not require TDM because it does not have a narrow therapeutic index.

choices.text: Chronic respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis
Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis
Acute Metabolic alkalosis, acute respiratory acidosis
Acute respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: Identify the areas marked F, C in the following diagram: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis

 

  • Area F: Positioned in the lower left part of the diagram, which corresponds to higher PCO2 and a pH less than 7.35. This area represents Acute Respiratory Acidosis due to an increase in CO2, causing a drop in blood pH.
  • Area C: Positioned in the upper right part of the diagram, which corresponds to lower PCO2 and a pH greater than 7.45. This area represents Acute Respiratory Alkalosis caused by a decrease in CO2, increasing blood pH.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the relationship between pH, bicarbonate (HCO3-), and CO2 is crucial for interpreting arterial blood gases. Area F indicates acute respiratory acidosis due to increased CO2, and area C indicates acute respiratory alkalosis due to decreased CO2.

questions.text:
A patient with cervical lymphadenopathy has (11;14) positive. Which of the following markers should be done to confirm the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. CD10;
  2. CD 200;
  3. SOX11;
  4. Cyclin D1
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3, 4

 

t (11;14) creating CyclinD1-IgH fusion gene is seen in mantle cell lymphoma has its origin from naive B cell.

 

Mantle cell lymphoma:

 

  • Uncommon lymphoid neoplasm that makes up about 8% of all NHL
  • Usually presents in the fifth to sixth decades of life
  • Male predominance
  • Tumor cells closely resemble the normal mantle zone B cells that surround germinal centers
  • More indolent, SOX11 variant that often presents with circulating disease with splenomegaly but without significant lymphadenopathy and with a low Ki67 (<10%).

 

Features:

 

  • Painless lymphadenopathy
  • Splenomegaly
  • Multifocal mucosal involvement of small bowel and colon - lymphomatoid polyposis

 

Histology:

 

 

 

Immunophenotyping:

 

  1. High levels of cyclin D1
  2. CD19, CD20
