  3. Moderately high levels of surface Ig (usually IgM and IgD with κ or γ light chain)
  4. CD5+ and CD23-, which helps to distinguish it from CLL/SLL.
  5. The IgH genes lack somatic hypermutation, supporting an origin from a naive B cell.

 

Other Options:

 

  • CD10 (1): CD10 is a marker commonly associated with follicular lymphoma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia, not mantle cell lymphoma.
  • CD200 (2): CD200 is expressed in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and other B-cell lymphomas but is not a primary marker for mantle cell lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with t(11;14) translocation, confirming the diagnosis of mantle cell lymphoma requires testing for Cyclin D1 and SOX11 expression.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1132-1133

questions.text:
Which of the following are vitamin-B12 dependent enzymes? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Methylmalonyl Co isomerase
  2. Homocysteine synthase
  3. Folate reductase
  4. Methionine synthase
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 4 only

 

Among the given enzymes, methyl malonyl Co isomerase and methionine synthase are vitamin B12 dependent enzymes.

 

Physiologic role of B12 –

 

  1. Methylmalonyl CoA Isomerase: D-Methyl malonyl CoA is formed in the body from propionyl CoA. It is then converted to L form by a racemase and then isomerized by methylmalonyl-CoA mutase (containing Ado-B12) to succinyl CoA, which enters into citric acid cycle. In B12 deficiency, methylmalonyl CoA accumulates and methyl malonic aciduria occurs.
  2. Homocysteine Methyl Transferase requires B12 activity to convert homocysteine to methionine.
  3. Methyl Folate Trap and Folate Deficiency - The production of methyl THFA is an irreversible step. Therefore, the only way for regeneration of free THFA is step No. 1 in Figure. When B12 is deficient, this reaction cannot take place. This is called the methyl folate trap. This leads to the associated folic acid scarcity in B12 deficiency.

 

 

Vitamin B12-dependent Enzymes:

 

1. Methylmalonyl CoA Isomerase (Methylmalonyl CoA mutase): This enzyme converts methylmalonyl CoA to succinyl CoA, a critical step in the catabolism of certain amino acids and fatty acids. The enzyme requires adenosylcobalamin (Ado-B12) as a cofactor.

 

4. Methionine Synthase: This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine using methylcobalamin (Me-B12) as a cofactor. This reaction is crucial for the regeneration of methionine and the production of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM), an essential methyl group donor in numerous methylation reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Homocysteine Synthase: There is no enzyme by this specific name, but homocysteine is converted to methionine by methionine synthase, which is vitamin B12-dependent.

 

3. Folate Reductase: This enzyme reduces dihydrofolate (DHF) to tetrahydrofolate (THF), an essential step in folate metabolism. However, it does not require vitamin B12 as a cofactor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enzymes methylmalonyl CoA isomerase and methionine synthase are dependent on vitamin B12. These enzymes play critical roles in metabolic pathways, including amino acid catabolism and methylation reactions.

questions.text:
Correct sequence after p wave: (INICET NOV 2020)

 

A- 'a' wave

B- 1st heart sound

C-Rapid filling of ventricles

D- 't' wave
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ABDC

 

Following the P wave, which represents atrial depolarization leading to atrial contraction:

 

A- 'a' wave occurs as a result of atrial contraction, pushing blood into the ventricles.

 

B- 1st heart sound is produced by the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves at the beginning of ventricular systole.

 

D- 't' wave represents the repolarization of the ventricles, indicating the beginning of ventricular relaxation.

 

C- Rapid filling of ventricles follows as the ventricles relax and the atrioventricular valves open, allowing blood to flow from the higher pressure atria to the relaxed ventricles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Electrical events precede mechanical events in cardiac homeostasis

 

P wave→ Atrial contraction (a wave).

 

QRS→ ventricular contraction (C wave)

 

T wave→ Ventricular relaxation (Early rapid filling (Y descent)

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/Clinical/ chap 239

questions.text: Which of the following disease has the highest mortality once clinically manifested? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rabies

 

Rabies is virtually 100% fatal once symptoms appear. It affects the central nervous system. It is a zoonotic disease, transmitted by a deep bite or scratch from an animal with rabies, which is, in 99% of the cases, a dog. It is preventable by a vaccine.

 

Nipah virus infection is fatal in 40 to 70 percent of cases.

 

Ebola case fatality rates have varied from 25% to 90% in past outbreaks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nipah: Nipah virus infection has a fatality rate of 40% to 70%. While severe, it is not as uniformly fatal as rabies once symptoms develop.

 

Option C. Ebola: Ebola virus disease has variable case fatality rates, ranging from 25% to 90% in different outbreaks. However, it is not as consistently fatal as rabies once symptoms manifest.

 

Option D. Zika: Zika virus infection is typically mild, and while it can cause severe complications such as microcephaly in newborns if contracted during pregnancy, it does not have a high mortality rate in symptomatic individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rabies has the highest mortality rate once clinical symptoms appear, making it virtually 100% fatal without immediate post-exposure prophylaxis.

questions.text: Match the surgery with related nerve injuries: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

 

 

The following are the associations between the type of surgery and the nerve most commonly at risk of injury:

 

A. Breast surgery - Long Thoracic Nerve: The Long Thoracic Nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which anchors the scapula to the chest wall. Injury to this nerve during breast surgery, especially radical mastectomies where axillary lymph nodes are removed, can lead to a condition called "winged scapula," where the medial border of the scapula protrudes outwards.

 

B. Thyroid surgery - External Laryngeal nerve: The External Laryngeal nerve is a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (itself a branch of the vagus nerve). It supplies the cricothyroid muscle, which plays a role in tensioning the vocal cords. Injury during thyroid surgery can lead to voice changes, particularly affecting the pitch.

 

C. Submandibular excision - Hypoglossal nerve: The Hypoglossal nerve is the twelfth cranial nerve and supplies the muscles of the tongue. Injury to this nerve during excision of the submandibular gland can lead to tongue deviation towards the side of the injury due to the unopposed action of the tongue muscles on the unaffected side.

 

D. Thymectomy - Vagus nerve: The Vagus nerve, or the tenth cranial nerve, has a wide range of functions including supplying parasympathetic fibers to many organs in the thorax and abdomen. Injury during thymectomy, a surgical procedure to can have multiple effects, including voice changes due to its role in innervating the larynx. However, it's worth noting that the phrenic nerve, which innervates the diaphragm, is also at risk during a thymectomy.

 

In summary, during surgical procedures, it's imperative to be aware of the nearby nerves and their courses to prevent unintended nerve injury, as this can lead to significant postoperative complications

choices.text: Weight for height less than -3 SD
Weight for age less than -3 SD

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criteria for severe acute malnutrition? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Weight for age less than -3 SD

 

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) is a serious health condition in children that requires urgent attention. The World Health Organization (WHO) defines SAM based on specific criteria, which are indicators of a child's nutritional status and risk of mortality.

 

Criteria for Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM):

 

  • Weight for height less than -3 SD (Standard Deviations)
  • Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC) < 11.5 mm
  • Bilateral Pedal Edema

 

However, Weight for age less than -3 SD is not a criterion for diagnosing severe acute malnutrition. While weight-for-age is a measure used to assess growth and general nutritional status, it does not specifically define SAM. Instead, weight-for-age is more indicative of general undernutrition or stunting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe acute malnutrition is defined by weight-for-height less than -3 SD, MUAC < 115 mm, or the presence of bilateral pedal edema, but not by weight-for-age less than -3 SD.

choices.text: Give continuous prophylaxis to the patient
Give prophylactic antivirals to the husband
Give antivirals whenever active lesions are present
Don't involve in intercourse when active lesions are present

questions.text: A female patient presents with active genital warts with a history of recurrence, but her husband doesn't have it. What advice will you give to prevent transmission? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Don't involve in intercourse when active lesions are present

 

  • This is the correct answer. Avoiding sexual contact when active lesions are present is one of the most effective ways to prevent the transmission of HPV.
  • Genital warts are primarily caused by specific types of human papillomavirus (HPV-6 and HPV-11).
  • These warts, also known as venereal warts or condyloma acuminata, are highly infectious and are commonly acquired through sexual contact.
  • However, they can also be transmitted through non-sexual means.
  • Genital warts are highly contagious when lesions are active, so abstaining from sexual activity during these times is crucial to prevent spread to partners.

 

 

Management of Genital warts:

 

  • Imiquimod and podophyllotoxin are the primary drugs recommended as first-line treatments for genital warts. Imiquimod stimulates toll-like receptors 7 and 8, inducing apoptosis in macrophages, monocytes, and dendritic cells.
  • Imiquimod cream is approved for the treatment of actinic keratoses, superficial basal cell carcinoma, and genital warts through topical immunomodulation
  • The most effective method to prevent the transmission of infection is to abstain from sexual intercourse when active lesions are present.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give continuous prophylaxis to the patient.

 

  • This is not the correct approach because continuous prophylaxis with antivirals is not typically recommended for genital warts, which are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV).
  • Antivirals are more commonly used for other viral infections like herpes simplex virus.
  • Moreover, prophylaxis doesn't prevent the transmission of HPV during periods without active lesions.

 

Option B. Give prophylactic antivirals to the husband.

 

  • This option is incorrect for similar reasons as option A. HPV, the virus causing genital warts, does not have a prophylactic antiviral treatment.
  • Furthermore, since the husband does not have active lesions or a history of genital warts, prophylactic treatment is not indicated.

 

Option C. Give antivirals whenever active lesions are present.

 

  • While this might seem like a reasonable approach, it is important to note that antivirals are not effective against HPV.
  • Treatment for active genital warts typically involves topical agents or procedures like cryotherapy, not systemic antiviral medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To prevent the transmission of genital warts caused by HPV, it is advisable to avoid sexual intercourse when active lesions are present, as there are no effective antiviral prophylaxis options for HPV, and HPV transmission risk is highest during periods with active lesions.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 25 Page no 25.43

Illustrated synopsis of dermatology & sexually transmitted diseases page no 318

Robbins & Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 10 E page no 998

questions.text: A hypertensive pregnant woman with abdominal pain, bleeding per vaginum, and loss of fetal movements. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abruptio placenta

 

Explanation:

 

Abruptio placentae, also known as placental abruption, commonly occurs in hypertensive disorders of pregnancy. It is characterized by the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus, leading to painful vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and often fetal distress or fetal death. The uterus may be tonically contracted in such cases.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Hypertensive Disorders: Abruptio placentae is frequently associated with hypertensive disorders of pregnancy.
  • Clinical Presentation: Painful vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and loss of fetal movements are hallmark signs.
  • Uterine Contraction: The uterus may feel firm and tender, indicating a tonic contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Placenta previa: Placenta previa involves painless vaginal bleeding due to the placenta covering the cervix. It generally does not cause decreased fetal movements unless there is severe bleeding leading to maternal and fetal compromise.

 

Option C. Hydramnios: Hydramnios (polyhydramnios) involves excessive amniotic fluid and does not typically present with bleeding.

 

Option D. Preterm labor: Preterm labor typically does not present with bleeding and is characterized by regular uterine contractions leading to cervical changes before 37 weeks of gestation. Prematurity in preterm labor is iatrogenic if induced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abruptio placenta should be suspected in a hypertensive pregnant woman presenting with painful vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and loss of fetal movements, as it is commonly associated with hypertensive disorders and presents with these clinical features.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 1944

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient undergoes a pacemaker replacement procedure at a tertiary care hospital. The surgeon successfully replaces the pacemaker and hands over the used device to the nursing staff for proper disposal as per biomedical waste management guidelines. According to the guidelines for biomedical waste management, in which colored bag should the used pacemaker be discarded? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Blue

 

  • According to biomedical waste management guidelines, used pacemakers, which are considered metal waste, should be disposed of in blue-colored containers or cardboard boxes marked with blue.
  • This ensures that the device is appropriately handled, disinfected, and sent for recycling or other safe disposal methods.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Affinity maturation is due to: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Somatic hypermutation

 

Affinity maturation is a process that occurs in B cells during an immune response, leading to the production of antibodies with increased affinity for their antigen. This process is primarily driven by somatic hypermutation (SHM).

 

Mechanism:

 

  • Somatic Hypermutation (SHM): This involves the introduction of point mutations at a high rate in the variable regions of the immunoglobulin (Ig) genes in activated B cells. These mutations occur in the DNA encoding the variable regions of both heavy and light chains of the antibody molecule.
  • Selection for High Affinity: B cells that produce antibodies with higher affinity for the antigen are selectively expanded. Those with mutations that increase the affinity of the antibody for its antigen are positively selected and proliferate, whereas B cells with lower affinity or non-functional antibodies are eliminated.
  • Result: This process leads to the production of high-affinity antibodies over time, enhancing the effectiveness of the immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isotype Switching: Also known as class switch recombination, this process changes the antibody isotype (e.g., from IgM to IgG) but does not directly affect the antigen-binding affinity.

 

Option C. mRNA Splicing: This process involves the removal of introns from pre-mRNA to produce mature mRNA, but it is not involved in affinity maturation.

 

Option D. VDJ Rearrangement: This process generates the initial diversity of the antigen receptor repertoire by recombining variable (V), diversity (D), and joining (J) gene segments. It occurs before exposure to antigen and does not contribute to the increased affinity seen in affinity maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Affinity maturation, which results in the production of high-affinity antibodies, is primarily due to somatic hypermutation (SHM) of immunoglobulin genes in B cells, coupled with selective survival and proliferation of B cells producing high-affinity antibodies.

choices.text: All live vaccines under NIS can be given as per schedule
All killed vaccines under NIS can be given
Only pneumococcal vaccine should be given to the child in acute phase
Live vaccines are contraindicated in the child's sibling

questions.text: A child suffering from steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome is brought to the OD for vaccination. Which of the following is true about vaccination in this child? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) All killed vaccines under NIS can be given

 

In children with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome, the approach to vaccination must be carefully considered, particularly due to their immunocompromised state from corticosteroid therapy.

 

  • Killed (inactivated) vaccines are safe and can be administered to these children as they do not pose a risk of causing disease. This includes vaccines such as the inactivated polio vaccine (IPV), diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine, and others under the National Immunization Schedule (NIS).
  • Live vaccines should be administered with caution. For children on corticosteroid therapy, live vaccines (e.g., MMR, varicella) are generally avoided unless the child is on low-dose corticosteroids (less than 1 mg/kg/day of prednisone or equivalent). Live virus vaccines are contraindicated in children receiving high doses of steroids or other immunosuppressive therapies like cyclophosphamide or cyclosporine.
  • Vaccination of household contacts: It's crucial to vaccinate healthy household contacts with live vaccines to protect the immunosuppressed child indirectly. However, precautions should be taken to avoid contact with the secretions of recently vaccinated individuals, particularly in the case of live oral vaccines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All live vaccines under NIS can be given as per schedule: This is not accurate as live vaccines should be given with caution or avoided in immunocompromised children, particularly those on high-dose steroids.

 

Option C. Only pneumococcal vaccine should be given to the child in the acute phase: While the pneumococcal vaccine is important, it is not the only vaccine that should be considered. Killed vaccines are generally safe and should be administered according to the vaccination schedule.

 

Option D. Live vaccines are contraindicated in the child's sibling: This is incorrect. Siblings and household contacts should receive live vaccines to reduce the risk of transmitting infections to the immunocompromised child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In children with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome, all killed vaccines under the National Immunization Schedule can be safely administered, while live vaccines should be given with caution depending on the child's immunosuppressive therapy.

questions.text: DNA Methylation is not involved in?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Base pair excision

 

Base pair excision repair (BER) is a mechanism that corrects DNA damage involving small, non-helix-distorting base lesions. This process is initiated by DNA glycosylases that recognize and remove damaged bases, followed by endonuclease activity, DNA synthesis, and ligation. DNA methylation does not play a direct role in this repair pathway.

 

DNA methylation is usually associated with triggering histone deacetylation, chromatin condensation, and gene silencing. Differentially methylated cytosines give rise to distinct patterns specific for each tissue type and disease state. Such methylation-variable positions (MVPs) are not uniformly distributed throughout our genome, but are concentrated among genes that regulate transcription, growth, metabolism, differentiation, and oncogenesis. Alterations in MVP methylation status create epigenetic patterns that appear to regulate gene expression profiles during cell differentiation, growth, and development, as well as in cancer.

 

Environmental stressors including toxins, as well as microbial and viral exposures, can change epigenetic patterns and thereby effect changes in gene activation and cell phenotype.

It is involved in mismatch repair but not in the base pair excision repair mechanism.

 

Other Options:

 

Roles of DNA Methylation:

 

Option A. Chromatin Remodeling: DNA methylation is involved in chromatin remodeling by recruiting proteins such as methyl-CpG-binding domain proteins (MBDs) that interact with histone deacetylases (HDACs), leading to chromatin condensation and gene silencing.

 

Option B. Mismatch Repair: DNA methylation marks newly synthesized DNA strands during replication, aiding in the identification and repair of mismatches.

 

Option C. Gene Silencing: DNA methylation typically leads to gene silencing by preventing the binding of transcription factors and promoting the formation of a condensed chromatin structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA methylation is not involved in the base pair excision repair mechanism. Instead, it plays significant roles in chromatin remodeling, mismatch repair, and gene silencing by modifying the DNA structure and influencing protein interactions and gene expression.

questions.text: A nurse removes her latex gloves contaminated with blood and bodily fluids after a procedure. According to biomedical waste management guidelines, into which colored bag should she place the used gloves for disposal? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Red

 

  • Latex gloves contaminated with blood and other bodily fluids are considered contaminated waste (recyclable) and should be disposed of in red-colored bags or containers.
  • This category includes items like tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles), and gloves.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to be pink, with blue extremities, and irregular respiration. Heart rate is 80 beats per minute. There is grimace and some flexion. What is the Apgar score for this baby? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5

 

The Apgar score for this baby will be 5.

 

 

  • Color: body pink, extremities blue: score-1
  • Heart rate: 80 beats per minute: score 1
  • Grimace: Score-1
  • Some flexion: Score-1
  • Irregular respiration: Score-1

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Apgar score is used to quickly assess the overall health of a newborn, with a score of 5 indicating the need for some medical intervention but not immediate resuscitation.

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed tumor in the retroperitoneal space? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Liposarcoma

 

Liposarcoma is the most commonly observed tumor in the retroperitoneal space. Liposarcomas are malignant tumors that arise from adipocytes and are most frequently located in the retroperitoneum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rhabdomyosarcoma: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant tumor of muscle origin. While it can occur in various parts of the body, it is more commonly associated with pediatric populations in the neck.

 

Option C. Synovial sarcoma: Synovial sarcoma is a rare type of cancer that tends to arise near large joints but can occur anywhere in the body.

 

Option D. Neurofibroma: Neurofibromas are benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors. While they can occur in various parts of the body, including the retroperitoneum, they are not the most frequently observed tumor in this location. It's also important to note that when associated with certain genetic conditions like Neurofibromatosis type 1, they can be seen in multiple areas of the body, but they still don't surpass liposarcomas in frequency in the retroperitoneal space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Retroperitoneal tumors can be benign or malignant and may be of various origins.
  • Mesodermal tumors are the most common malignant retroperitoneal tumors.
  • The order of frequency for primary retroperitoneal malignancy is liposarcoma, leiomyosarcoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, and malignant nerve sheath tumors.
  • Liposarcoma has three histologic varieties, which are well-differentiated and undifferentiated liposarcoma, pleomorphic liposarcoma, and myxoid/round cell liposarcoma.
  • Among the three subtypes, pleomorphic liposarcoma is the most malignant and often metastasizes, while well-differentiated liposarcoma is the least malignant.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true regarding KF ring? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

1. Seen in all patients with neurological involvement

2. Is pathognomonic for Wilson's disease

3. Resolves with desferrioxamine

4. Seen in all patients with hepatic involvement

5. Seen in superior and inferior pole of Descemet's membrane
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 5 only.

 

Statement 1: The Kayser-Fleischer ring is frequently seen in patients with neurological involvement due to Wilson’s disease, but it may not be present in all cases.

 

Statement 5: The Kayser-Fleischer ring is a copper deposit seen at the superior and inferior poles of the corneal Descemet's membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: While the KF ring is highly suggestive of Wilson's disease, it is not solely pathognomonic because it can appear in other chronic cholestatic liver conditions.

 

Statement 3: Desferrioxamine is used for iron chelation and is not effective for copper removal in Wilson's disease. Treatment for copper overload involves agents like penicillamine or trientine.

 

Statement 4: Not all patients with hepatic involvement due to Wilson's disease will have visible KF rings, as their presence correlates more strongly with the duration and severity of copper accumulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

KF can be seen in disorders causing chronic cholestasis. Seen in ~99% of patients with neuro wilson's, 44-60% with hepatic involvement.

 

Desferioxamine is chelating agent in iron toxicity. 

 

Reference - Harrison/Liver/Wilsons/Chap 344

questions.text: The given life cycle belongs to which of the following organisms? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leptospira

 

The life cycle shown in the images is indicative of leptospirosis, a zoonotic disease caused by bacteria of the genus Leptospira. The diagram highlights the transmission cycle involving various animal reservoirs and the environment, which is characteristic of leptospirosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hanta virus: Transmitted through aerosolized rodent excreta but does not fit the detailed transmission cycle depicted in the image.

 

Option C. Yersinia pestis: Causes plague, transmitted primarily through fleas, and does not follow the environmental cycle shown in the image.

 

Option D. Salmonella typhi: Causes typhoid fever, transmitted through ingestion of contaminated food and water, and does not have a life cycle involving animal reservoirs as depicted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The life cycle of Leptospira involves transmission from animal reservoirs through contaminated water and soil, leading to human infection, which fits the depiction in the provided images.

questions.text: In skeletal muscle, dihydropyridine and ryanodine receptors are coupled by?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mechanically

 

  • In skeletal muscle, dihydropyridine and ryanodine receptors show mechanical coupling involving structural interaction between the two.
  • Excitation-contraction coupling in both skeletal and cardiac muscle depends on structural and functional interactions between the voltage-sensing dihydropyridine receptor L-type Ca (2+) channels in the surface/transverse tubular membrane and ryanodine receptor Ca (2+) release channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum membrane.
  • The channels are targeted to either side of a narrow junctional gap that separates the external and internal membrane systems and are arranged so that bi-directional structural and functional coupling can occur between the proteins. There is strong evidence for a physical interaction between the two types of channel protein in skeletal muscle.
  • It is thought to occur by a "mechanical coupling" mechanism involving protein-protein interactions that lead to activation of the sarcoplasmic reticulum ryanodine receptor by the voltage-sensing transverse (1-) tubule dihydropyridine receptor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chemically: This would imply that the interaction is mediated by a chemical messenger, which is not the case for DHPR and RyR coupling in skeletal muscle.

 

Option B. Electrically: Electrical coupling would imply that the interaction is mediated by an electric signal directly, which is not the mechanism in skeletal muscle.

 

Option C. Chemically and then electrically: This combination is incorrect as the coupling is purely mechanical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In skeletal muscle, the dihydropyridine and ryanodine receptors are coupled mechanically, meaning their interaction and functional coupling rely on direct physical contacts between these protein structures to initiate muscle contraction.

choices.text: Acuity of onset and loss of consciousness

questions.text: Which of the following features differentiate delirium from dementia in Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acuity of onset and loss of consciousness

 

Delirium is characterized by an acute and fluctuating onset with disturbances in consciousness and attention. Dementia, such as Alzheimer's disease, has a gradual, insidious onset and is primarily a disorder of memory without loss of consciousness.

 

Delirium and dementia, though distinct syndromes, can sometimes overlap in presentation, making differentiation challenging. However, some key features can help differentiate the two:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acuity of onset and agitation: While the acuity of onset can differentiate the two, both delirium and dementia can be associated with agitation.

 

Option C. Visual hallucinations and impaired memory: Visual hallucinations are more common in delirium and some types of dementia like Lewy Body Dementia but not necessarily Alzheimer's disease. Impaired memory is a feature of dementia, primarily Alzheimer's, but can also be present in delirium.

 

Option D. Agitation and irritation: Both can be seen in either delirium or dementia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 22.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a true statement regarding telomerase? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Involved in DNA repair

 

Telomerase is not primarily involved in DNA repair. While telomere maintenance can influence genome stability and prevent end-to-end chromosome fusions, telomerase itself does not play a direct role in the classical DNA repair pathways such as base excision repair, nucleotide excision repair, mismatch repair, or double-strand break repair.

 

Telomerase is a specialized enzyme that adds repetitive nucleotide sequences to the ends of chromosomes (telomeres) in eukaryotic cells. Its primary function is to maintain the length and stability of chromosomes by compensating for the loss of DNA that occurs during cell division.

 

Additional Information:

 

  • Telomeres are repetitive non-coding DNA sequences at the ends of chromosomes that protect them from degradation and prevent chromosomal fusion.
  • Telomerase activity declines with age, leading to the progressive shortening of telomeres and eventual cell senescence or apoptosis.
  • In many cancer cells, telomerase activity is upregulated, allowing these cells to bypass senescence and continue dividing indefinitely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Has reverse transcriptase activity: Telomerase contains an RNA component that serves as a template for adding telomeric repeats to the chromosome ends. The enzyme uses this RNA template to synthesize DNA, acting as a reverse transcriptase.

 

Option B. Present only in Eukaryotes: Telomerase is found only in eukaryotic cells because prokaryotic chromosomes are typically circular and do not have telomeres that require maintenance.

 

Option C. Maintains the chromosome length: Telomerase extends the telomeres, preventing their shortening during DNA replication and thus maintaining chromosome length and stability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Telomerase is an enzyme with reverse transcriptase activity, present only in eukaryotes, and is crucial for maintaining chromosome length by adding telomeric repeats. It is not directly involved in DNA repair.

questions.text: Identify the image shown below. (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Gunshot wound

 

The given image is of a gunshot wound.

 

Features of gunshot wound:

 

  • Central round hole with surrounding soot soiling.

  • Burnt hairs (singeing).

  • Punctate skin lesions from powder particles (tattooing).

  • Bevelling of edges (Exit Wounds)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tattooing: While tattooing refers to punctate skin lesions caused by powder particles in gunshot wounds, it alone does not describe the entirety of the image shown.

 

Option C. Arsenic poisoning: Arsenic poisoning typically causes symptoms like skin changes, but not the characteristic central hole and surrounding soot seen in gunshot wounds.

 

Option D. Graze wound: A graze wound is typically a superficial wound caused by the bullet skimming the surface of the skin, which looks different from the wound shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A gunshot wound can be identified by its central round hole, surrounding soot, singeing of hairs, tattooing from powder particles, and bevelling of the wound edges.

choices.text: Anti CTLA 4 Ab is a new modality in the treatment of advanced cancers
Mutation of tumor suppressor genes decreases antigen toxicity
PD1/ PDL1 activation leading to tumor suppression
Binding of CD28 leads to immune tolerance

questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding immune surveillance? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti CTLA 4 Ab is a new modality in the treatment of advanced cancers

 

CTLA4 is a negative regulator of T-cell responses. recognition of tumor cells may lead to engagement of the T-cell inhibitory receptor, CTLA4, or activation of regulatory T cells that suppress immune responses. Antibodies that block the interaction of CTLA-4 with its ligands B7. 1 and B7. 2 can enhance immune responses, including anti-tumor immunity.

 

Ipilimumab, a fully humanized IgG1 monoclonal Anti CTLA-4 antibody, has shown a significant improvement in survival of advanced-stage melanoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mutation of tumor suppressor genes decreases antigen toxicity: This statement is incorrect because mutations in tumor suppressor genes (e.g., TP53) lead to the loss of cell cycle control and contribute to tumorigenesis, not decreased antigen toxicity.

 

Option C. PD1/PDL1 activation leading to tumor suppression: The PD-1/PD-L1 pathway is another immune checkpoint that, when activated, suppresses the immune response. In cancer, tumors often upregulate PD-L1 to evade immune destruction, so this pathway is involved in immune evasion, not suppression of tumors.

 

Option D. Binding of CD28 leads to immune tolerance: CD28 is a co-stimulatory molecule that, when bound to B7 on APCs, promotes T-cell activation rather than tolerance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-CTLA-4 antibodies like Ipilimumab are a new modality in the treatment of advanced cancers, enhancing the anti-tumor immune response by blocking inhibitory signals to T cells.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 574

choices.text: A, B and C
B and C only
B and D

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs are used for absence seizures? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

A. Carbamazepine

B. Valproate

C. Ethosuximide

D. Gabapentin
questions.solution:
Ans. B. B and C only

 

The first line drugs for treatment of absence seizures are valproate and ethosuximide. Carbamazepine and phenytoin are contra-indicated in absence seizures.

 

Drugs Used in Absence Seizures

 

  • Ethosuximide: This drug is specific for absence seizures. It works by blocking T-type calcium channels in the thalamus, which are believed to play a role in the generation of absence seizures.
  • Valproic Acid (Valproate): Valproate is effective in treating a wide range of seizure types, including absence seizures. It works by increasing GABA levels and blocking sodium and calcium channels. Valproate is also used for bipolar disorder and migraine prophylaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Carbamazepine: Carbamazepine is not used for absence seizures. In fact, it can exacerbate absence seizures. It is typically used for partial seizures and generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

 

Options D. Gabapentin: Gabapentin is not effective for absence seizures. It is mainly used for neuropathic pain and as an adjunctive treatment for partial seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DRUGS USED IN ABSENCE SEIZURES

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs exacerbates myasthenia and is usually avoided in a patient with myasthenia gravis? (INICET Nov 2020)

1. Lidocaine

2. Aspirin

3. Meropenem

4. Phenytoin
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1 and 4
 

1. Lidocaine can exacerbate myasthenia gravis and should be used with caution in patients with this disease. Lidocaine can cause neuromuscular blockade, which can worsen the muscle weakness and fatigue associated with myasthenia gravis.

 

4. Phenytoin is an antiepileptic drug that can cause neuromuscular blockade, which can exacerbate the muscle weakness and fatigue associated with myasthenia gravis. Therefore, it is generally avoided in patients with this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Aspirin

 

  • Mechanism: Aspirin is an anti-inflammatory and antiplatelet drug. It does not have neuromuscular blocking properties and does not exacerbate myasthenia gravis.
  • Use in Myasthenia Gravis: Aspirin is generally safe for use in myasthenia gravis patients.

 

3. Meropenem

 

  • Mechanism: Meropenem is a broad-spectrum antibiotic. While some antibiotics can interfere with neuromuscular transmission, meropenem is not typically associated with exacerbating myasthenia gravis.
  • Use in Myasthenia Gravis: Meropenem is usually considered safe for use in myasthenia gravis patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DRUGS THAT SHOULD BE AVOIDED IN MYSTHENIA GRAVIS

questions.text: A public health officer is reviewing the storage conditions of various vaccines in a rural health center. She wants to ensure that all the vaccines have been stored appropriately and have not been exposed to temperatures outside the recommended range. She is looking for a specific indicator on the vaccine vials that shows the cumulative heat exposure over time. Which of the following is the correct indicator she should check? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) VVM

 

  • Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators routinely used to monitor heat exposure of the vaccine and determine vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain.
  • VVMs change color as the vaccine is exposed to cumulative heat. If the color of inner square is similar or darker than the outer circle, the vaccine vial should be discarded.
  • A VVM can be used to assess vaccine potency and not vaccine efficacy.
  • Expiry date can’t be determined by VVM and has no relation to extend the expiry date.
  • If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine should be discarded.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) as the correct tool used to indicate the cumulative heat exposure of vaccines over time, ensuring their potency and safe use.

questions.text: Reticular fibres are not present in which of the following structures? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Thymus

 

Explanation:

 

Reticular fibres are not present in the thymus. The thymus is a primary lymphoid organ involved in the development and maturation of T lymphocytes (T cells) and does not contain a significant amount of reticular fibers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lymph Node: Lymph nodes contain reticular fibers within their structure. Reticular fibers in lymph nodes create a network that supports immune cells, such as lymphocytes and macrophages, as they filter and process lymphatic fluid.

 

Option C. Bone Marrow: Reticular fibers are found in the bone marrow. They contribute to the framework of the bone marrow, supporting blood-forming cells and various hematopoietic elements involved in blood cell production.

 

Option D. Spleen: Reticular fibers are present in the spleen. Similar to lymph nodes, the spleen contains reticular fibers that support immune cells and help filter blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reticular fibres:

 

A form of connective tissue fibre known as reticular fibres, reticular fibres, or reticulin is made of type III collagen released by reticular cells. Crosslinking reticular fibres create a delicate meshwork (reticulin). Soft tissues like the liver, bone marrow, and the tissues and organs of the lymphatic system benefit from the support provided by this network.

 

They differ from type I collagen fibres in that, they are finer and are arranged in the form of a network (reticulum). The fibres appear black in colour on staining with silver impregnation. Due to this affinity to silver salts, they are also known as argentophil fibres.

choices.text: Bladder training, with reward for delaying micturition during daytime
Bell and pad based classical conditioning

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented with complaints of bed-wetting almost twice a week for the past 1 year. A detailed investigation was done to rule out the organic cause. What should be the treatment plan for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bell and pad based classical conditioning

 

This is a first-line behavioral treatment for primary nocturnal enuresis. It involves an alarm that sounds when wetness is detected, conditioning the child to awaken and use the toilet.

 

Other Options:

 

The child described seems to have primary nocturnal enuresis, which is common in children and often has no organic cause:

 

Option A. Pharmacotherapy with imipramine: This is an option, but it's usually reserved for cases that don't respond to first-line treatments because of potential side effects.

 

Option B. Psychodynamic psychotherapy: Not typically used as a first-line treatment for nocturnal enuresis.

 

Option C. Bladder training: This focuses on delaying micturition during daytime, which is beneficial but not considered as the treatment of choice

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sleep related enuresis is defined as voiding of urine at inappropriate places. It is nocturnal in around 80% of cases. The most common cause of bed wetting are psychosocial such as sibling rivalry. The treatment of choice is bed alarms. Drug of choice is desmopressin. Another medication which can be used is imipramine.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 169.

choices.text: Septal branch of superior labial artery

questions.text: Which of these options is not a division originating from the external carotid artery within Kiesselbach's plexus? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries

 

Anterior and posterior ethmoidal artery are branches of ophthalmic artery which in turn is a branch of internal carotid artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphenopalatine artery: This artery is correctly identified as a branch of the maxillary artery, which itself is a major branch of the external carotid artery. It contributes to Kiesselbach's plexus by providing the septal branch of the sphenopalatine artery.

 

Option C. Greater palatine artery: Also a branch of the maxillary artery, the septal branch of the greater palatine artery participates in forming Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

Option D. Septal branch of superior labial artery: This artery, a branch of the facial artery (which originates from the external carotid artery), is part of the blood supply to Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ARTERIAL SUPPLY OF THE NOSE:

 

Internal carotid system -

 

  • Branches of ophthalmic artery
  • Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Posterior ethmoidal artery

 

External Carotid System –

 

  • Sphenopalatine artery (branch of maxillary artery) gives nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.
  • Septal branch of greater palatine artery (branch of maxillary artery).
  • Septal branch of superior labial artery (branch of facial artery).

 

KIESSELBACH'S PLEXUS -

 

Four arteries anastomose at the anterior inferior part of nasal septum to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

  • Anterior ethmoidal
  • Septal branch of superior labial
  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine
  • Septal branch of greater palatine

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 198

questions.text: High anion gap acidosis with low bicarbonate levels is seen in all the following conditions except: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Renal Disorders

 

High anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) is characterized by the accumulation of acids in the body, which are not accompanied by an increase in other measured anions, thus increasing the anion gap. This condition typically involves a decrease in bicarbonate as the body tries to buffer the excess hydrogen ions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lactic Acidosis: This condition occurs when lactate levels increase in the bloodstream during tissue hypoxia, commonly seen in shock or severe dehydration, and results in HAGMA.

 

Option C. Diabetic Ketoacidosis: In DKA, the body produces high levels of blood acids called ketones, which lead to HAGMA.

 

Option D. Salicylate Poisoning: In salicylate toxicity, especially at higher doses, metabolic acidosis occurs due to uncoupling of oxidative phosphorylation, leading to HAGMA. Initially, salicylate stimulates the respiratory center causing a respiratory alkalosis, which can be followed by metabolic acidosis at higher doses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal disorders typically cause non-anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA) due to an inability to excrete acid or conserve bicarbonate, rather than high anion gap acidosis seen in conditions like lactic acidosis, diabetic ketoacidosis, and salicylate poisoning.

questions.text: A known asthmatic patient with fever and sore throat was prescribed an antibiotic. Two days later he presents with a maculopapular rash. Which of the following drugs might have caused this? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Amoxicillin

 

Out of the options given above, amoxicillin is the only drug which is an antibiotic. It is an amino penicillin. Allergic reactions in the form of skin rashes to Penicillin group of antibiotics are very common, out of which it is the highest with aminopenicillins.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Prednisolone: This is a corticosteroid used in the treatment of asthma to reduce inflammation. Corticosteroids like prednisolone are not typically associated with causing maculopapular rashes. In fact, they are often used to treat allergic reactions and rashes.

 

Options B. Salbutamol: Also known as albuterol, this is a bronchodilator used to relieve bronchospasm in conditions like asthma. Salbutamol is not commonly associated with skin rashes like a maculopapular rash.

 

Options C. Fexofenadine: This is an antihistamine used for allergic reactions. It is unlikely to cause a maculopapular rash and is more commonly used to treat such rashes when they are due to allergic reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amoxicillin, an aminopenicillin antibiotic, is commonly associated with allergic reactions, including maculopapular rashes. This is a well-known side effect of penicillin antibiotics. Prednisolone, salbutamol, and fexofenadine are less likely to cause such reactions, and in the case of prednisolone and fexofenadine, they are actually used to treat allergic reactions and rashes.

questions.text: Raise in ESR during pregnancy is due to? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fibrinogen

 

Explanation:

 

Pregnancy is characterized as a hypercoagulable state, and several changes occur in the coagulation system during pregnancy. One of the significant changes is the increase in fibrinogen levels, which leads to a rise in the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR).

 

Key Points:

 

  • Fibrinogen Levels: During pregnancy, fibrinogen levels increase by approximately 50%, from 200-400 mg/dL to 300-600 mg/dL. This rise in fibrinogen contributes significantly to the increased ESR.
  • ESR: The ESR can increase up to four times during pregnancy due to the increased levels of fibrinogen and globulin.
  • Platelet Count: There may be a slight fall in platelet count during pregnancy, commonly due to gestational thrombocytopenia, which is caused by hemodilution and increased platelet consumption. This condition usually has no adverse effect on pregnancy and is often observed in the third trimester.
  • Coagulation Factors: There is an increase in the plasma levels of several coagulation factors, including factors 1 (fibrinogen), 2, 7, 8, 9, and 10. Factors 2, 5, and 12 remain unchanged or mildly increased, while factors 11 and 13 are slightly decreased.
  • Clotting Time: Clotting time is generally unaffected by pregnancy.
  • Anti-Thrombin III: Levels of anti-thrombin III decrease during pregnancy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Albumin: Albumin levels typically decrease during pregnancy due to hemodilution, and they do not contribute to the rise in ESR.

 

Option B. Platelet: Platelet count may slightly decrease due to gestational thrombocytopenia, but this does not contribute to the rise in ESR.

 

Option D. Anti-thrombin antibody: This is not a relevant factor in the context of ESR increase during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The rise in erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) during pregnancy is primarily due to the increased levels of fibrinogen.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Pg59

choices.text: Km of an enzyme = 10 micromole and Kcat = 20 per sec
Km of an enzyme = 2000 nanomole and Kcat = 50 per sec
Km of an enzyme = 2 micromole and Kcat = 200 per sec
Km of an enzyme = 4 micromole and Kcat = 200 per sec

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes has the highest catalytic efficiency? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Km of an enzyme = 2 micromole and Kcat = 200 per sec

 

Catalytic efficiency is calculated as Kcat/Km. Higher values of Kcat and lower values of Km gives better catalytic efficiency.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Catalytic efficiency, calculated as 𝐾𝑐𝑎𝑡/𝐾𝑚 is maximized with high 𝐾𝑐𝑎𝑡​ and low Km​.

questions.text: Identify the foramen marked in the image below: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Foramen rotundum

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the sphenoid bone. The foramen marked is the foramen rotundum. Maxillary branch of trigeminal nerve passes through it.

 

 

The foramen rotundum is a small circular opening in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone, located in the middle cranial fossa of the skull. It serves as a passage for the maxillary nerve (CN V2), which is one of the three branches of the trigeminal nerve.

 

The maxillary nerve exits the cranial cavity through the foramen rotundum and then travels through the pterygopalatine fossa, where it gives off several branches that innervate the maxillary teeth, the maxillary sinus, and the skin of the face in the maxillary region.

 

Other structures that may pass through the foramen rotundum include small blood vessels and veins, but these are less significant than the maxillary nerve in terms of clinical relevance.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Foramen Ovale:

 

  • Location: The foramen ovale is also located in the sphenoid bone, adjacent (Postero- lateral) to the foramen rotundum.
  • Contents: It transmits the mandibular nerve (another branch of the trigeminal nerve or CN V3), the accessory meningeal artery, and sometimes a small emissary vein.

 

Option C. Vidian Canal (Pterygoid Canal):

 

  • Location: The vidian canal is a small canal in the sphenoid bone, extending from the pterygopalatine fossa to the middle cranial fossa.
  • Contents: It contains the vidian nerve, which is a branch of the maxillary nerve (CN V2), as well as the vidian artery and sympathetic fibers.

 

Option D. Foramen Spinosum:

 

  • Location: The foramen spinosum is situated in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. It is present postero-lateral to foramen ovale
  • Contents: It transmits the middle meningeal artery, a branch of the maxillary artery, and the middle meningeal vein.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the level of the cross-section shown in the image below. (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. T4-T5

 

Explanation:

 

The cross-section shown in the image is at the level of T4-T5.

 

Ascending and Descending aorta are visible separately along with bifurcation of pulmonary trunk, this implies it is the section of T4-T5 level.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options A, Option B: In cross-sections at the levels of T1-T2 and T2-T3, only the small vascular openings of the branches arising from the arch of aorta would be visible.

 

Option C: In cross section of T3-T4 level  - section of arch of aorta along with branches of arch of aorta would be visible

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bifurcation of pulmonary trunk along with separate ascending and descending aorta are clearing pointing towards T4-T5 level.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was operated for a tumour in the lower end of femur. The gross specimen of the resected tumour is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INCET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

OSTEOSARCOMA

 

  • The matrix forming the tumor is the cause of calcification.
  • It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone behind multiple myeloma.
  • The classic form of osteosarcoma is typically seen in patients in their second or third decade, with a peak in the adolescent growth spurt.
  • It occurs more frequently in males than in females and is found in the metaphyseal areas of long bones, with 50% of lesions about the knee joint.
  • The distal femur is the most common site, followed by the proximal tibia and then the proximal humerus.
  • Characteristic histological feature is malignant cells with osteoid formation. This osteoid matrix presents as calcification.
  • Osteosarcoma is the most common radiation-induced sarcoma.
  • Clinical features:
    • Almost all patients report progressive pain. Night pain may be an important clue to the true diagnosis, seen in 25% of patients
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Permeated lytic destruction of metaphyseal bone, with eventual cortical breakthrough into the subperiosteal space and subsequent formation of a Codman triangle at the diaphyseal end of the tumor.

 

 

Codman’s triangle

 

  • As the tumor continues to push its way into the extracortical soft tissue, a typical sunburst pattern of neoplastic bone may be seen outside the involved bone.

 

 

  • MRI is the best test to measure the extent of the tumor within the bone and in the soft tissue and to determine the relationship of the tumor to nearby anatomical structures.
  • A bone scan should be obtained to look for skeletal metastases, and radiographs and CT scans of the chest should be done to search for pulmonary metastases; the lungs are the most common sites of metastases.
  • CT scan may be helpful in differentiating osteosarcoma from myositis ossificans or an osteochondroma. The ossification in myositis ossificans is more mature at the periphery of the lesion, whereas the center of osteosarcoma is more heavily ossified.
  • Treatment:
    • It is highly radio-resistant tumor and ideally, treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.
    • With the combination of chemotherapy and surgical treatment, the prognosis for 5-year survival is 70-80%.
    • The drugs commonly used today include high-dose methotrexate, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and ifosfamide.
    • In osteosarcoma of the extremities, limb-sparing surgery with wide resection of the tumor is the standard approach.
    • Amputation is reserved for the exceptional or recurrent case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chondrosarcoma. It occurs over a broad age range, with peaks between 40 and 60 years for primary chondrosarcoma and between 25 and 45 years for secondary chondrosarcoma. Most common in Proximal location like pelvis (most common site), proximal femur, and proximal humerus. Most common malignant tumor of bone in hand (although rarely occur). Secondary chondrosarcomas arise at the site of a pre-existing benign cartilage lesion like in case of multiple enchondromas and multiple hereditary exostoses. Chondrosarcoma can produce hyperglycemia in 85% cases. Metastasis from Chondrosarcoma most commonly goes to lungs (hematogenous). The radiographic appearance is similar to enchondroma, it is a lesion arising in the medullary cavity with irregular matrix calcification. The pattern of Calcification is described as “Punctate”, “popcorn”, or “comma-shaped”. It has a more aggressive appearance with Bone destruction, cortical erosions, periosteal reaction, and rarely a soft-tissue mass. Treatment is by Wide local excision/Radical excision.

 

 

Option C. GCT. They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance. The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation. Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients. Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT. Radiographic findings often are diagnostic. The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone with soap bubble appearance. Microscopically, giant cell tumors are composed of many multinucleated giant cells (typically 40-60 nuclei per cell) in a sea of mononuclear stromal cells (malignant cells). Curettage and stripping of the cavity is the treatment of choice.

 

 

Option D. Chondroblastoma. Chondroblastoma is a rare type of benign tumor that grows at the ends of the long bones, close to the joints. Most often, the tumors develop at the ends of the femur, tibia, or humerus. They typically occur in children and young adults, and are more common in males. Although chondroblastomas are not cancerous, they can continue to grow if left untreated. A growing tumor can destroy the surrounding bone, making it painful to move the nearby joint. The cause of chondroblastomas is not known. The tumors are thought to arise from the growth plates at the ends of the bones, near joints. Classic “chicken wire” calcification is seen. Epiphysis + calcification + upper end humerus = Chondroblastoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows a cut section of osteosarcoma of the femur.
  • The destructive tumor arises from the metaphysis, with extensive involvement of the marrow cavity and extension into soft tissue.

questions.text: A patient presented with meningitis with a history of fever for 4 days and erythematous rashes on the chest. There was no history of travel and tick bite. His CSF findings showed increased protein, normal glucose, mild lymphocytosis and few RBCs. Which of the following is the most likely organism to cause this clinical picture? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Enterovirus

 

The clinical presentation and CSF findings are suggestive of viral meningitis, most probably caused by an Enterovirus. Enteroviruses are common causes of viral meningitis and present with fever, rashes, and mild lymphocytosis in the CSF.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. West Nile virus: Although it can cause meningitis, there is no history of travel, making this less likely. West Nile virus is endemic in certain regions of North America like California Central Valley, southwestern Arizona, southern Texas, and Louisiana, which have both compatible climates and avian reservoirs for the disease.

 

Option B. Meningococci: Typically causes bacterial meningitis with higher neutrophil count and lower glucose levels in the CSF.

 

Option C. Strep pneumoniae: Also typically causes bacterial meningitis with higher neutrophil count and lower glucose levels in the CSF.

 

Educational objective

 

CSF Findings for Different Types of Meningitis:

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not involved in the overhead abduction of the arm? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pectoralis major

 

  • Pectoralis major is mainly involved in flexion, adduction and medial rotation of the arm (at the shoulder joint) and is not involved in the abduction of the arm.
  • Glenohumeral abduction is about 120° or more. The glenohumeral arthrodesis restricts the abduction at about 45°. Further abduction occurs at the sterno- and acromioclavicular articulations, and contralateral vertebral flexion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serratus Anterior: The serratus anterior muscle is involved in the overhead abduction of the arm. This muscle helps in the upward rotation of the scapula, allowing the arm to be raised overhead.

 

Option B. Deltoid: The deltoid muscle is a key muscle for overhead abduction of the arm. It has three distinct portions (anterior, middle, and posterior) that cover the shoulder joint. The middle portion of the deltoid is particularly responsible for abduction of the arm, lifting it away from the body.

 

Option C. Trapezius: The trapezius muscle also plays a role in the overhead abduction of the arm. The upper fibers of the trapezius assist in elevating the shoulder girdle, contributing to arm abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PRINCIPLE MUSCLES ACTING ON SHOULDERS

questions.text: The disruption of which of the following is responsible for watery diarrhea in cholera caused by Vibrio? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zonula occludens

 

When cholera toxin is released from the bacteria in the infected intestine, it binds to the intestinal cells known as enterocytes through the interaction of the pentameric B subunit of the toxin with the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the intestinal cell, triggering endocytosis of the toxin.

 

Next, the A/B cholera toxin must undergo cleavage of the A1 domain from the A2 domain in order for A1 to become an active enzyme.

 

Once inside the enterocyte, the enzymatic A1 fragment of the toxin A subunit enters the cytosol, where it activates the G protein Gsa through an ADP-ribosylation reaction that acts to lock the G protein in its GTP-bound form, thereby continually stimulating adenylate cyclase to produce cAMP. 

 

The high cAMP levels activate the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), causing a dramatic efflux of ions and water from infected enterocytes, leading to watery diarrhea.

 

 

The effects of cholera involve the actions of other Vibrio cholerae toxins that aid the pathogen in its colonization, coordinated expression of virulence factors, and toxin action.

 

These additional proteins include

 

  • Zona occludens toxin (zot, involved in Vibrio cholerae invasion by acting to decrease intestinal tissue resistance)
  • Accessory cholera toxin (ace, increases fluid secretion)
  • Toxin-coregulated pilus (tcpA, essential colonisation factor receptor for the CTXf phage)
  • NAG-specific heat-labile toxin (st)
  • Outer membrane porin proteins (ompU and ompT).
  • The expression of virulence factors is controlled by the transcriptional factors ToxR, TcpP and ToxT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intercalated discs: Found in cardiac muscle cells and involved in cell-to-cell adhesion and electrical coupling, not related to intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Option B. Macula densa: Involved in regulating kidney function and blood pressure, not related to intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Option D. Hemidesmosomes: Involved in cell-to-extracellular matrix adhesion, not related to intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The disruption of zonula occludens (tight junctions) by cholera toxin is responsible for the increased permeability of intestinal epithelial cells, leading to the characteristic watery diarrhea seen in cholera.

questions.text: A clinician is conducting a study on the occurrence of a rare disease within a specific population over a certain time period. The disease cases occur independently, and the average rate of occurrence is constant. Which statistical distribution best represents the likelihood of observing a specific number of disease cases within this defined time period? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Poisson distribution

 

Poisson Distribution

 

  • It is a ‘discrete probability distribution’ that expresses the ‘probability of a number of events occurring in a fixed period of time’ (if these events occur with a known average rate and independently of the time since the last event).
  • It can also be used for the number of events in other specified intervals such as distance, area or volume.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Binomial distribution is used for those events which can only have two possible results given as yes or no / success or failure. It is usually done for finite number of events unlike Poisson’s distribution.

 

Option B. Gaussian distribution/ D. Normal distribution is the distribution of values of a quantitative variable such that they are symmetric with respect to a middle value with same mean, median and mode, and then the frequencies taper off rapidly and symmetrically on both sides – ‘bell shaped distribution’.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Poisson distribution is used to model the number of rare disease cases occurring independently in a fixed period of time.

questions.text:
Identify the findings in freshwater drowning? (INICET Nov 2020)

  1. Hemodilution

  2. Hypokalemia

  3. Hyponatremia

  4. Arrhythmia
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1, 3, 4

 

Rather than hypokalemia, there is an increase in potassium levels due to the release of intracellular potassium from swollen red blood cells. Hypokalemia is not typically a finding in freshwater drowning.

 

1. Haemodilution: Due to the excessive absorption of water through the alveolar-capillary membrane, the blood becomes diluted.

 

3. Hyponatremia: Haemodilution leads to a decrease in the concentration of sodium in the blood.

 

4. Arrhythmia: Electrolyte abnormalities caused by the haemodilution and resultant imbalance can lead to cardiac arrhythmias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of freshwater drowning, we see

 

  • Hemodilution – Due to excessive fluid absorption

  • Hyponatremia – Due to hemodilution

  • Arrythmia – Due to electrolyte abnormalities

  • Hyperkalemia -Due to release of intracellular potassium from swollen RBCs

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures does not form part of the laryngeal skeleton? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation

 

The structure marked as 'A', is the hyoid bone, which is not a part of the laryngeal skeleton.

 

The hyoid bone is a U-shaped bone located at the base of the tongue. While it is not considered a part of the larynx itself.

 

The structures marked in the image are:

 

A - Hyoid bone

B - Thyroid cartilage

C - Epiglottis

D - Cricoid cartilage

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thyroid Cartilage: The thyroid cartilage is a large, shield-shaped cartilage in the larynx. It forms the prominent Adam's apple in the front of the neck and plays a role in sound production.

 

Option C. Epiglottis: The epiglottis is a leaf-shaped cartilage  which belongs to larynx located at the base of the tongue. Its primary function is to prevent food and liquids from entering the airway (trachea) during swallowing.

 

Option D. Cricoid Cartilage: The cricoid cartilage is a ring-shaped cartilage located just below the thyroid cartilage. It is the only complete ring of cartilage in the larynx and provides structural support to the airway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A set of cartilages that are joined by ligaments and fibrous membranes make up the laryngeal skeleton:

 

  • Hyaline cartilage: The thyroid, cricoid, and the greater part of the arytenoid cartilages
  • Elastic cartilage: The corniculate, cuneiform, tritiate, and epiglottic cartilages and the apices of the arytenoid cartilage.

questions.text: Which of the following bony structures is present behind the marked area? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lesser wing of sphenoid

 

The pterion is a point on the side of the skull where several bones meet, including the frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones. The lesser wing of the sphenoid is one of the bones that contributes to the formation of the pterion. It's an important landmark because it's located just behind the pterion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post clivus: The clivus is a bony ridge on the occipital bone, and it is located at the base of the skull. The "post clivus" isn't a commonly used term in anatomy, and it's not directly related to the pterion.

 

Option C. Sella turcica: The sella turcica is a saddle-shaped depression in the sphenoid bone where the pituitary gland is located. It is situated more toward the center of the skull, behind the eyes and nasal cavity, and is not directly related to the pterion.

 

Option D. Carotid canal: The carotid canal is a passage in the temporal bone that houses the internal carotid artery. It is located deeper within the skull, closer to the middle ear, and is not directly related to the pterion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pterion is an H-shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

 

1. Frontal bone

2. Squamous part of the temporal bone

3. Greater wing of the sphenoid bone

4. Parietal bone

choices.text: Dilated loops of intestine with valvulae conniventes

questions.text: Which of the following is a finding of large bowel obstruction? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dilated loops with haustrations

 

Explanation:

 

Dilated bowel loops with haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction.

Large bowel obstructions have colonic distension proximal to the obstruction with the distal portion collapsed. The colon is considered dilated if it is more than 6 cm in diameter while the cut off for caecum is 9cm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dilated loops of intestine with valvulae conniventes: Dilated loops of the intestine with plica circulars (valvulae conniventes) and predominantly central loops are features of the small bowel obstruction. The small bowel is considered dilated if it is more than 3 cm in diameter.

 

Option B. String of pearls sign: The string of pearls sign is also a feature of small bowel obstruction seen in plain radiographs or CT. It represents a row of gas bubbles trapped between the valvulae conniventes.

 

Option C. Central dilated bowel loops: While central dilation can occur in any intestinal obstruction, it is more typical of small bowel obstruction where the loops tend to centrally accumulate.

 

Educational Objective:


Identifying dilated loops with haustrations is critical for diagnosing large bowel obstruction, helping differentiate it from small bowel obstruction, which features dilated loops with valvulae conniventes and may show the string of pearls sign.

questions.text: Match the following poisons and their probable mechanism of action: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

 

Explanation:

 

A. Zinc chloride:

 

  • Mechanism: Irritant
  • Explanation: Zinc chloride is a chemical compound known to cause erosive esophagitis and irritation to the eyes and mucous membranes.

 

B. Chloral hydrate:

 

  • Mechanism: Stupefying (CNS depressant)
  • Explanation: Chloral hydrate is a central nervous system depressant used historically as a sedative and hypnotic agent.

 

C. Quinine:

 

  • Mechanism: Abortifacient
  • Explanation: Quinine has been used historically to induce abortion, although its use in this context is highly dangerous and not recommended.

 

D. Potassium carbonate:

 

  • Mechanism: Corrosive
  • Explanation: Potassium carbonate is an alkali that has a corrosive action on tissues, causing chemical burns upon contact.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in given endoscopic view of the nasal cavity:(INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inferior turbinate

 

Marked structure is Inferior turbinate.

 

  • Inferior turbinate is a separate bone, arranged longitudinally.
  • Attaches anteriorly with maxilla and posteriorly with palatine bone.
  • Also attached to lacrimal bone and uncinate process of ethmoid in between.
  • Over the bone, thick vascular mucosal tissue surrounds.
  • The vascular channels travel from posterior to anterior inside the turbinate mucosa, so that inspired air will be in exchange of moisture (humidification of inspired air) with vascular channels for a long duration.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Middle turbinate: This is located above the inferior turbinate and is part of the ethmoid bone. It plays a role in directing air flow and protecting sinus openings.

 

Option C. Superior turbinate: The smallest of the turbinates, located higher up in the nasal cavity and also part of the ethmoid bone.

 

Option D. Uncinate process: This is a part of the ethmoid bone that forms the anterior border of the hiatus semilunaris, involved in the drainage pathway of the sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inferior turbinate is a critical structure for the proper conditioning of air entering the respiratory system. Its large surface area and vascular mucosa play essential roles in the humidification and warming of inhaled air, contributing to the overall respiratory health and protection against pathogens and particulate matter.

questions.text: In spine straightening surgeries, screws used for fixation are inserted through which of the following parts of the vertebra? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pedicle

 

  • Spinal instrumentation (rods,  screws, hooks, etc.) are applied to the region of the spine to be corrected through transpedicular route and bone graft is added. 

  • In the spine straightening surgery, to stabilize the spine, screws are placed on the pedicles of the vertebral bone. 

 

 

  • Hooks may also be used in conjunction with screws, and are placed around the pedicle or around the lamina.

  • Rods are then secured in the screw heads, connecting adjacent vertebrae. 

  • The rods are shaped to match the desired corrected curvature of the spine, and are attached to the screws and/or hooks.

  • Bone graft material is placed around the final assembly and as the spine heals, spinal fusion is accomplished by bone growth between the vertebrae. This bone growth permanently fixes the spine in the desired position. The implants hold the spine in the corrected position while the spine fuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pedicle of the vertebra is the area used to fixate the screws through during the spine straightening surgeries for scoliosis.

questions.text: Identify the cells marked in the given image? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymphocyte- 1, Monocyte-4, Eosinophil-2, Basophil-3, Neutrophil -5

 

 

A peripheral blood smear shows RBCs, WBCs (granulocytes and agranulocytes), and platelets.

 

1. Lymphocyte : Lymphocytes are slightly larger than red blood cells (RBCs) and have a large, dense nucleus with little cytoplasm and no granules.

 

4. Monocyte : Monocytes are the largest WBCs with a kidney-shaped nucleus and abundant cytoplasm without granules.

 

2. Eosinophil : Eosinophils have bilobed nuclei (spectacle-shaped) with large, brick-red (eosinophilic) granules in the cytoplasm.

 

3. Basophil : Basophils have large bluish granules that obscure the nucleus, which is often difficult to see due to the dense granulation.

 

5. Neutrophil : Neutrophils typically have a multi-lobed (3-5 lobes) nucleus and fine bluish granules in the cytoplasm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granulocytes:

 

  • Neutrophil - 3 to 5 lobed nucleus with small, bluish granules in the cytoplasm
  • Eosinophil - Binucleate/spectacle shaped nuclei with brick-red granules in the cytoplasm
  • Basophil- Large bluish granules in the cytoplasm which obscure the nucleus.

 

Agranulocytes:

 

  • Lymphocytes- size just larger than an BC. No granules, no nucleoli present.
  • Monocytes - largest cells with a kidney-shaped nucleus.

questions.text: A farmer presents with a swollen foot and multiple sinuses as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mycetoma

 

The most likely diagnosis here is Mycetoma which is caused by Eumycetoma.

 

Mycetoma is an uncommon chronic granulomatous infective disease of the skin/dermis and subcutaneous tissues. “Madura Foot” or “Maduramycosis,” it is caused by true fungi (eumycetoma) or by the filamentous bacteria (actinomycetoma).

 

It is characterized by a triad of tumefaction, draining sinuses and the presence of colonial grains in the exudates. It is seen commonly in people who walk barefoot. Eumycetoma is more common in Northern India, while Actinomycetoma is more common in Southern India.

 

The two main groups of mycetoma are the Actinomycotic and Eumycotic groups. Actinomycetoma is caused by a group of filamentous bacteria which include Nocardia and Streptomyces species. The Nocardia species include Nocardia asteroids, Nocardia braziliensis and Nocardia caviae. The Streptomyces species include Streptomyces madurae, Streptomyces pelletieri and Streptomyces somaliensis.

 

The color of the grains found in the discharge is indicative of the species and helps to initiate appropriate treatment.

 

The foot is the most commonly affected and the dorsal aspect of the left foot for unexplained reasons is more affected.

 

The grains are histologically seen as sulfur granules surrounded by neutrophils which lead to a purulent tissue reaction containing fibroblasts. This prevents the antibiotic from acting on the micro-organisms, hence the need for debridement in certain cases.
