Combined drug therapy is preferred to a single drug therapy to avoid resistance and any residual infection.

 

Surgical debridement, followed by prolonged appropriate antibiotic therapy for several months is required for actinomycetoma while a combination therapy with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (14 mg/kg, twice daily), dapsone (1.5 mg/kg, twice daily) and streptomycin (14 mg/kg) has been used along with Rifampicin for resistant cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: Typically presents as a non-healing ulcer or nodule and does not exhibit the characteristic draining sinuses and grains seen in mycetoma.

 

Option C. Nocardia: Nocardia can cause mycetoma (specifically actinomycetoma), but in the context of the broad diagnosis, mycetoma is the more inclusive and accurate term.

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis: Caused by Sporothrix schenckii, usually presents with nodular lesions along lymphatic channels rather than multiple sinuses and grains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycetoma is characterized by swelling, draining sinuses, and colonial grains in exudates, and is common among individuals who walk barefoot. The diagnosis is supported by clinical presentation, histology, and the color of the grains. Treatment involves surgical debridement and prolonged antibiotic therapy for actinomycetoma or antifungal therapy for eumycetoma.

questions.text: A psychotic patient developed voluntary purposeless movements and was once observed to be standing still for hours with waxy flexibility and negativism. What is the appropriate medical management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lorazepam

 

The patient's presentation suggests catatonia, which can manifest with features like waxy flexibility, negativism, and purposeless movements.

 

Lorazepam is a first-line treatment for catatonia. It often provides rapid relief of symptoms.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Haloperidol is an antipsychotic that can be used in psychotic disorders, but it is not the first-line treatment for catatonia. Additionally, antipsychotics might exacerbate or even induce catatonia.

 

Option C. Clonidine and Option D. Propranolol are not used as primary treatments for catatonia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Catatonia is a neuropsychiatric syndrome that can manifest with features like waxy flexibility, negativism, and purposeless movements. Lorazepam is a first-line treatment for catatonia and can provide rapid symptom relief. ECT is considered to be the treatment of choice.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 59, 67.

questions.text: A woman with Grave's disease was taking antithyroid medication throughout her pregnancy. The baby was born with aplasia cutis congenita. Which drug could have caused this condition? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carbimazole

 

Carbimazole is a medication used to treat hyperthyroidism and is known to cause teratogenic effects if used during pregnancy. It can lead to a rare congenital condition called aplasia cutis congenita, where the baby is born with localized areas of missing skin. The use of carbimazole, especially during the first trimester of pregnancy, is linked with this embryopathy, which highlights the importance of careful medication selection in pregnant women with thyroid disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methylthiouracil: Although it is an antithyroid drug, it is less commonly used and not specifically associated with aplasia cutis congenita.

 

Option C. Levothyroxine: This is a thyroid hormone replacement and is used to treat hypothyroidism, not associated with congenital defects.

 

Option D. Hydrouracil: This option appears to be a distractor as no such common drug name exists that is relevant in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MMZ, Carbimazole associated with embryonopathy in first trimester

 

Graves in Pregnancy:

 

<16 weeks: PTU (MM teratogenic)

 

>16 weeks: MMI (PTU hepatotoxicity)

 

Lactation: MMI (RAIA avoided 4-6 weeks after cessation of breastfeeding as RAI is concentrated in breast tissue)

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Hyperthyroidism/Graves/Chap 384

questions.text: 50 yr old gentleman presented with progressive abdominal distension with shifting dullness on examination and dilated veins on lateral chest wall. Ascitic fluid analysis given below. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Budd-Chiari syndrome

 

Presence of lateral dilated veins with high SAAG, low protein suggests Late Budd-Chiari syndrome.

 

SAAG=Serum albumin- Ascitic Albumin = 2g/dl

 

Interpretation

 

  • ≥1.1: Portal Hypertension (Transudate)
  • <1.1: Exudate

 

Ascitic fluid protein helps identify sinusoidal vs non-sinusoidal causes

 

  • Ascitic fluid protein >2.5 = non-sinusoidal  

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congestive Heart Failure: Typically presents with high SAAG and high protein content in the ascitic fluid.

 

Option C. Cirrhosis: While cirrhosis can also present with high SAAG, it usually shows low protein content in the ascitic fluid, which aligns with this case, but the presence of dilated veins specific to Budd-Chiari provides a more accurate diagnosis.

 

Option D. Tuberculosis: Tuberculous peritonitis typically presents with a low SAAG and high protein content, which is inconsistent with the findings in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Hepatology/ascites

questions.text: A young woman was found dead at home under mysterious circumstances. Her live-in partner was reported missing. These were the postmortem images taken by the forensic photographer. Which of the following is the likely cause of her death? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Throttling  

 

Manual strangulation, also known as throttling, is a type of asphyxial death where the perpetrator uses his hand to encircle and compress the front and side of the neck

 

In throttling, the following mechanisms may lead to death:

 

Autopsy findings:

 

  • Bruising on the neck

  • Abrasions of the neck

  • Contused tissues of the neck

 

Cause of death in throttling:

 

  • Occlusion of blood supply to the blood to the brain - carotid arteries

  • Occlusion of the airway leading to asphyxia

  • Carotid sinus pressure causing cardiac arrest

 

The given autopsy images are suggestive of throttling.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Strangulation: While strangulation is a general term that includes throttling, the specific mechanism in this case is manual strangulation, which is best described as throttling.

 

Option C. Hanging: Hanging typically presents with a ligature mark around the neck and different positional signs, which are not visible in this image.

 

Option D. Mugging: Mugging involves external pressure applied using limbs or objects, which generally do not produce the distinct bruising and abrasions seen in throttling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Throttling involves manual strangulation by applying pressure to the neck, causing bruises, abrasions, and contusions, and can lead to death by occlusion of blood supply or airway and pressure on the carotid sinus.

questions.text: A patient presents with a mobile, warm to touch nodule in the neck. On the anaerobic culture of the biopsy material from this swelling, it showed colonies as shown in the image which had gram-positive branching rods on staining. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Penicillin

 

The colonies resemble breadcrumbs or the surface of ‘molar’ teeth suggestive of actinomycete infection of cervicofacial region also called as Lumpy jaw.

 

Culture characteristics - Grows slowly under anaerobic conditions, on blood or serum glucose agar at 37°C. After about a week, it appears as small, creamy-white, adherent colonies on blood agar. The colonies resemble breadcrumbs or the surface of ‘molar’ teeth.

 

Gram-positive filamentous branching rods. Non-motile, non-sporing and non-acid-fast. Clumps of the organisms can be seen as yellowish ‘sulphur granules’ in pus discharging from sinus tracts, or the granules can be squeezed out of the lesions.

 

Sensitive to penicillin, but prolonged courses up to 6 weeks are necessary for chronic infections. Oral penicillin such as amoxicillin are now popular. Clindamycin and erythromycin are effective in patients with penicillin allergy. Recalcitrant lesions respond well to tetracycline because of its good bone penetration. Surgical intervention may be necessary in chronic jaw lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline: Effective for certain infections but not the first-line treatment for actinomycete infections.

 

Option B. Cotrimoxazole: Not typically used for actinomycete infections.

 

Option D. Surgical drainage: May be required as an adjunct to antibiotic therapy in chronic cases, but it is not the primary treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Penicillin is the drug of choice for treating actinomycete infections, particularly in cervicofacial cases presenting with nodules and characteristic colonies. Prolonged antibiotic therapy is necessary, and surgical intervention may be required for chronic lesions.

questions.text: The given condition is caused by which drug? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bleomycin

 

  • The given image shows flagellate dermatitis. It is caused by bleomycin.
  • Flagellate dermatoses are infrequent types of figurate dermatoses characterized by parallel lines or curves resembling whiplash marks.
  • Bleomycin, a polypeptide chemotherapeutic agent, primarily affects the respiratory and cutaneous systems, likely due to the absence of the inactivating enzyme hydrolase in these tissues.

 

 

  • It manifests as widespread, itchy, flagellate, erythematous plaques on the trunk and extremities within hours to months after bleomycin administration.
  • Flagellate hyperpigmentation may persist even after the rash has resolved.
  • While there is no specific treatment for this condition, avoiding bleomycin can lead to clearance of the symptoms over several months to years.
  • However, re-exposure to the drug might trigger a more severe reaction.
  • Bleomycin is also associated with development of pulmonary fibrosis.
  • Peplomycin, a bleomycin derivative with reduced pulmonary toxicity, is utilized in the treatment of prostatic carcinoma and lymphomas. Nevertheless, it has been associated with flagellate erythema through mechanisms like those of bleomycin.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Bleomycin, on the other hand, can cause skin side effects like flagellate erythema, which appears as streaky red or hyperpigmented lines on the skin, resembling the appearance in the image provided. This particular side effect is a hallmark of Bleomycin toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For medical students and residents, it is crucial to identify bleomycin as the chemotherapeutic agent that can cause flagellate hyperpigmentation, a dermatological side effect not commonly associated with actinomycin, mitomycin C, or doxorubicin.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 4 & 120, Page no 4.12 & 120.8

Goodman & Gillman’s The pharmacological basis of therapeutics 13th edition Page no 1193

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3702947/

https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/share/F7KSRDKWUJX3W2GZTEAC?target=10.1002/ski2.92

questions.text: A statistician is examining the scores of a recent standardized test to assess the variability in student performance. She is particularly interested in understanding the extent of score dispersion from the lowest to the highest mark achieved. Which statistical measure should she use to directly determine this? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Range

 

  • Range is expressed as minimum - maximum (or maximum – minimum) values in a given set of data.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Variance: It is given as square of standard deviation (Deviation of each value from the standard value).

 

Option B. Coefficient of variation (COV): It is a measure used to compare relative variability.

 

Option D. Interquartile range: Quartiles divide the distribution into 4 equal groups. The difference between Q1 and Q3 gives the interquartile range.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The range directly measures the extent of score dispersion from the lowest to the highest value in a dataset.

questions.text: Transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation is used to reduce pain. What is the mechanism behind this?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gate control theory

 

Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) used for pain relief is based on the gate theory of pain.

 

According to gate control theory, the pain stimuli transmitted by afferent pain fibers are blocked by gate mechanism located at the posterior gray horn of spinal cord. If the gate is opened, pain is felt. If the gate is closed, pain is suppressed.

 

 

TENS activates a complex neuronal network using electrodes to result in a reduction in pain. At frequencies and intensities used clinically, TENS activates large diameter afferent fibers. This afferent input is sent to the central nervous system to activate descending inhibitory systems to reduce hyperalgesia. Specifically, blockade of neuronal activity in the periaqueductal gray (PAG), rostral ventromedial medulla (RVM) and spinal cord inhibit the analgesic effects of TENS showing that TENS analgesia is maintained through these pathways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central inhibition: Incorrect. Central inhibition is not the primary mechanism of action for TENS in pain relief.

 

Option B. Desensitization: Incorrect. Desensitization refers to a reduction in response to a stimulus over time, which is not the primary mechanism for TENS.

 

Option D. Descending inhibition: Incorrect. While descending inhibitory pathways are involved in the modulation of pain, the gate control theory specifically explains the mechanism behind TENS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) reduces pain through the gate control theory, which involves blocking pain signals at the spinal cord level by activating large diameter afferent fibers.

choices.text: When used with alcohol, the patients develops nausea, vomiting, flushing, chest discomfort and palpitations
It is an anti-craving drug for alcohol
It can be initiated even in minimally motivated person
Its action persists maximum up to 2-3 days after stopping the drug

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about disulfiram? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. When used with alcohol, the patients develops nausea, vomiting, flushing, chest discomfort and palpitations

 

Disulfiram, when used concurrently with alcohol, causes an accumulation of acetaldehyde in the body due to its inhibition of the enzyme acetaldehyde dehydrogenase. This leads to a range of unpleasant symptoms, including nausea, vomiting, flushing, chest discomfort, and palpitations, which are part of the Disulfiram-alcohol reaction. This reaction is intentional and serves as a deterrent to alcohol consumption. It is given at a dose of 250mg/day, dose may be increased up to 500 mg/day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Disulfiram is not primarily an anti-craving drug for alcohol. It works by creating an aversive reaction to alcohol rather than reducing the craving for alcohol. Medications like naltrexone or acamprosate are more accurately described as anti-craving drugs.

 

Option C. Disulfiram should be prescribed to highly motivated individuals. It requires a commitment to abstain from alcohol due to the serious nature of the Disulfiram-alcohol reaction. It is not typically recommended for individuals who are minimally motivated or likely to continue consuming alcohol.

 

Option D. The action of Disulfiram can persist beyond 2-3 days after stopping the drug. Its inhibitory effect on acetaldehyde dehydrogenase can last for up to a week or more in some cases, making it possible for the Disulfiram-alcohol reaction to occur even several days after the last dose of Disulfiram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Disulfiram, when used concurrently with alcohol, causes a severe and unpleasant reaction due to the accumulation of acetaldehyde, including nausea, vomiting, flushing, chest discomfort, and palpitations, serving as a deterrent to alcohol consumption. It should be used in highly motivated individuals committed to abstaining from alcohol.

questions.text: Match the following weapons with the possible injuries caused by them: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A-4, B-3, C-1, D-2

 

Mechanism of Injury with the Following Weapons:

 

A. Axe - 4. Chop wound: Axes are heavy and have a sharp edge, causing deep, gaping wounds that are classified as chop wounds.

 

B. RTA (Road Traffic Accident)- 3.Grazed abrasion: In RTAs, the skin may be scraped off, resulting in grazed abrasions due to friction against the road surface.

 

C. Blade- 1. Incised wound: Blades are sharp-edged tools that cause clean, sharp cuts known as incised wounds.

 

D. Lathi - 2. Tram track wound: A lathi, or baton, is a blunt object that can cause parallel linear bruises known as tram track wounds when struck with force.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mechanism of injury with the following weapons:

questions.text: Which among the following is the most severe manifestation of CKD? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia 

 

Hyperkalemia, characterized by elevated potassium levels in the blood, is particularly dangerous in CKD due to its direct impact on cardiac function. High potassium levels can disrupt normal heart rhythms, potentially leading to life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased GFR: While it indicates the progression of CKD and reduced kidney function, it does not pose immediate life-threatening risks like hyperkalemia.

 

Option B. Increased creatinine: Indicates kidney dysfunction but is a marker rather than a direct cause of severe clinical consequences.

 

Option D. Proteinuria: Signifies kidney damage; however, it is more of a prognostic indicator rather than an acute life-threatening condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperkalemia in CKD patients is a critical condition that requires immediate medical attention due to its potential to cause fatal cardiac disturbances. Always prioritize the management of hyperkalemia in CKD patients to prevent cardiac complications.

questions.text: Mr. Thompson, a 58-year-old male, underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy for the treatment of gallstones. Following the procedure, he complained of abdominal pain and fever. Upon further evaluation, it was found that he had a bile leak. The surgeon ordered imaging tests to identify the extent of the bile duct injury. The imaging results showed injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct with bile leak. What would be the Strasberg classification of this injury? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type C

 

Injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct associated with bile leak is classified as Strasberg's type C injury.

 

Correct. Strasberg Type C injuries are defined by bile leaks from the major ductal systems, such as the right posterior sectoral duct in this case. The leak can be caused by a missed stone, an unrecognized transection, or an avulsion due to excessive traction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type A: Strasberg Type A injuries are characterized by bile leaks from minor ducts or cystic duct that are present either at or near the gallbladder bed. They often present as bile collections in the gallbladder fossa.

 

Option B. Type B: Type B injuries involve an occlusion of the right posterior bile duct. This occlusion might be due to a clip placement or ligature, typically at the time of surgery. It does not involve a bile leak from an aberrant right posterior sectoral duct.

 

Option D. Type D: Type D injuries are characterized by lateral injury or partial transection of extrahepatic bile ducts/Common hepatic hepatic. This would be more extensive than just a leak from an aberrant duct.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Declare as complete abortion and follow-up in 15 days
Admit and observe
Follow-up with beta-HCG

questions.text: A patient with 6 weeks amenorrhea and a positive pregnancy test came with complaints of lower abdominal pain, moderate bleeding PV. She was hemodynamically stable. On ultrasound, there was no gestational sac in the uterus. Ovaries were normal and no free fluid in the pouch of Douglas. What is the next line of management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Follow-up with beta-HCG

 

The patient presents with symptoms that could indicate either an ectopic pregnancy or an early miscarriage. The absence of a gestational sac in the uterus on ultrasound at 6 weeks' gestation warrants further investigation to determine the location and viability of the pregnancy. The most appropriate next step is to follow up with serial beta-HCG levels.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Ectopic Pregnancy vs. Early Miscarriage: The differential diagnosis includes both ectopic pregnancy and early miscarriage.
  • Serial Beta-HCG Measurement: Beta-HCG levels typically double every 48-72 hours in a normal early intrauterine pregnancy. An abnormal rise or plateau in beta-HCG levels may indicate an ectopic pregnancy or a failing pregnancy.
  • Ultrasound Follow-up: In combination with beta-HCG monitoring, follow-up ultrasounds can help determine if a gestational sac becomes visible in the uterus or elsewhere.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Declare as complete abortion and follow-up in 15 days: Declaring a complete abortion without further investigation is premature and may miss an ectopic pregnancy, which can have serious complications.

 

Option B. Admit and observe: While observation is important, serial beta-HCG levels provide critical information that can guide further management decisions.

 

Option C. Diagnostic laparoscopy: This is an invasive procedure and is not the first step in stable patients without definitive evidence of ectopic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, a positive pregnancy test, and no gestational sac visible on ultrasound, the next step is to follow up with serial beta-HCG levels to differentiate between an early intrauterine pregnancy, an ectopic pregnancy, and a miscarriage.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg 356

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with history of acute MI complains of acute, severe, and diffuse abdominal pain accompanied by multiple episodes of vomiting. Upon examination, his pulse rate is 110bpm with an irregular rhythm, while his blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg. The abdomen looks soft, not swollen, and there are no bowel sounds. What potential diagnosis could be considered for this patient based on these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI)

 

AMI refers to the sudden onset of intestinal hypoperfusion, which can be caused by an arterial embolism, arterial thrombosis, or venous thrombosis. Given the patient's history of ischemic heart disease (IHD), he is at risk for cardiac emboli. The symptoms described, such as severe diffuse abdominal pain out of proportion to the clinical findings with an absence of bowel sounds and vomiting, are typical for AMI. The irregular rhythm (possibly atrial fibrillation) increases the risk of embolization, leading to acute mesenteric ischemia, typically involving SMA leading to massive intestinal gangrene if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute severe pancreatitis: While this can cause severe abdominal pain, it typically presents with pain radiating to the back and is often associated with a history of alcohol intake or gallstone disease. The absence of bowel sounds might be seen, but other signs like fever, lack of increased amylase or lipase levels, and the nature of pain differentiate it from AMI.

 

Option B. Ruptured aortic aneurysm: This is a life-threatening condition that presents with sudden, severe pain. While it can cause hypotension, the nature of pain and other clinical findings (e.g., palpable pulsatile abdominal mass) can differentiate it from AMI.

 

Option D. Peptic ulcer perforation: A perforated peptic ulcer can lead to sudden, severe abdominal pain. However, this typically presents with a board-like rigid abdomen due to the spillage of gastric contents into the peritoneal cavity, leading to acute peritonitis. This is different from the "soft" abdomen described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given clinical scenario suggests acute mesenteric ischemia as a possible diagnosis. The most common cause of acute mesenteric ischemia is an embolus. The risk factors for acute mesenteric ischemia/embolus in the given clinical scenario are the presence of an irregularly irregular pulse suggestive of atrial fibrillation and a previous history of ischemic heart disease/myocardial infarction.

 

The sudden onset of severe abdominal pain in a patient with atrial fibrillation or atherosclerosis is the most important clue to an early diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia. The pain is typically in the central abdomen and out of proportion to the physical findings. Associated features may include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal distension, peritonitis, and passage of bloody stools.

 

Angiography is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia, and management involves laparotomy. The goal of operative exploration is to reset the compromised bowel and restore blood supply via embolectomy.

questions.text: A resident in neurology is assessing a patient who recently sustained a traumatic brain injury using the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS). How should the resident describe the type of data obtained from the GCS? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ordinal scale data

 

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale represents ordinal data since the GCS score is categorized as mild, moderate, or severe, following a specific order of severity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nominal scale data: Data based on names without a specific order.

 

Option C. Alphanumerical data: Data that includes both letters and numbers, not applicable here.

 

Option D. Interval scale data: Data measured along a scale where each point is equidistant from the next, but GCS does not meet this criterion.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: All of the following nerves are involved in the movement of the eyeball except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation:

 

The nerve marked as 'A' is the optic nerve (II CN), and is not involved in the movement of the eyeball.

 

The optic nerve is primarily responsible for carrying visual information from the retina to the brain. It is not directly involved in controlling eye movements, but it is crucial for vision itself.

 

The nerves marked in the image are:

 

  • A- Optic nerve (II CN)
  • B- Oculomotor nerve (III CN)
  • C- Abducens nerve (VI CN)
  • D- Trochlear nerve (IV CN)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oculomotor nerve (III CN): The oculomotor nerve controls the majority of the eye's movements. It innervates several extraocular muscles responsible for moving the eye in various directions, including upward, downward, and medially. It also controls the pupil's constriction and the accommodation of the lens for focusing on near objects. It innervates all extraocular muscles except - lateral rectus and superior oblique.

 

Option C. Abducens nerve (VI CN): The abducens nerve controls the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for moving the eye outward or laterally. It allows for abduction of the eye, helping to look away from the nose.

 

Option D. Trochlear nerve (IV CN): The trochlear nerve controls the superior oblique muscle, which is responsible for depressing the eye and intorsion (rotation inward). It helps in downward and inward eye movements.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following pupillary abnormalities is most likely to be observed in a patient with primary open-angle glaucoma? (INICET Nov 2020
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Marcus Gunn pupil  

 

  • Primary open-angle glaucoma commonly causes bilateral and asymmetric optic nerve damage.
  • A defect in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex in one eye can cause a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or a Marcus-Gunn pupil on a swinging flashlight test.
  • The Marcus Gunn pupil is observed when the flashlight is moved from the normal to the abnormal eye and the affected pupil dilates instead of remaining constricted.
  • Seen in optic neuritis.
  • Earliest indictor of optic nerve disease (Retrobulbar neuritis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adie tonic pupil is a Sluggishly reacting mid-dilated pupil with light-near dissociation due to postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage.

 

Option C. Argyll-Robertson pupils (AR pupils) are bilateral small pupils with light-near dissociation, which is a specific sign in neurosyphilis and is due to a lesion in the pretectal nucleus.

 

Option D. Hutchinson's pupil is a clinical sign where the pupil on the side of an intracranial mass lesion is dilated and unreactive to light, due to compression of the oculomotor nerve on that side.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marcus Gunn pupil, or relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), is an important clinical sign in primary open-angle glaucoma, indicating asymmetric optic nerve damage, and is identified using the swinging flashlight test.

questions.text: The transplacental transmission of the organism given in the image which causes microcephaly is: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zika Virus

 

The image shows transplacental transmission of Zika virus given causing microcephaly.

 

Zika virus crosses the placental barrier and the developing blood–brain barrier (BBB). ZIKV exhibits clear tropism for proliferative neural cells, often with cytotoxic effects. ZIKV also productively and detrimentally infects cranial neural crest cells (CNCC), which give rise to cranial bones and can exert paracrine effects on the developing brain. Once Zika virions enter neurogenic regions in the brain, they reduce the number of mitotic progenitor cells by promoting cell cycle arrest and apoptotic cell death, autophagy, or possibly by precocious differentiation resulting in microcephaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nipah: Nipah virus primarily causes encephalitis and respiratory illness but does not typically cause congenital infections or microcephaly.

 

Option C. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV can cause congenital infections and microcephaly, but the image and description provided are specific to Zika virus.

 

Option D. Rubella: Rubella virus can cause congenital rubella syndrome, which includes microcephaly among other defects, but the specific viral transmission and pathology detailed in the image refer to Zika virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Zika virus is known for causing microcephaly through transplacental transmission by infecting and damaging neural progenitor cells in the developing fetal brain.

choices.text: No intervention as the patient is asymptomatic

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is found to have a fibroid of 14 weeks size. She has no specific symptoms. What is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) No intervention as the patient is asymptomatic

 

Explanation:

 

In the case of an asymptomatic fibroid, intervention is generally not required regardless of the size. The management approach is typically conservative, involving observation and regular monitoring.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Asymptomatic Fibroids: Fibroids that do not cause symptoms do not require immediate intervention. Instead, they can be observed with yearly ultrasounds or reviewed earlier if symptoms develop.
  • Common Symptoms of Fibroids: These include heavy menstrual bleeding, dysmenorrhea, pressure symptoms, and the presence of an abdominal mass.
  • Management of Symptomatic Fibroids: Depending on the patient's age, size of the fibroid, number, and location, symptomatic fibroids may be considered for myomectomy or hysterectomy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: This is a major surgical procedure and is typically reserved for symptomatic fibroids or when other treatment options have failed or are not suitable.

 

Option B. Myomectomy: Myomectomy is a surgical procedure to remove fibroids and is considered for symptomatic patients who wish to preserve their uterus.

 

Option D. Medical management: Medical management is used to manage symptoms and is not necessary for asymptomatic fibroids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In asymptomatic patients with fibroids, intervention is generally not required. Observation and regular monitoring are appropriate unless symptoms develop, in which case, further management options such as myomectomy or hysterectomy may be considered.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3rdedition Pg207

choices.text: 2,3 and 4
1,2,3 and 4
4 only
1 and 2 only

questions.text:
Ketosis is common in type 1 DM due to: (INICET Nov 2020)

1. Decreased beta-oxidation of fatty acids

2. Increased mobilization of fat from the adipose cell

3. Decreased acetyl Co in TCA cycle

4. Increased beta-hydroxy butyrate synthase
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3 and 4

 

2, 3 and 4 statements correctly explain the reason behind increased ketogenesis as seen in type1 DM.

 

In Type 1 DM insulin is deficient and GLUT4 (insulin-dependent uptake) mediated glucose uptake is not possible in the heart or skeletal muscles. So, fat is mobilized from adipose tissue for energy.

 

 

The following points explain the reasons behind increased ketogenesis:

 

Statement 2: Increased Mobilization of Fat from the Adipose Cell: In type 1 DM, insulin deficiency leads to increased lipolysis in adipose tissue, resulting in the release of free fatty acids into the bloodstream. These fatty acids are transported to the liver, where they undergo beta-oxidation.

Statement 3: Decreased Acetyl CoA in the TCA Cycle: Insulin deficiency also leads to reduced availability of oxaloacetate in the liver, which is diverted to gluconeogenesis. This decreases the entry of acetyl CoA into the TCA cycle, causing an accumulation of acetyl CoA.

Statement 4: Increased Beta-Hydroxybutyrate Synthase: The increased concentration of acetyl CoA leads to the synthesis of ketone bodies, including beta-hydroxybutyrate. The enzyme beta-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase catalyzes the conversion of acetoacetate to beta-hydroxybutyrate.

 

Other Statements:

  • Decreased Beta-Oxidation of Fatty Acids (1): This is incorrect. In type 1 DM, beta-oxidation of fatty acids is actually increased due to the elevated levels of free fatty acids resulting from enhanced lipolysis.

 

Additional Context:

In the absence of insulin, glucose uptake by cells is impaired, leading to increased lipolysis and subsequent beta-oxidation of fatty acids. The resulting acetyl CoA cannot enter the TCA cycle efficiently due to low levels of oxaloacetate, leading to the production of ketone bodies (acetoacetate, beta-hydroxybutyrate, and acetone).

 

Educational Objective

 

Ketosis in type 1 diabetes mellitus is caused by increased mobilization of fat from adipose tissue, decreased entry of acetyl CoA into the TCA cycle, and increased production of ketone bodies, particularly beta-hydroxybutyrate.

questions.text: A patient presents with urethral discharge. A gram stain smear is made from the discharge sample and the following microscopic image is seen. What is the most likely causative organism? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria gonorrhea

 

The clinic history along with microscopic image is suggestive of Neisseria gonorrhea.

 

Gram-negative, intracellular, cocci, usually seen in pairs (diplococci) with the adjacent sides flattened (typically kidney-shaped); (Looks like two coffee beans kissing).

 

In urethral discharge, it is predominately found within the polymorphs.

 

Gonococci do not contain capsules (meningococci do).

 

Virulence factors -

 

  • Pili: Pili mediate attachment to mucosal cell surfaces and also are antiphagocytic. Piliated gonococci are usually virulent, whereas nonpiliated strains are avirulent.
  • Lipooligosaccharides (LOS)
  • Outer membrane proteins and Opa proteins eg. Porin A: mediates invasion of the epithelial cells.
  • IgA protease hydrolyzes secretory IgA, which could otherwise block the attachment of Neisseria gonorrheae to the mucosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomonas: Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated protozoan and not a gram-negative diplococcus.

 

Option B. Chlamydia trachomatis: Causes urethritis but is an obligate intracellular bacterium that does not show the gram-negative diplococcus morphology.

 

Option D. Gardnerella: Associated with bacterial vaginosis and presents as gram-variable coccobacilli, not gram-negative diplococci.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The presence of gram-negative, intracellular, kidney-shaped diplococci in urethral discharge is characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhea, a common causative agent of sexually transmitted infections resulting in urethritis.

choices.text: Follow up with beta-hCG
Suction and evacuation

questions.text: A patient with 12 weeks amenorrhea presents with vaginal bleeding. On examination, the cervical os is open and the uterus is 14 weeks size. USG shows a snowstorm appearance. The next best step in the management is? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Suction and evacuation

 

Explanation:

 

The snowstorm appearance on ultrasound is characteristic of a complete molar pregnancy (hydatidiform mole). Molar pregnancies are abnormal pregnancies where there is an overgrowth of trophoblastic tissue.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Complete Molar Pregnancy: Presents with vaginal bleeding, an enlarged uterus greater than expected for gestational age, and a snowstorm appearance on ultrasound.
  • Treatment: The primary treatment for a molar pregnancy is suction and evacuation to remove the abnormal trophoblastic tissue.
  • Post-Evacuation Surveillance: After evacuation, it is crucial to monitor beta-hCG levels to ensure complete removal of the molar tissue and to detect any possible malignancy (e.g., choriocarcinoma).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Medical management: Medical management is not appropriate for molar pregnancy, as surgical evacuation is necessary.

 

Option B. Follow up with beta-hCG: Beta-hCG monitoring is essential after the initial treatment but not before the evacuation of the molar tissue.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is not the first line of treatment for a molar pregnancy unless there are specific complications or risk factors warranting such an invasive procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of a molar pregnancy involves suction and evacuation to remove the abnormal trophoblastic tissue, followed by post-evacuation surveillance with beta-hCG levels to monitor for persistent gestational trophoblastic disease or malignancy.

 

Ref: William’s Textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 614

questions.text: Which curve among the following represents the production of gamma-globin chains?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Orange curve

 

In the given image, the orange curve represents the gamma-globin chain production.

 

 

Gamma globin chain is produced in the fetal period and disappears by 6 months of age. Postpartum which is the pattern represented by the orange curve.

 

The type of hemoglobin variant is determined by the combination of globin chains.

Adult hemoglobin consists of 2 alpha and 2 beta chains, whereas fetal hemoglobin is made of 2 alpha and 2 gamma-globin chains. ﻿

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Green Curve: Incorrect. The green curve represents beta-globin chain production, which increases after birth and replaces gamma-globin chains in adult hemoglobin.

 

Option B. Black Curve: Incorrect. The black curve does not accurately represent any specific globin chain production in this context.

 

Option C. Blue Curve: Incorrect. The blue curve represents epsilon-globin chain production, which occurs during the embryonic stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The orange curve in the provided image represents the production of gamma-globin chains, which are crucial during the fetal period and decline after birth as beta-globin production increases.

questions.text: Phototherapy converts bilirubin to? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lumirubin

 

Phototherapy is a standard treatment for neonatal jaundice and indirect hyperbilirubinemia. The primary purpose of phototherapy is to reduce elevated bilirubin levels in the blood by converting the toxic unconjugated bilirubin into a form that can be more easily excreted by the body.

 

Mechanisms involved in phototherapy:

 

  1. Irreversible Structural Isomerization: This is the most important mechanism of phototherapy. It converts bilirubin into lumirubin, a more water-soluble isomer that can be excreted by the kidneys in an unconjugated form. Lumirubin is more easily excreted in the urine, reducing serum bilirubin levels.
  2. Reversible Photo-isomerization Reaction: This process converts toxic unconjugated bilirubin into a non-toxic configurational isomer, which can be excreted in the bile without conjugation.
  3. Photo-oxidation: This is a minor mechanism where bilirubin undergoes oxidation to form colorless products that are also excreted.

 

Contraindications: Phototherapy is contraindicated in conditions like porphyria, where exposure to light can cause severe photosensitivity and blistering.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stercobilin: This is a bile pigment formed from the breakdown of bilirubin in the intestines, giving stool its characteristic brown color. It is not directly involved in the process of phototherapy.

 

Option C. Biliverdin: Biliverdin is a precursor to bilirubin in the heme breakdown pathway. Phototherapy does not convert bilirubin back to biliverdin.

 

Option D. Urobilin: Urobilin is a product of bilirubin metabolism that is excreted in the urine, giving urine its yellow color. It is not the primary product of phototherapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phototherapy converts bilirubin into lumirubin, a water-soluble isomer that can be excreted by the kidneys, making it an effective treatment for neonatal jaundice.

questions.text: Match the following parasites with their respective hosts: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-2, C-4, D-1

 

  • Diphyllobothrium latum: Humans (definitive host), Cyclops (first intermediate host), and Fish (second intermediate host).
  • Paragonimus westermani: Humans (definitive host), Snail (first intermediate host), Crayfish and Crab (second intermediate host).
  • Brugia malayi: Humans (definitive host), Mansonia mosquito (intermediate host).
  • Fasciola hepatica: Sheep and Humans (definitive hosts), Snail (first intermediate host), Aquatic vegetation (second intermediate host).

 

Educational Objective

choices.text: Calcium Channel Blocker action
Nitric oxide mediated vasodilation

questions.text: An elderly woman on treatment for migraine presents with chest pain. She has a previous history of ischemic heart disease. Which of the following mechanism of the prescribed drug for migraine might have caused this presentation? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 5-HT agonist

 

Chest pain in an elderly woman with a history of ischemic heart disease, who is on treatment for migraine, could potentially be linked to the mechanism of action of her migraine medication. Among the options given 5-HT agonists can cause this adverse effect. Triptans and ergotamine are a group of drugs that are used in acute attacks of migraine. They act on 5HT1B/1D receptors as agonist and cause vasoconstriction of the blood vessels. Therefore, they should be avoided in patients with coronary artery disease as they can precipitate myocardial infarction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5-HT Antagonist: Serotonin (5-HT) antagonists like cyproheptadine and methysergide etc are used for prophylaxis of migraine (not in treatment). These drugs are not commonly associated with causing chest pain or exacerbating ischemic heart disease.

 

Option C. Calcium Channel Blocker Action: While calcium channel blockers (CCBs) are used in migraine prophylaxis, they are generally heart-protective and used in the treatment of angina and hypertension due to their vasodilatory effects. It's unlikely that CCBs would cause chest pain.

 

Option D. Nitric Oxide Mediated Vasodilation: Nitric oxide donors (like nitrates) are used in the treatment of angina due to their vasodilatory effects. They are not typically used in migraine treatment, and their vasodilatory action would be more likely to relieve, rather than cause, ischemic chest pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-HT Agonist includes medications like triptans (e.g., sumatriptan), which are commonly used in migraine treatment. Triptans are 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonists and can cause vasoconstriction of blood vessels. In patients with ischemic heart disease, this vasoconstriction can exacerbate angina (chest pain) or precipitate myocardial infarction, especially if the coronary arteries are already compromised.

choices.text: Bicarbonate in the intracellular compartment
Calcium in the extracellular compartment

questions.text: Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium is mainly due to? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intracellular proteins

 

Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium is mainly due to intracellular proteins.

 

The Gibbs-Donnan effect describes the unequal distribution of Diffusible charged ions on either side of a semipermeable membrane which occurs in the presence of impermeant charged ions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphate: While phosphate ions are present in both intracellular and extracellular compartments, they are not the primary cause of the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium. Their concentrations do not significantly contribute to the electrochemical gradient and osmotic balance in the same way as intracellular proteins do.

 

Option B. Bicarbonate in the intracellular compartment: Bicarbonate ions are crucial for maintaining acid-base balance, but they are not the main factor in establishing the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium. Their movement across membranes is more related to pH regulation rather than creating an electrochemical gradient due to impermeant ions.

 

Option C. Calcium in the extracellular compartment: Calcium ions are essential for various cellular functions, including muscle contraction and neurotransmission, but they do not play a primary role in the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium. Their concentration differences across membranes are tightly regulated by channels and pumps, rather than by the presence of impermeant ions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium,

 

  • On each side of the membrane, each solution will be electrically neutral
  • The product of diffusible ions on one side of the membrane will be equal to the product of diffusible ions on the other side of the membrane
  • The electrochemical gradients produced by unequal distribution of charged ions produces a transmembrane potential difference which can be calculated using the Nernst equation
  • The presence of impermeant ions on one side of the membrane creates an osmotic diffusion gradient attracting water into that compartment.

 

Intracellular proteins are negatively charged non-permeable ions, then distribution of other permeable ions is affected in a predictable way (Donnan Effect) so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal.

questions.text: Components of the MELD (2016) score are all except? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Albumin

 

The Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score is used to prioritize patients for liver transplantation and assesses the severity of chronic liver disease. The MELD score includes three laboratory values:

 

“CBI mnemonic = Creatinine, Bilirubin, INR are the parameters is MELD score.

 

Currently Sodium levels to the score and MELD-Na score used for prognostication. Hyponatremia associated with adverse outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilirubin: Reflects the liver's ability to excrete bilirubin.

 

Option C. INR (International Normalized Ratio) for prothrombin time: Indicates the liver's ability to synthesize clotting factors.

 

Option D. Creatinine: Assesses renal function, which can be compromised in liver failure. Additionally, sodium was added to the MELD score to improve its prognostic accuracy, resulting in the MELD-Na score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Albumin is not a component of the MELD score. The key components are bilirubin, creatinine, and INR, with sodium also included in the updated MELD-Na scoring system to better predict outcomes in patients with end-stage liver disease.

 

Reference: Harrison 21/Cirrhosis/Chap 344

choices.text: Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same
Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

questions.text: A team of oncologists is implementing a new treatment strategy for metastatic melanoma that significantly improves overall survival rates for patients. How would you categorize the change in incidence and prevalence of metastatic melanoma in the population treated at this center? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

 

  • The given scenario shows that there is a new treatment which can extend overall survival but cannot cure a particular disease.
  • So, old cases will live longer and thus, there will be increase in prevalence. Incidence will not get affected due to this.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incidence increases and prevalence reduces: Incorrect as the new treatment does not affect the number of new cases.

 

Option B. Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same: Incorrect because the incidence is unaffected by treatment, and the prevalence would increase due to longer survival.

 

Option D. Incidence reduces and prevalence increases: Incorrect because the incidence remains the same.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PREVALENCE

 

  • Total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over.
  • Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of disease [P = I × d]
  • Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery

 

INCIDENCE

 

  • Number of new cases occurring in a defined population over a specified period of time.

 

Note - A treatment that extends the lives of patients with a chronic condition will increase prevalence, even if incidence remains stable.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented to the OPD with painful genital ulcers. Which of the following can cause a painful ulcer on the glans penis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chancroid

 

Painful genital ulcer is caused by Chancroid.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Syphilis: The primary lesion of syphilis, known as a chancre, is typically painless. It is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum and usually presents as a firm, round, and painless ulcer.

 

Option B. Chlamydia: Chlamydia trachomatis infection can cause genital ulcers but these are generally painless and associated with lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). Chlamydia can cause urethritis, cervicitis, and other non-ulcerative conditions but is not typically associated with painful genital ulcers.

 

Option D. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV): LGV is a chronic infection of the lymphatic system caused by certain serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis. The primary lesion is usually a painless genital ulcer or papule, which may go unnoticed by the patient.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is by? (NICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exosome

 

Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is by Exosome.

 

Exosomes are extracellular vesicles generated by all cells and they carry nucleic acids, proteins, lipids, and metabolites. They are mediators of near and long-distance intercellular communication in health and disease and affect various aspects of cell biology. These vesicles are enclosed by a lipid bilayer. They are heterogeneous in size (30-2000 m diameter).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysosome: Lysosomes are organelles involved in degrading and recycling cellular waste, cellular signaling, and energy metabolism. They do not play a direct role in intercellular communication.

 

Option B. Peroxisome: Peroxisomes are involved in lipid metabolism and the detoxification of harmful substances. They are not involved in intercellular communication.

 

Option D. Genome: The genome refers to the complete set of genetic material within an organism. It is not a structure involved in intercellular communication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exosomes are key players in intercellular communication in eukaryotes, mediating the transfer of various biomolecules between cells and influencing diverse biological processes.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male with Marfanoid habitus presents with sharp chest pain and sudden onset dyspnea. Chest X-ray was performed and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C Pneumothorax

 

Explanation:

 

The given CXR shows the presence of pneumothorax, which represents air in the pleural space. 

 

DIAGNOSIS: Right pneumothorax

 

MEDIASTINAL SHIFT: Contralateral

 

MOST SENSITIVE IX: CT scan

 

MOST SENSITIVE X-RAY: Expiratory X ray

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary embolism: Often presents with sudden onset dyspnea and may show signs of right heart strain on imaging, but it does not directly cause the visible signs of air in the pleural cavity as seen in pneumothorax.

 

Option B. Hydropneumothorax: This would be indicated by both air and fluid levels within the pleural space, which are not visible in this X-ray.

 

Option D. Aortic dissection: Would potentially show mediastinal widening or other structural abnormalities, which are not depicted in this image.

 

Educational Objective:


Pneumothorax is identified by the visible presence of air in the pleural space, leading to lung collapse, and is commonly associated with sudden onset chest pain and dyspnea, especially in patients with connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in this image: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ascaris lumbricoides

 

The roundworm, Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine.

 

They are large cylindrical worms with tapered ends

 

The anterior end is more pointed than the posterior.

 

They are pale pink or flesh colored when freshly passed in stools, but become white outside the body.

 

The mouth at the anterior end has three finely toothed lips, one dorsal and two ventrolateral

 

Habitat - Small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum).

 

Natural host – Man

 

Infective form – embryonated eggs containing infective rhabditiform larvae

 

Mode of transmission – feco-oral route

 

Disease caused by A. lumbricoides is called as ascariasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strongyloides stercoralis: Causes strongyloidiasis, and the worms are much smaller and typically not as robust as those shown in the image.

 

Option B. Enterobius vermicularis: Causes enterobiasis or pinworm infection. The worms are much smaller and thinner, typically only a few millimeters long.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma duodenale: Causes hookworm infection. The worms are also smaller and have a characteristic hook shape at one end.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ascaris lumbricoides is a large, cylindrical nematode parasite found in the human intestine, easily identifiable by its size, tapered ends, and characteristic pink to white color transition. The disease it causes, ascariasis, is transmitted via the fecal-oral route.

questions.text: A male patient who just lost his work felt irritated and depressed for the majority of the time. Thinking about the future troubled him, and he was irritated with his family members. He went out to see movies with his friends on occasion and was able to enjoy himself, but when he returned home, he experienced identical sensations. What's the most likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adjustment disorder

 

The patient's symptoms – depressive mood, irritability, and worry about the future – began after a clear stressor, which in this case is the loss of his job. While he has some features of depression, the ability to temporarily feel better, such as when seeing movies with friends, makes a major depressive episode less likely.

 

This disorder arises within three months of a particular stressor (e.g., job loss) and resolves within six months after the stressor ends or the individual adapts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Generalized anxiety disorder: Chronic worry is a feature, but there is usually no specific identifiable stressor or precipitant, and the duration of symptoms should be at least 6 months.

 

Option C. Mixed anxiety with depression: This isn’t a specific DSM-5 diagnosis. While the patient has symptoms of both, the clear onset after job loss points more towards adjustment disorder.

 

Option D. Moderate depression: The patient’s ability to still experience pleasure (e.g., enjoying movies) makes a full depressive episode less likely.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Adjustment disorder is characterized by emotional responses to stressful events like financial problems, medical illness, relationship problems or death of a loved one. It manifests with emotional or behavioral symptoms which include depressed mood, anxiety, worry, a feeling of inability to cope and some degree of disturbance in individuals daily functioning. The symptoms typically remit within 6 months if the stressor has ended. Treatment of choice is supportive psychotherapy.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 112.

choices.text: Mixed meal having all 3 in equal amount

questions.text: The maximum thermic effect is seen with a meal which has? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Protein

 

Increased heat production or increased metabolic rate following the intake of food is called as thermogenic effect of food or diet-induced thermogenesis or specific dynamic action (SDA) of food.

 

Part of this is due to the expenditure of energy for digestion; absorption and active transport of products of the digestion. Another reason for this expenditure of energy is that reserve materials, such as glycogen, triacyl glycerol, protein, etc. are synthesized from small molecules available after digestion.

 

A high protein diet leads to higher protein turnover resulting in increased diet induced thermogenesis.

 

The values of SDA are: for proteins 30%, for lipids 15%, and for carbohydrates 5%. This means that out of every 100 grams of proteins consumed, the energy available for doing useful work is 30% less than the calculated value.

It is a common experience that during hot weather following the consumption of a protein rich meal, one feels hot and humid for a while. On the other hand, in cold weather, the same would provide a comfortable feeling

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fat: Fats have a moderate thermic effect, lower than proteins.

 

Option C. Carbohydrates: Carbohydrates have the lowest thermic effect.

 

Option D. Mixed meal having all 3 in equal amount: A mixed meal would have a combined thermic effect that is a weighted average of the individual macronutrient effects, which would be lower than that of a protein-only meal.

 

Real-world Observation: It is commonly observed that after consuming a protein-rich meal, especially during hot weather, individuals may feel hot and humid due to the increased heat production. Conversely, in cold weather, the same meal can provide a warming effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maximum thermic effect is seen with protein-rich meals, as proteins require more energy for digestion, absorption, and metabolism compared to fats and carbohydrates.

questions.text: Iritis is seen in all except: (INICET NOV 2020
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rheumatoid Arthritis

 

Iritis, or inflammation of the iris, is not commonly associated with Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA). Instead, RA is more commonly linked to other ocular conditions such as episcleritis and scleritis, which affect different parts of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SLE: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus can involve various parts of the eye, including the development of uveitis, which includes iritis.

 

Option B. Ulcerative Colitis: This inflammatory bowel disease is known to have extraintestinal manifestations including uveitis, which encompasses iritis.

 

Option C. Behcet's Disease: This is a multisystem inflammatory disorder that commonly affects the eyes, including the iris, making iritis a typical manifestation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rheumatoid arthritis is typically associated with scleral and episcleral inflammation rather than iritis, distinguishing it from other autoimmune conditions like SLE, Ulcerative Colitis, and Behcet's Disease that can present with iritis as a part of their systemic manifestations.

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/Rheumatoid arthritis

questions.text: A neuron is receiving 400 inputs from 150 sensory neurons. This is an example of? How would you categorize a situation where a single neuron receives inputs from 150 sensory neurons, totaling to 400 inputs? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Convergence

 

Convergence refers to the process by which multiple neurons synapse onto a single neuron, resulting in the integration of information from different sources. In this scenario, the single neuron is receiving inputs from 150 sensory neurons, indicating that there is convergence of input onto the single neuron.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Divergence: Divergence occurs when a single neuron sends its axon to synapse with multiple downstream neurons. This process spreads information from one neuron to many.

 

Option C. Feedback inhibition: This is a regulatory mechanism where a neuron sends a signal to inhibit its own activity indirectly through a network of intermediate neurons. It’s not relevant to the scenario described.

 

Option D. Feedforward excitation: This mechanism involves a neuron sending excitatory signals to downstream neurons to propagate an action potential. It’s not directly related to the scenario described.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Convergence is when multiple neurons synapse onto a single neuron, integrating inputs from various sources. In the scenario described, where one neuron receives inputs from 150 sensory neurons, convergence is the appropriate term.

questions.text:
Which of the following investigations are not used for diagnosing osteoporosis?(INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. DEXA
  2. Bone scan
  3. Quantitative CT
  4. Chemical analysis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) II, IV are correct

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • Bone mineral density is measured by DEXA scan (65 years onwards)
  • Normal Ca2+, PO‑4, ALP
  • Hemiplegic – Humerus maximum loss of bone mineral density

 

 

  • Radiological Investigation: 
    • Quantitative CT is a newer imaging technique that can be used to detect osteoporosis
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Estrogen
    • Bisphosphonates – Increases hip fracture.
    • Calcitonin
    • Low dose PTH – Stimulates osteoblasts.

 

Other Options:

 

  • A bone scan helps to examine any irregularities in the bone. Sometimes, these bone irregularities may indicate either infection or cancer disease. In addition, it can also help to detect arthritis and bone fractures.

  • Chemical analysis test will not show any diagnostic change because the serum calcium, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase levels remains normal in osteoporosis. The problem with osteoporosis is of bone quality and not its chemical makeup.

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • DEXA scan is the investigation of choice.
  • Quantitative CT is a bone mineral density (BMD) measurement technique in which the CT scanner is calibrated using solid phantoms (made of calcium hydroxyapatite, representing various bone mineral densities) placed under the patient in a pad. With this calibration, the Hounsfield units are converted to bone mineral density values. The technique can be used for both peripheral and central BMD measurements, with lumbar spine and hip being preferred locations.
  • DEXA measures the bone mineral density of both the outer (cortical) shell and the inner (trabecular) structure of the bone. QCT, on the other hand, measures only the inner part. Because of this difference, QCT studies of the spine show a lower T-score than a DEXA would.

choices.text: Cervical mucus thickening
Increase GnRH release

questions.text: Oral contraceptives act by all of the following mechanisms except: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase GnRH release

 

Explanation:

 

Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) function through several mechanisms to prevent pregnancy, but increasing the release of Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) is not one of them. In fact, OCPs inhibit the release of GnRH.

 

Mechanisms of action of OCPs:

 

  • Inhibit ovulation: By suppressing the release of GnRH, and consequently, the pituitary secretion of Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH) and Luteinizing Hormone (LH), OCPs prevent the development and release of an ovum.
  • Prevent implantation: OCPs create a less favorable endometrial environment for implantation of a fertilized egg.
  • Cervical mucus thickening: OCPs increase the viscosity of cervical mucus, making it more difficult for sperm to enter the uterus and fertilize an ovum.
  • Produce static endometrial hypoplasia: OCPs cause the endometrial lining to remain thin, which further prevents implantation.
  • Affect tubal motility: OCPs can alter the motility of the fallopian tubes, reducing the likelihood of sperm meeting an ovum.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Inhibit implantation: OCPs prevent the endometrium from becoming suitable for implantation.

 

Option B. Cervical mucus thickening: OCPs increase the thickness of cervical mucus to block sperm penetration.

 

Option C. Inhibit ovulation: OCPs suppress the hormonal signals that trigger ovulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral contraceptive pills prevent pregnancy by inhibiting ovulation, preventing implantation, thickening cervical mucus, producing static endometrial hypoplasia, and affecting tubal motility. They do not increase GnRH release; rather, they inhibit it.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition 485

choices.text: Volume of serum passing through kidney in 24 hours

questions.text: Which of the following is not required for calculation of creatinine clearance? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Volume of serum passing through kidney in 24 hours

 

The volume of plasma passing through the kidney in 24 hours is not used in the calculation of creatinine clearance.

 

Other Options:

 

The calculation of creatinine clearance involves the following parameters:

 

Option A. Urine creatinine concentration: This is the amount of creatinine present in the urine, typically measured in milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL).

 

Option B. Serum creatinine concentration: This is the amount of creatinine present in the blood, also measured in milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL).

 

Option C. 24-hour urine output: This is the total volume of urine produced in 24 hours, measured in milliliters (mL).

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Calculate the ECF volume in a volunteer in whom 10 gm of mannitol was injected in venous blood. At equilibrium urinary excretion of mannitol was found to be 10% and the plasma concentration of mannitol was 65 mg/100 ml?

In a volunteer, 10 grams of mannitol was injected into the venous blood. At equilibrium, the urinary excretion of mannitol was found to be 10% and the plasma concentration of mannitol was measured at 65 mg/100 ml. Calculate the extracellular fluid (ECF) volume based on this information. (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 14L

 

ECF volume of the above volunteer is calculated to be 14 L.

 

Mannitol is a marker of ECF volume as it does not cross the cell membrane and remains in the ECF.

 

The ECF volume can be calculated using the formula:

 

 

Where,

 

  • V = ECF volume
  • Amount injected = 10 gm
  • Amount of mannitol excreted = 10% of 10 gm = 1gm

  • Plasma concentration of mannitol = 65 mg/100mL = 0.65 gm/L

     

Calculation:

 

ECF Volume = (10-1) /0.65 = 13.8 L = approximately 14 L

 

Educational Objective:

 

The extracellular fluid (ECF) volume can be calculated by using the dilution principle, taking into account the amount of marker substance injected, the amount excreted, and the plasma concentration of the marker.

choices.text: A, B & C
A, B, C & D

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about the drugs used in Gout? (INICET Nov 2020)

A. Aspirin is not used as it decreases the uric acid excretion

B. Diclofenac is used as it concentrates in the joint

C. Indomethacin is used as it acts by multiple pathways

D. Aspirin is used as it is most powerful NSAID
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A, B & C

 

Options A. Aspirin is not used as it decreases the uric acid excretion: This statement remains correct. Aspirin at low doses can decrease uric acid excretion, potentially worsening gout. Therefore, it is generally not recommended in the management of gout.

 

Options B. Diclofenac is used as it concentrates in the joint: Diclofenac is commonly used in the management of gout due to its anti-inflammatory properties. It gets concentrated in joints and its effect in reducing inflammation and pain in gout is beneficial.

 

Options C. Indomethacin is used as it acts by multiple pathways: Indomethacin is indeed used in the treatment of gout. It is an NSAID that works by inhibiting the production of prostaglandins. It has multiple pathways of action including inhibition of COX and decrease in rate of phagocytosis of urate crystals.

 

Other Options:

 

Options D. Aspirin is used as it is the most powerful NSAID: This statement is incorrect for reasons previously mentioned. Aspirin, particularly at low doses, is not recommended for gout due to its potential to increase serum uric acid levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The preferred treatment for an acute gout attack is an NSAID (nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug), such as indomethacin.
  • A typical first-line treatment for gout is indomethacin. Besides suppressing prostaglandin synthesis, indomethacin and other NSAIDs also reduce rate of crystal phagocytosis.
  • Furthermore, intraarticular steroids like methylprednisolone or triamcinolone may be given.
  • Aspirin is not utilized because it promotes renal retention of uric acid.

questions.text: A patient presented with the complaints of chest pain. Which among the following is the best investigation to diagnose MI within 2-4 hours? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Troponin – T

 

Troponin-T is the most sensitive and specific biomarker available for diagnosing myocardial infarction (MI) within the early hours of symptom onset. It begins to rise within 3-4 hours of myocardial damage, peaks at around 12-48 hours, and remains elevated for up to 7-10 days, making it highly useful for early diagnosis and detection of recent heart damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LDH: it is a less specific enzyme that may be elevated in many types of tissue damage and is not ideal for early diagnosis of MI.

 

Option C. CKMB: it rises within 4-8 hours of myocardial injury, making it less useful than Troponin-T in the very early stages post-symptom onset.

 

Option D. BNP: it is primarily used to assess heart failure and is not a primary marker for acute myocardial infarction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Rise by >20%of troponin is used for diagnosis of Reinfarction

 

Newer biomarkers: HFABP, miRNA1,21,33

 

Reference - (Cardiology/Biomarkers, MI)

choices.text: Colposcopy and biopsy
Follow-up after 6 months

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is diagnosed with carcinoma in situ (CIS) of the cervix and no obvious macroscopic growth. What is the next line of management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conization

 

  • Carcinoma in situ is Stage 0 Cancer.
  • It means it involves the entire thickness of the epithelium without invasion of the basement membrane.
  • This should be followed by a conization as the woman is 30 years old and conization will provide us with a biopsy specimen as well as be curative
  • If family is complete/ elderly patient, simple hysterectomy should be done

 

Treatment for Different stages of cervical cancer

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: While effective, it is more invasive and typically reserved for those who have completed childbearing or for older patients.

 

Option C. Colposcopy and biopsy: This is used for further evaluation but is not the definitive treatment for CIS when the diagnosis is already confirmed.

 

Option D. Follow-up after 6 months: Follow-up without intervention is not appropriate for CIS due to the risk of progression to invasive cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a young woman diagnosed with carcinoma in situ (CIS) of the cervix, conization is the recommended next step, providing both diagnostic and therapeutic benefits.

 

Ref: FIGO Revised Staging of Cervical Cancer, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th Edition, Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 8th edition page367,

questions.text: Identify the vitamin which when deficient can lead to neonatal seizures? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pyridoxine

 

Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) deficiency is a well-known cause of refractory seizures in neonates and infants. Pyridoxine is crucial for the synthesis of neurotransmitters such as gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), which plays a key role in inhibiting neural activity. A deficiency in pyridoxine can disrupt neurotransmitter balance, leading to seizures that are often difficult to control with standard anticonvulsant therapy.

 

Neonatal seizures caused by pyridoxine deficiency typically present within the first few hours to days of life. These seizures are often clonic in nature and may involve multiple foci. The underlying cause of pyridoxine-dependent seizures is typically a mutation in the ALDH7A1 gene, which impairs the ability of an enzyme to break down I-alpha-aminoadipic semialdehyde, leading to a buildup of toxic substances that affect brain function.

 

Prompt administration of pyridoxine can rapidly resolve the seizures, making it an essential diagnostic and therapeutic consideration in neonates presenting with unexplained seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine: Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency is associated with neurological disorders like Wernicke's encephalopathy and beriberi, but it is not typically associated with neonatal seizures.

 

Option C. Riboflavin: Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) deficiency can cause ariboflavinosis, characterized by sore throat, redness and swelling of the lining of the mouth and throat, but it is not commonly linked to neonatal seizures.

 

Option D. Pantothenic acid: Pantothenic acid (Vitamin B5) deficiency is extremely rare and is associated with symptoms like fatigue, depression, and irritability, but it does not typically cause neonatal seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridoxine deficiency can cause refractory seizures in neonates, and recognizing this condition is crucial because these seizures can be rapidly treated with pyridoxine supplementation.

questions.text: The illustration below shows alternative splicing of a gene which has intron segments 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. It yields two products A and B, by the action of different promoters. You are provided with the promoters W, X, Y, and Z, each of which binds to a different segment as shown below and acts in the marked direction. Which of the following promoters will you use to get product A? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. W Y

 

Explanation:

 

A promoter is a region of DNA upstream of a gene where relevant proteins bind to initiate

transcription of that gene. In the case of this question, product A is formed by including specific

segments and excluding others through the process of alternative splicing.

 

  • Sequence A consists of segments 1, 3, 4, and 5.
    • Promoter W Required for segment 1.
    • Promoter Y Required for segments 3, 4, and 5.
    • Segment 2 is excluded during alternative splicing.

 

Thus, the combination of Promoters W and Y will result in the production of sequence A by including

the correct segments and excluding segment 2.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a (W, X, Y): This combination Required Promoter X, for segment 2, but it

    is unnecessary since W and Y alone are sufficient to yield product A.

  • Option b (W, Z): Promoter Z does not include segments 3, making this option incorrect for generating product A.
  • Option c (WX): Promoters W and X are insufficient because they do not include segments 3, 4, and 5, which are essential for product A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A promoter is a region of DNA upstream of a gene where relevant proteins bind to initiate

transcription of that gene.

 

Using promoters W, Y will yield product A by including segments 1, 3, 4, and 5 and removing segment 2 through alternative splicing.

questions.text: A school going child had applied henna and comes to dermatology OPD with the following lesions What is the possible diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dermatitis artefacta

 

The given image points towards a likely diagnosis of dermatitis Artefacta.

 

  • Dermatitis artefacta is a psychodermatological disorder where lesions are self-inflicted, often due to psychological stress or disorders. The pattern of the lesions, which are well-circumscribed and may follow an accessible pattern that the child could reach, is suggestive of dermatitis artefacta.
  • Dermatitis artefacta is a condition in which the patient deliberately produces skin lesions without any rational motive. This is a psychological ailment where the patient is fully aware of their actions.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Indicated by the symmetrical placement of lesions in accessible areas on the face, neck, chest etc. Additionally, the lesions may exhibit varying stages of healing, similar to an abrasion.
  • These visible symptoms of dermatitis artefacta can be seen as a form of nonverbal communication, representing a "cry for attention and help" from a patient who is unable to express their needs through meaningful verbal communication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contact dermatitis due to henna:
