  • Contact dermatitis from henna, often related to the chemical para-phenylenediamine (PPD), usually manifests as a diffuse, erythematous rash in areas where the henna was applied.
  • If the reaction were due to henna, one would expect to see an affected scalp where the henna was applied.
  • However, the presence of localized lesions on the cheek and the normal appearance of the scalp suggests that this is not a case of allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) caused by henna.

 

Option C. Polymorphic light eruption (PLE):

 

  • This is an abnormal reaction to sunlight it is not expected to have a direct correlation with the application of henna.
  • Lesions will be small, itchy papules or Papulo-vesicles on an erythematous background. They will also be monomorphic (unlike as the name suggests).

 

Option D. Vitiligo:

 

  • Vitiligo is characterized by depigmentation of the skin and would not present with erythematous or inflamed lesions as shown in the image.
  • It represents a loss of pigment and is not physically raised or inflamed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In assessing skin lesions, it's important to consider the psychological aspect of dermatology.
  • Dermatitis artefacta should be suspected in lesions that are localized, well-circumscribed, and do not have a distribution pattern consistent with the history or other physical causes.

 

Ref:

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology 9th edition 128.13

Kaplan & Saddocks concise textbook of clinical Psychiatry 11th edition page 435, 436

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition 405

questions.text: What would be the next suitable examination for a chronic smoker, aged 40, who is experiencing blue discoloration of the toe and intermittent claudication? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Duplex scan

 

The duplex scan is a type of ultrasound that combines traditional ultrasound with Doppler ultrasound. It can visualize the structure of blood vessels and the flow of blood within them. It is non-invasive, doesn't require the use of contrast media, and can provide immediate results. Given the patient's symptoms of blue discoloration of the toe (suggesting compromised blood flow) and intermittent claudication (pain in the legs while walking, indicating peripheral artery disease), a duplex scan is an excellent first choice to evaluate the patency of the arteries and the location and severity of any blockages. For a chronic smoker with these symptoms, a duplex scan is a commonly used initial diagnostic tool to evaluate peripheral arterial disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT Angiography: Computed tomography angiography (CTA) is a diagnostic tool that combines X-ray technology with computer imaging to visualize blood flow in the arteries. While it can provide detailed images of blood vessels and can identify blockages or other vascular problems, it requires the injection of a contrast medium, exposes the patient to radiation, and might not be the first-line diagnostic tool in this scenario.

 

Option B. MR Angiography: Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) is a type of MRI that looks specifically at blood vessels. It provides detailed images of arteries and can be useful in detecting vascular problems. However, it might not be the first choice for initial evaluation, especially when quicker, less expensive, and equally informative tests are available, like the duplex scan.

 

Option C. Digital subtraction angiography: Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is an invasive procedure that involves injecting a contrast medium into the blood vessels and taking X-ray images. It provides detailed visualization of the inner structures of blood vessels and is particularly useful for planning interventions. However, due to its invasive nature, it is typically done if planning a vascular intervention like balloon dilation or stenting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • Chronic smoking can cause peripheral arterial disease, which can present with bluish discoloration of the toe and intermittent claudication.
  • Duplex Scanning is a non-invasive technique that uses ultrasound to provide an image of the vessel and can be used to investigate this condition.
  • Duplex Scanning allows for detailed visualization of blood flow within the vessel, with different colors indicating changes in direction and velocity of flow.

questions.text: The data which best explains the difference between the highest and the lowest values is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Range

 

Range gives the difference between the highest and lowest values in a given set of data.

 

For example, in a dataset of students' marks, if the highest score is 100 and the lowest is 51, the range would be 49.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Variance: Variance (or SD2) is the mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution. It measures how far data is spread out.

 

Option B. Coefficient of variation: The coefficient of variation (CV) is used to compare the variability. It expresses the It is unitless and helps compare variability across different datasets.

 

CV= SD/ mean x 100

 

Option D. Interquartile range: Quartiles divide the distribution into four equal groups. The difference between the mid-values of each quartile gives the interquartile range, which measures the spread of the middle 50% of data.

 

Educational Objective:


Range is a simple measure that explains the spread between the highest and lowest values in a dataset, making it useful for quickly understanding data dispersion.

choices.text: Need for drug monitoring
ECG monitoring for arrhythmias
Sedation being the side effect

questions.text: A patient was treated with imipramine for a major depressive episode in the hospital for 4 weeks. What is the main concern while considering his discharge from the hospital?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  Suicidal risk

 

The main concern while considering the discharge of a patient who has been treated with imipramine for a major depressive episode is Suicidal Risk.

 

Suicidal risk is a critical concern when discharging patients who have been treated for major depression. The risk of suicide can actually increase as the patient begins to recover, partly because they may gain more energy and motivation before their mood improves significantly. Further TCA are lethal in overdose. Therefore, ensuring that the patient has a safe environment, a follow-up plan, and appropriate support upon discharge is crucial.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Need for Drug Monitoring: While some level of monitoring is advisable when a patient is on imipramine, especially for tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) blood levels in certain cases, it is not typically the primary concern at discharge for depression treatment.

 

Options B. ECG Monitoring for Arrhythmias: Although TCAs like imipramine can have cardiac side effects, including arrhythmias, and may warrant ECG monitoring, particularly in older adults or those with pre-existing heart conditions, it's not usually the primary concern at the point of discharge unless the patient has a known cardiac issue.

 

Options D. Sedation Being the Side Effect: While sedation can be a side effect of imipramine, it is generally not the main concern at discharge. The more pressing issue is the patient's mental health stability and safety.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The main concern when discharging a patient treated with imipramine for a major depressive episode is the risk of suicide. This requires ensuring that the patient has a safe environment, a follow-up plan, and appropriate support to manage their mental health effectively after discharge.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Morphine is used for treatment of pulmonary oedema
  2. Pethidine is used for treatment of pain due to biliary colic
  3. Indomethacin can cause headache
  4. Aspirin is used for treatment of peptic ulcer disease
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A and C

 

Aspirin can actually exacerbate peptic ulcer disease due to its mechanism of inhibiting prostaglandin production, which is protective for the gastric mucosa. It is more commonly associated with causing or worsening gastric ulcers rather than treating them.

 

A. Morphine is used for treatment of pulmonary edema: Morphine can be used in the acute management of pulmonary edema, particularly when it's due to heart failure. It reduces preload and afterload on the heart and can alleviate the associated anxiety and discomfort. However, its use has become less common due to concerns about potential side effects, including respiratory depression.

 

C. Indomethacin can cause headache: This is true. While Indomethacin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to treat pain, inflammation, and fever, one of its side effects can be headache.

 

Other options:

 

B. Pethidine is used for treatment of pain due to biliary colic: Pethidine (Meperidine) is generally not recommended for biliary colic because it can cause spasm of the sphincter of Oddi, potentially worsening pain in biliary coli due to its anticholinergic property.

 

D. Aspirin is used for treatment of peptic ulcer disease: This is false. Aspirin can actually exacerbate peptic ulcer disease due to its mechanism of inhibiting prostaglandin production, which protects the gastric mucosa. Aspirin is more commonly associated with causing or worsening gastric ulcers rather than treating them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Morphine can be used for the treatment of pulmonary edema, and indomethacin can cause headaches.
  • Aspirin is not used for the treatment of peptic ulcer disease and can actually worsen it. While opioids can be used for biliary colic, their use is not without complications, and not all opioids are appropriate for this condition.

choices.text: Hairy cell leukemia
Follicular lymphoma
AML M7

questions.text: Which of the following conditions will have the least chances of a dry tap on bone marrow aspiration? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Follicular lymphoma

 

Follicular lymphoma is the least likely cause of a dry tap on bone marrow aspiration.

 

A "dry tap" occurs when bone marrow aspiration fails to yield adequate marrow material, usually due to the marrow being fibrotic, densely packed with cells, or infiltrated by abnormal cells. This can occur in various hematologic conditions where the bone marrow architecture is disrupted.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hairy cell leukemia: This condition often causes extensive marrow fibrosis and infiltration by malignant cells, making bone marrow aspiration difficult, thus increasing the likelihood of a dry tap.

 

Option C. AML M7 (Acute Megakaryoblastic Leukemia): This subtype of acute myeloid leukemia is associated with marrow fibrosis, which can result in a dry tap during bone marrow aspiration.

 

Option D. Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS): Some subtypes of MDS can cause fibrosis and hypercellularity, leading to a higher likelihood of a dry tap.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of dry tap are:

 

  • Faulty technique
  • Metastatic carcinoma infiltration
  • Chronic myeloid leukemia
  • Myelofibrosis
  • Hairy cell leukemia
  • Acute leukemia
  • Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • AML- M7

choices.text: 2, 4, and 5
1, 2, and 3
1, 3, and 4

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is correct regarding Peutz-Jeghers syndrome? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. Arborizing pattern of smooth muscle
  2. Loss of heterozygosity in the STK11 gene
  3. Multiple Gl polyps
  4. Autosomal recessive
  5. Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium is seen
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, and 3

 

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant, hereditary disorder.

 

Characterized by

 

  • Multiple intestinal hamartomatous polyps having an arborizing pattern of smooth muscle.
  • Mucocutaneous dark blue to brown melanin pigmentation, which is particularly evident on the face, buccal mucosa, hands, feet, perianal and genital regions

 

 

Germline heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the STK11 gene are present in approximately half of individuals with familial Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

 

Presents at a median age of 11 years.

 

The hamartomatous polyps seen in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome are characterized by a branching network of smooth muscle fibers continuous with the muscularis mucosa that supports the glandular epithelium of the polyp.

 

 

Complications:

 

  • Intussusception, which is occasionally fatal.
  • Markedly increased risk of many malignant conditions. Lifetime risk is approximately 40% and regular surveillance is recommended from a very young age for sex cord tumors of the testes.
  • During later life, there is a risk for gastric and small intestinal cancers, and subsequently for colon, pancreatic (100%), breast, lung, ovarian, and uterine cancers.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Autosomal recessive (4): Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is not autosomal recessive; it is autosomal dominant.
  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (5): This is a feature associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), not Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is characterized by an arborizing pattern of smooth muscle, loss of heterozygosity in the STK11 gene, and multiple GI polyps, and it is autosomal dominant.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1557

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with long hands and feet, and a protruding lower jaw. Which of the following genes is most likely implicated in this scenario? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PIT1

 

Mutations of the pituitary-specific gene PIT-1 can lead to the development of a somatotroph adenoma which produces elevated levels of GH Growth hormone (and IGF-1) which can lead to acromegaly as given in the clinical scenario above.

 

Somatotrophs, mammosomatotrophs, and lactotrophs are derived from stem cells that express the pituitary transcription factor, PIT-1.

 

If the increased levels of GH are present after closure of the epiphyses, acromegaly develops. In this condition, growth is most conspicuously seen in

 

  • Skin and soft tissues, viscera (thyroid, heart, liver, and adrenals).
  • The bones of the face, hands, and feet are thickened and enlarged.
  • Bone density may increase (hyperostosis) in both the spine and the hips.
  • Enlargement and protrusion of the jaw is seen (prognathism), and broadening of the lower face.
  • The feet and hands are enlarged, and the fingers become thickened and sausage-like.

 

 

GH excess can also be associated with a variety of other manifestations, like gonadal dysfunction, diabetes mellitus, generalized muscle weakness, hypertension, arthritis, congestive heart failure, and an increased risk of gastrointestinal cancers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GATA1: This gene is associated with hematopoiesis and mutations in GATA1 are linked to blood disorders, not acromegaly.

 

Option C. TPIT (TBX19): This gene is involved in the development of corticotroph cells in the pituitary and is associated with ACTH production, not GH.

 

Option D. SF1 (Steroidogenic factor 1): SF1 is important in the development of the adrenal glands and gonads, and its mutations are associated with disorders of sex development, not acromegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PIT1 mutations are implicated in the development of somatotroph adenomas, leading to acromegaly with features such as enlarged hands, feet, and a protruding lower jaw.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathological basis of disease 8th edition pg 2129

choices.text: EBV Negative
CD 30 Negative
CD 20 positive
Poor prognosis compared to classical HL

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Poor prognosis compared to classical HL

 

Nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma (NLPHL) is a subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma that is distinct from classical Hodgkin lymphoma (cHL). NLPHL is characterized by the presence of lymphocyte and histiocyte (L&H) cells, also known as "popcorn cells," which are CD20 positive and CD30 negative. Unlike classical Hodgkin lymphoma, NLPHL is typically EBV negative and has an excellent prognosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. EBV Negative: NLPHL is usually negative for Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), distinguishing it from some subtypes of classical Hodgkin lymphoma, where EBV can be present.

 

Option B. CD30 Negative: CD30 is a marker typically expressed in classical Hodgkin lymphoma but not in NLPHL, making this statement true for NLPHL.

 

Option C. CD20 Positive: NLPHL cells express CD20, a B-cell marker, which is another feature that distinguishes it from classical Hodgkin lymphoma, where CD20 is typically negative.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Activated partial thromboplastin time
Prothrombin time

questions.text: A child was brought to the emergency department with a big lesion on his forearm. As a surgery resident you decide to excise the lesion in the emergency operation theatre. Which of the following investigations will test the entire coagulation pathway? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thromboelastography

 

Thromboelastography (TEG) tests the entire coagulation pathway. It measures coagulation cascade, platelet function, and fibrinolysis.

 

It is a test that quantitatively measures the ability of whole blood to form a clot. The advantages are:

 

  • Global assessment of blood coagulability, including coagulation cascade, platelet function, and fibrinolysis
  • Rapid real-time bedside test with a simple methodology (point-of-care testing)
  • Diagnosis of coagulopathic bleeding
  • Guide transfusion therapy and decrease the use of blood products
  • Detect dynamic changes in blood coagulation during resuscitation
  • Predict the clinical efficacy of therapeutic agents affecting blood coagulability

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT): aPTT assesses the intrinsic and common pathways of the coagulation cascade. It does not measure platelet function or fibrinolysis, so it does not test the entire coagulation pathway.

 

Option B. Prothrombin time (PT): PT assesses the extrinsic and common pathways of the coagulation cascade. Similar to aPTT, it does not evaluate platelet function or fibrinolysis, making it less comprehensive than TEG.

 

Option D. Bleeding time: Bleeding time is primarily a test of platelet function and vascular integrity. It does not assess the coagulation cascade or fibrinolysis and thus does not provide a full picture of the coagulation pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thromboelastography (TEG) is the most comprehensive test for evaluating the entire coagulation pathway, including coagulation factor activity, platelet function, and fibrinolysis, making it ideal for intraoperative and emergency settings.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537061/

choices.text: 15 follicular cell clusters contain 10-12 cells
10 follicular cell clusters contain 6-8 cells
3 follicular cell clusters contain 10-15 cells
6 follicular cell clusters contain 10-15 cells

questions.text: The most appropriate biopsy specimen in case of a thyroid biopsy is? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6 follicular cell clusters contain 10-15 cells

 

For a thyroid biopsy, particularly when using fine-needle aspiration (FNA), the adequacy of the sample is crucial for accurate diagnosis. The adequacy is determined by the number of follicular cell clusters present and the number of cells within those clusters.

 

The most appropriate specimen should have at least 6 follicular cell clusters, each containing 10-15 cells. This ensures that there is sufficient cellular material for a definitive cytological diagnosis, whether for assessing benign conditions like colloid nodules or diagnosing neoplasms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The following cytologic findings have been used to define specimen adequacy:

questions.text:
Blood examination shows pancytopenia, which can be correct? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. Megaloblastic anemia
  2. Hairy cell leukemia
  3. MDS with hypocellular BM
  4. APML
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

Megaloblastic anemia (hypocellular phase), hairy cell leukemia, and MDS (hypocellular bone marrow) can show pancytopenia.

 

  1. Megaloblastic anemia: This type of anemia, often caused by vitamin B12 or folate deficiency, can lead to pancytopenia, especially in its more severe or hypocellular phase. The bone marrow in megaloblastic anemia can show hypercellularity with ineffective hematopoiesis, but in some cases, it can present as hypocellular, contributing to pancytopenia.
  2. Hairy cell leukemia: This is a type of chronic B-cell lymphoproliferative disorder. It is commonly associated with pancytopenia due to bone marrow infiltration by hairy cells and associated fibrosis, which suppresses normal hematopoiesis.
  3. MDS with hypocellular BM: Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) are a group of hematologic conditions characterized by ineffective hematopoiesis and dysplasia in one or more of the myeloid cell lines. In cases of MDS with a hypocellular bone marrow, pancytopenia can occur due to the reduced production of blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) is typically not associated with pancytopenia. APML usually presents with leukocytosis or normal white cell counts, along with thrombocytopenia and anemia. However, severe pancytopenia is not a characteristic feature, and therefore, APML is not typically associated with pancytopenia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of pancytopenia –

 

I. Aplastic anemia

 

II. Pancytopenia with normal or increased marrow cellularity e.g.

 

  1. Myelodysplastic syndromes
  2. Hypersplenism
  3. Megaloblastic anemia

 

III. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (page 314)

 

IV. Bone marrow infiltrations e.g.

 

  1. Hematologic malignancies (leukemias, lymphomas, myeloma)
  2. Non-hematologic metastatic malignancies
  3. Storage diseases
  4. Osteopetrosis
  5. Myelofibrosis

questions.text: What will be the most likely associated condition with increased TSH and low T4 levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hashimoto's thyroiditis

 

Increased TSH and low T4 levels are seen in primary hypothyroidism. Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the only cause of primary hypothyroidism in the given options.

 

Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual & progressive thyroid failure. It is the most common cause of primary hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. There are also autoantibodies against thyroid receptors, thyroid peroxidase, and thyroglobulin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoparathyroidism: Hypoparathyroidism is generally not associated with hypothyroidism, except in certain congenital multisystem disorders such as DiGeorge's syndrome.

 

Option C. Grave's disease: Grave's disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. It is an autoimmune disorder caused by autoantibodies against the TSH receptor, leading to elevated T3 and T4 levels with low TSH levels.

 

Option B. Pituitary Adenoma: A TSH-producing pituitary adenoma can increase TSH levels, but this would result in elevated T3 and T4 levels as well.

 

Educational Objective:


Primary hypothyroidism is characterized by increased TSH and low T4 levels. Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of primary hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas.

choices.text: Vagal output to cardiac fibers increase

questions.text: Which of the following events occur immediately when a person changes his/her posture from supine to standing?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decrease in firing from baroreceptor 

 

There is a decreased firing from the baroreceptors.

 

  • When a person stands up from a lying down position, it causes pooling of the blood in the legs, due to gravity. This reduces the venous return and leads to a decrease in cardiac output.
  • Reduced cardiac output leads to a fall in blood pressure, which, in turn, causes reduced firing from baroreceptors.
  • As a result, the vagal tone is suppressed, leading to an increased heart rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vagal output to cardiac fibers increase: Incorrect. The vagal output decreases to allow an increase in heart rate to maintain blood pressure when standing.

 

Option C. Mesenteric Vasoconstriction: Incorrect. Although vasoconstriction occurs to help maintain blood pressure, mesenteric vasoconstriction is not the immediate response.

 

Option D. Increase cardiac contractility: Incorrect. Increased cardiac contractility occurs as a compensatory mechanism, but it is not the initial response to standing up.

 

Educational Objective:


When a person stands up from a supine position, there is a pooling of blood in the lower extremities, leading to reduced venous return and cardiac output, which results in decreased baroreceptor firing and subsequent compensatory mechanisms to maintain blood pressure.

questions.text:
Which of the following increases in COPD? 

 

  1. FRC
  2. TLC
  3. VC
  4. FEV1/FVC
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 2

 

In COPD, the Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) increases. Total Lung Capacity (TLC) may be increased or normal. Hence, both 1 and 2 are correct.

 

  • In obstructive lung diseases, both FEV1 and FVC reduce, with the decrease in FEV1 being greater than the reduction in FVC. As a result, the ratio of FEV1/FVC decreases.
  • Total lung capacity is usually normal in chronic bronchitis but is increased in emphysema.
  • Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration. In COPD, FRC is increased.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 only: Incorrect. While FRC does increase, TLC may also be increased in COPD, making option A incomplete.

 

Option B. 1 and 4: Incorrect. FEV1/FVC ratio decreases in COPD, so option 4 is incorrect.

 

Option C. 1 and 3: Incorrect. Vital Capacity (VC) does not increase in COPD; it typically decreases or remains unchanged.

 

Educational Objective:


In COPD, there is an increase in Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) and potentially Total Lung Capacity (TLC), particularly in cases of emphysema. FEV1/FVC ratio decreases, reflecting the obstructive nature of the disease.

questions.text: Rees and Ecker diluting fluid is used in _______?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) RBC Pipette

 

Rees and Ecker's solution is used as a diluting fluid in the RBC pipette for performing platelet counts. Its composition includes:

 

Components and Values:

 

  • Sodium citrate: 3.8 g
  • Formaldehyde (40%): 0.2 ml
  • Brilliant cresyl blue: 0.1 g
  • Distilled water: 100 ml

 

Steps Involved in Platelet Count:

 

  1. Filling the pipette
    • The diluting fluid is drawn to mark 1 of the RBC pipette and expelled.
    • Blood is aspirated to 0.5 mark of the RBC diluting pipette.
    • Diluting fluid is aspirated to the 101 mark.

 

Other Options Explanation:

 

Option A. Wintrobe tube: Incorrect. The Wintrobe tube is used in the determination of erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and hematocrit values.

 

Option B. WBC Pipette: Incorrect. The WBC pipette is used with other diluting fluids specific for leukocyte counts, not Rees and Ecker's fluid.

 

Option D. Hemoglobin pipette: Incorrect. Hemoglobin pipettes are used for hemoglobin estimation, typically not requiring Rees and Ecker's solution.

 

Educational Objective:


Rees and Ecker’s solution is specifically used in the RBC pipette to dilute blood samples for accurate platelet counting.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parathyroid adenoma

 

Parathyroid adenoma is a benign tumor of the parathyroid gland, which causes primary hyperparathyroidism (not secondary).

 

Secondary hyperparathyroidism is characterized by high levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) to compensate for low levels of serum calcium, due to another underlying condition.

 

Causes of Secondary Hyperparathyroidism Include:

 

  • Chronic kidney disease: The damaged kidneys cannot produce sufficient amounts of the active form of vitamin D, 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol, leading to hypocalcemia and triggering PTH secretion.
  • Vitamin D deficiency: Results in hypocalcemia, which in turn increases PTH secretion.
  • Lithium: Can increase the set-point of calcium for PTH suppression, leading to parathyroid hyperplasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lithium intake: Correct for secondary hyperparathyroidism. Lithium may increase the set-point of calcium for parathyroid hormone suppression.

 

Option C. Vitamin D deficiency: Correct for secondary hyperparathyroidism. Vitamin D deficiency causes hypocalcemia, stimulating PTH secretion.

 

Option D. Chronic kidney disease: Correct for secondary hyperparathyroidism. Chronic kidney disease impairs active vitamin D production, resulting in hypocalcemia and increased PTH.

 

Educational Objective:


Parathyroid adenoma is associated with primary hyperparathyroidism. Secondary hyperparathyroidism arises from conditions that lead to hypocalcemia, such as chronic kidney disease, vitamin D deficiency, or lithium intake.

choices.text: Extend knee and plantar flex foot
Flex knee and plantar flex foot

questions.text: A pregnant woman has cramps in her legs. What will you suggest her to relieve the pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extend knee and dorsiflex foot

 

Extension at the knee joint and dorsiflexion at the ankle joint helps in stretching the calf muscles, which relieves the pain.

 

Leg cramps are common during pregnancy, often due to a deficiency of diffusible serum calcium or an elevation of serum phosphorus. Management includes:

 

  • Massaging the leg
  • Stretching exercises
  • Application of local heat
  • Supplementation of vitamin B1 and calcium

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flex knee and dorsiflex foot: Incorrect. This position does not adequately stretch the calf muscles and may not relieve the cramp.

 

Option C. Extend knee and plantar flex foot: Incorrect. Plantar flexion can worsen the cramp by further contracting the calf muscles.

 

Option D. Flex knee and plantar flex foot: Incorrect. This position does not stretch the calf muscles and may exacerbate the pain.

 

Educational Objective:


To relieve leg cramps, suggest extension of the knee and dorsiflexion of the foot to effectively stretch the calf muscles. Additionally, consider correcting any nutritional deficiencies associated with leg cramps in pregnancy.
